<answer>



Never! You must never try to pass a judgment on yourself quite like this. You have not solitary right on your life, the life that we have by the reason of many other lives around you, lives that have been before you and the one will come after you. This is the reality of each human life that stops us from becoming autocratic even in the matters of our own affairs. We must think for others even when we think entirely for the good of our own purposes. This is not possible anyway to cast a world full of people out of our thoughts and stay normal.



This therefore is not for you alone to decide as what sort of person you are, have been or will become in the future. This has never been a decision for you to make and will never be. If you look carefully into your own opinions and beliefs then you will realize that all you know about yourself is to a very great extent dependant upon your interaction with the people in your life, on their opinions, general conduct towards you and general response to your demands and requests. This therefore is not possible for you to reach any final conclusion about your person, which is a terrible thing to do anyway if you do it against what might be decisive good in you.



But if you do somehow manage to convince yourself that you are a bad person indeed then you will be waiting for this ‘verdict’ to be over thrown and overruled by the new knowledge you will gather about yourself, as you will definitely making all people in your interaction make nearly equally bad, which most of them are not going like. You will be taught anew as for instance how to respect people, including yourself, love them and respect them when goings on are not as good.



I wonder why there are so much pain and suffering in some people’s lives. May be certain people get too harsh and judgmental on themselves? May be people who form rigid opinions and view, about life, others and themselves, are people who eventually come to mend their views, or suffer a breakdown of some sort?



</answer>

What is man's accomplishments, buildings that crumble, knowledge that is forgotten, compared to the ever lasting sky?  Given the enormity of nature (the universe), to be self important, is to be evil.  If "good," is what lies within nature, that is, nature is as huge and powerful as it is, because it is 'good,' and no part of it is selfish.  There is no part of nature that lives for, or loves only itself, hence it endures long.  That is why therefore, to be self-important, is to go in contrary to the nature of nature, the nature of existence..."



Daoists are basically arguing here, that truly evil people, are people who love and live for, only for themselves.  Benjamin Franklin even warned "he who loves only himself will have no rivals." I'd choose to sacrifice myself, so that two of my family members can be saved. I have nothing to contribute to this world, whereas the rest of my family are more useful beings.



My mom is super caring; my dad's funny and selfless; my brothers are highly intelligent. The world would be a better place if they remained, while I disappear.



Is that a fair answer? Who would you choose?



</answer>

<question>



What do you think this means?



My Philosophy teacher handed a piece of paper to each of us today- and then left.  He had written on the board:  "Read the paper, tell me what you think it means."
I know what I think it means... But I'm curious as to what you think it means... Let me know.  Here it is:



"Salvation needn't come at the cost of faith,
Love needn't die on the steps of hatred,
and One need not feel the pain of Death whispered.



I fear no man, nor God.
I fear not plague, nor death.
I fear only one-



I seek what I fear.
I fear what I seek.
I seek only thyself."



So what do you think it means?
I'm open to any answers... really.
Thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



Sadie P
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 512 (Level 2)



</answer from>

<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I fear only one- I seek what I fear and he fears what he seeks and he seeks only thyself (himself).  He fears only himself or mankind in general.

<question>



Is this any reason to give a friend the silent treatment for a full month?



My friend is Bipolar and we've been intimate. I'm trying to make a very long story short:



1. My friend posted a myspace bulletin which said he got a new job at mcdonalds, and he posted the exact location.



2. Naturally I was thinking he posted the bulletin , which gave the exact location of his employemnt to ALL his friends, for a reason...because he wants his friends to visit him at mcdonalds.



3. I visited him at mcdonalds to surprise him and say hello.



4. He basically gives me the cold shoulder and ignores me



5. I write an email apologizing for the unnannounced visit



6. He accepts my apology with a two word email: "It's cool."



7. Ten days later when i dont hear from him i send an email saying " i miss you" and i ask "are you mad at me?"



8. He writes back "We cant talk anymore", then blocks me from his myspace , and removes me as a friend.



9. He ignores all my attempts to fix things (email, messages, text, voicemail, calls) for over a full month, a total of 35 days



10. We're friends again.



11. He claims the reason he gave me the "silent treatment" was because his new "boyfriend" was going to call the COPS on me for "stalking" him because I visited mcdonalds ( a public restaurant) just ONE time and for only 5 minutes.



11. It's not stalking if you only see someone ONCE and never do it again. Plus I apologized for the misunderstanding and he accepted my apology.



12. So it begs the question: Do you think he gave me the REAL reason why he gave me the "silent treatment" for 35 days?



We're friends now and I dont think it would be wise for me to "revisit the past" to find the "truth" because I value our friendship too much to lose him again.



</question>

they're no longer together now anyway



maybe thats why we are friends again

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



Sword to cut my own path
Member since: 30 May 2008
Total points: 67 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Can you tell me What is a person?



give me three points, as to what makes a person a person and a conclusion or any other thoughts you have on artificial intelligence , thank you



</question>



<additional details>



this is for an essay i have to do at school, Im asking this because I ,need (3) argumentative points , but i don't know what to write for those thanks for the answers.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Doctor Why
Member since: 25 July 2006
Total points: 40467 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



A person is NOT synonymous with being a human. There are copious examples (even today) of human beings considered to be other things than persons - most often property instead. 'De-personing' someone is, in my observation, one of the most common ways of justifying behaviours that would otherwise be completely unacceptable if they were performed on another person. America de-persons criminals, terrorists, and enemies in war rather regularly.



Nor is a person a thinking being. A human who is mentally incapable may still be considered a person even when a genius is not. I can recall cases of people born without a brain having their rights staunchly defended and genius slaves being oppressed more BECAUSE they were smart.



I think we should take a cue also from children. Sometimes a child will insist on having a beloved stuffed animal given a place at the dinner table. And many men (more than you would think) present valentine's day gifts to their cars but not their spouses. What defense does a child give for this insistence? "They're a real person!"  A Hagerty survey on cars showed people spending more on their car than their significant other (60%), talking to it on a regular basis (62%), and even buying it a Valentine's Day gift (29%). Not exactly behaviours we would expect toward simple objects.



This suggests that 'personhood' is a status that we set in our minds. A person is someone who should be afforded rights and status similar to yourself. They are an entity and an individual worthy of a certain basic respect and tolerance. Someone who is NOT a person does not (in the mind of the viewer) deserve any of these things.



Who is a person and who is not, then, tells us a lot more about the being who is making such a declaration than the entities that he is talking about. Being a person is a judgement, not an intrinsic quality.



There are doubtlessly lots of different things people might use to make this judgement.  And intelligence probably helps, as does being alive.  But these are only in a populist sense and not definitional barriers.  My take, for what it's worth.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank you



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



lockheed...
Member since: 08 July 2007
Total points: 174 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I can't give you much but you might want to include the Turin test for artificial intelligence



An interrogator is connected to one person and one machine via a terminal, therefore can't see her counterparts. Her task is to find out which of the two candidates is the machine, and which is the human only by asking them questions. If the machine can "fool" the interrogator, it is intelligent.



</answer>



<answer from>



reddzorr...
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 128 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If some thing recognizes that they exist and are a person, and can make choices.



If some thing can make choices based on data and predict future outcomes in an application never before directly interacted with by making conjectures.



If some thing's mental being (personality, morals, memories) could have developed in a different way without the direct interference of sentient beings.



If some thing can learn from it's experiences and could adjust every aspect of it's behavior (philosophical def.) by it's will.



</answer>



<answer from>



starkids...
Member since: 18 October 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)

</answer>

<answer from>



Envious Sleep
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 266 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hey, leave the monkey out of this!



It's very obviously just an insult. Constructive criticism is criticism that will help; they provide advice and examples and specifically point out the faults so that the author/artist/whatever will know what is wrong and will therefore be able to change it and improve.



Telling someone they suck worse than a monkey does not help.
"Ok, so I suck worse than a monkey...what now? I don't know what to change! D="



EDIT: We are not "advance versions of monkeys." We are, actually, very close relatives and did not evolve from monkeys, but rather bipedal hominids. We only share 98% of our genes with chimpanzees, and I believe a smaller percentage with other species of monkeys.



More over, you are being EHTNOCENTRIC. You shoud not be comparing and judging another culture's morals and intelligence based on your own. Primates have their own culture and just because they live in the wild it does not mean that they are more "heathen" or "savage" than we are. In fact, they feel emotions just as humans do and are able to solve complex problems and invent tools. They even have turf wars.



Source(s):



Anthropology coursepack =3
And what I remember from class.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ms. Revolution
Member since: 27 January 2008
Total points: 2735 (Level 4)

<question from>



#1 Jocker
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 39 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



"You don't have to paint a figure to express human feelings." Do you agree? Explain.  ?



Can Abstract Art Convey Feelings?



</question>



<answer from>



Chaitali N
Member since: 22 December 2007
Total points: 4483 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, why not!



</answer>



<answer from>



Celine
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 141 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, abstractly.



</answer>



<answer from>



andymark...
Member since: 29 March 2006
Total points: 2020 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The "Art Renewal Center" claims that if you stare at an oil slick long enough, you will think that it's saying something to you. This isn't my opinion, though it rings somewhat true to me. I feel that landscapes, animals, and even small-scale still-lifes can also portray human emotions. And I feel that certain stylizations of these images can also bring even more emotion into the peice. But there's a point when stylization becomes complete abstraction, and I don't like it anymore.



So I think that both purely abstract works, and purely realistic peices, seem emotionless and dead. The real emotions lie between the two.



</answer>

#1 Jocker
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 39 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Freud's Oedipus Complex  ?



Do you see any merits to the Oedipus Complex? (Most would agree that actually desiring sex with one parent and killing off the other is a bit extreme, but could there be a “kernel” of truth in this theory about the way little boys & girls bond and develop early instinctive relationships with parents of the opposite sex?) Since this would be an example of the kind of desire that is “repressed” below the level of consciousness, what kind of clinical evidence might count for or against such a notion. Is a repressed desire inherently untestable?



</question>

<question from>



V Aletheia
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 1115 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Who is your favorite philosopher/s and why?



Feel free to add particular texts that may have changed your life.



I would say:



-Arthur Schopenhauer's "The World as Will & Representation", "Parerga and Paralipomena", and "Essays & Aphorisms"



-Karl Marx's "Kapital" and his and Engel's "Communist Manifesto"



-Ludwig Wittgenstein's "Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus"



</question>



<additional details>



Hahahaha great response.



</additional details>



<answer from>



bstilnkn...
Member since: 21 June 2008
Total points: 557 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I like your choices - Western as they are.



Nagarjuna (150-250 ce) is a favorite for me because he previsions so many Westerners.  Nagarjuna describes findings of modern physics very accurately.



A direct parent of Marx, if you ask me....



"Nagarjuna's philosophy represents something of a watershed not only in the history of Indian philosophy but in the history of philosophy as a whole, as it calls into questions certain philosophical assumptions so easily resorted to in our attempt to understand the world.  Among these assumptions are the existence of stable substances, the linear and one-directional movement of causation, the atomic individuality of persons, the belief in a fixed identity or selfhood, and the strict separations between good and bad conduct and the blessed and fettered life.  All such assumptions are called into fundamental question by Nagarjuna's unique perspective which is grounded in the insight of emptiness (sunyata), a concept which does not mean "non-existence" or "nihility" (abhava), but rather the lack of autonomous existence (nihsvabhava).  Denial of autonomy according to Nagarjuna does not leave us with a sense of metaphysical or existential privation, a loss of some hoped-for independence and freedom, but instead offers us a sense of liberation through demonstrating the interconnectedness of all things, including human beings and the manner in which human life unfolds in the natural and social worlds."



Source(s):



http://www.iep.utm.edu/n/nagarjun.htm



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Bravo. And thanks for the quote and link.



</asker's comment>

<question from>



Leena
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 68 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why civil society principles are ideal and not applicable? with consideration of human nature of born equal?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Today a child is learning to walk. She reaches across the table to test the feel of a whiskey bottle tipped over on its side in front of parents who are passed out and unable to know or care about this milestone in her development. The flavor of her first step comes from the drop of whiskey she samples from the fingers dipped in the puddle in front of the bottle.



Today a child is learning to walk. Daddy holds her wavering form patiently with hands ready to catch her from behind as she totters toward Mama whose hands are outstretched and ready to catch her from in front.



The equality of these two children is a principal of civil society one must stretch mightily to conceptualize, much less apply. Their inequalities will characterize their entire lives.



</answer>

<question>



Comment on any one or more of the following quotes by Sartre: “Man is nothing else but what he makes of him...?



Comment on any one or more of the following quotes by Sartre: “Man is nothing else but what he makes of himself.” “I am responsible for myself and for everyone else.” “We are alone with no excuses.” “Even if God did exist, that would change nothing.”



</question>



<answer from>



Chaitali N
Member since: 22 December 2007
Total points: 4483 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



man is what he makes out of his deeds/actions as actions speaks louder then anything in this world.



</answer>



<answer from>



Time Will Tell
Member since: 19 March 2007
Total points: 7535 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



All 4 comments are bold but sounds like something he was taught not learned or overcame. I don't think it's worthy of my view of good insight or guidance.



</answer>



<answer from>



kismet hardy
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 217 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The irony of the first statement can't be lost here. We are all gathered in a place where we have to care how complete strangers 'rate' our pseudonym! In this gossip-obsessed world, it would seem what we make of ourselves has little value unless someone else validates it...



The second quote has lost a lot of value in today's society too. Those people are now seen as selfish, self-obsessed and generally high-maintenance...



God doesn't have any more of a say over the evils of the world than a black president will be able to change what America does to it...



</answer>



<answer from>



chalf
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 1654 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



“Man is nothing else but what he makes of himself.”



I agree with this quote the most. More often than not, we tend to limit our own potential and capabilities by getting affected by how others view us. If we just let ourselves go on with our lives unfettered by others' criticisms and discouragements, we probably would dare to do things which we thought are impossible for us before.



"I am responsible for myself and for everyone else.”



He sounds like an egoistic freak here. I say he's trying too hard to carry upon the world's responsibility on his shoulders.



"Even if God did exist, that would change nothing.”



If God exists, that in itself would be very much of a surprise already for most people, and wouldn't that be the most dramatic change ever experienced for mankind? Anything could happen then with such a revelation.



</answer>

<question from>



Switch It Up!
Member since: 01 November 2008
Total points: 234 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What good is knowledge if it's not accompanied by wisdom?



I take a step back and look at the picture, I look at the world in a third person and I see that we have so much knowledge but so little wisdom.



Take a look at the world like I have, see it in such disarray? With wisdom it wouldn't be like this! It would be a utopia with the knowledge we have now!



So tell me, what good is knowledge if you can't wield it to it's fullest potential?



</question>



<answer from>



Andrew T
Member since: 02 November 2008
Total points: 97 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Wisdom is the ability to make accurate and "better" decisions based on the available knowledge you have currently processed'"



</answer>



<asker's comment>



You are the only one who understood my question.



</asker's comment>



<comments>



Switch It Up!



This is to the last answer, your statement "One could ask what good is wisdom without knowledge".



I believe that isn't correct, Because one can't be wise without knowledge, Solomon the wise emphasizes this in proverbs. So it's impossible for one to be wise and illiterate at the same time.



</comments>



<answer from>
Member since: 15 June 2006
Total points: 3906 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



knowledge you learn with school, time and life experiences.



wisdom is something that you learn by trial and error and living through things, wisdom can be passed down from generation to generation.



You build knowledge as you go along but you build wisdom after you learn life's lessons.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mithrim
Member since: 23 March 2008
Total points: 884 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Knowledge can be sought and learned, wisdom must be earned and achieved.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sℸ eupraxsophist
Member since: 26 July 2006
Total points: 12010 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



One could also ask what good is wisdom without knowledge.



You think the world is in disarray now?  It is a mistake to think that we live in a unique time in history.  Things could certainly be better, but they could also be much, much worse.  The wars of today are nothing compared to the struggles for our very existence against the Nazis & communists last century.  The economic crisis of today is nothing compared to the much higher unemployment rate and much lower standard of living in the Great Depression.



Wisdom, or lack of, is a part of human nature.  We are not so removed from the animals as many of us would like to think we are.  Humans are still quite susceptible to being swayed by their beliefs and emotions, and rational thought is still very much the exception rather than the rule.  We would rather be right than correct, so we cling to religions and political ideologies in spite of the chaos, strife and suffering they so plainly cause.  We are insecure, so we cling to nationalism and other forms of "us vs. them" thinking so that we have one group to feel connected to and another we can focus our more negative emotions on.



Knowledge is a tool, wisdom is how you use that tool.  That tool is certainly less effective if you don't know how to use it properly, but it's still better than not having it to use at all.  Knowledge has demonstrably made our society & civilization much better, despite our less-than-complete use of wisdom.



Besides, what most people call wisdom is really just opinion.  There often is no objectively "best way" to use knowledge.  Even in a perfectly rational world, how we use our knowledge depends on our needs, desires and priorities, all of which differ from one person to the next.



</answer>

<answer from>



Divinity...
Member since: 25 October 2007
Total points: 295 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't believe beauty CAN be defined.
Beauty is purely an opinion. If there was no living, intelligent being to distinguish beauty then would it even exist?
Some may find something beautiful that others find ugly and so like other things such as "what defines good music", it has no definition.



On the other hand the dictionary defines beauty as "the qualities that give pleasure to the senses" so this definition can be applied separately to each individual but there is no universal definition that can be applied to everyone as a whole as it is purely opinionated.



Divinitywolf



</answer>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



~Hum
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 293 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Do you ever feel like the world is full of hate and anger?



I'm an idealist-- I know, I know. I Do believe that there is much good in the world and in people, but am I the only one who's disgusted by what one person can do to others sometimes??  It's atrocious, and yet though there are people who try to make the world a better place, there really isn't a way to stop it.  I think it's wrong to close your eyes to the evils of the world and ignore them.  If you walk past a person in need, but only see someone with personal issues-- well, duh, everyone has their own issues, but walking by with veiled eyes... I think it's wrong.  Experience has taught me that more times than not, that those who you help aren't likely to appreciate it, and spit on you back, but I keep at it because there are people who you can help... those who need it... and are desperate. How is that people can close their eyes to the evils of the world like that-- I just don't understand. I mean, sure, you have your own lives and it may not be a top priority because we have things like families, children, or other obligations, but....



</question>



<answer from>



adagio58
Member since: 21 February 2008
Total points: 3777 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yes, you can try to help others in the world, quite commendable conduct, but then you cannot carry the burdens of the world on your shoulders. Do whatever you can and do it for love of mankind and God but let your seeds of goodwill fall where they may, it is not for you to judge the outcome because, who knows!, somewhere down the line your small act of kindness will be remembered and just may turn a life around that needs direction. You don't know what or when, just leave that to God who is working through you!  ;- )



Regarding evil, you cannot see the beauty of a sunset if you're always looking at the ground, true? Nor can you see the Christ if your mind is dwelling on evil, so-called. You need to take time to connect with the higher energies, the Universal Consciousness, so that it can flow through you the individual and create a spiritual awareness in yourself and others.



There's another matter as well, all souls in this physical realm have certain lessons to be learned in one shape or another. Those who have been unjust in one life will likely be reaping the result of their previous actions in this life, that is, of experiencing unjustness this time around. As fellow human beings we can do our part to help humanity but certainly we cannot save the world! And it was not meant for us to do so. Try to find a balance somewhere in all this.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I'm not particularly religious, but I really liked the ideas that you wrote into this-- thank you for your words of wisdom.



</asker's comment>

<answer>



IDEALIST:
An adherent of a philosophical theory of idealism: an artist or author who advocates or practices idealism in art or writing.



IDEALISM:
A theory that ultimate reality lies in a realm transcending phenomena; a theory that the essential nature of reality lies in consciousness or reason; a theory that only the perceptible is real; a theory that only mental states or entities are knowable.



Yes, I feel that the world has a lot of anger in it. You say you are an idealist, but I don't understand why you are telling us in this question, "but am I the only one who's disgusted by what one person can do to others sometimes?? It's atrocious", yet you answer depraved questions in a substandard category? (I saw it in your profile). It doesn't make sense.



If you would like to, I've attached a web page to read that may help you become a genuine idealist. I read this web page. It helped me and changed my life...

<original file>16494.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk106634.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



Sweet Apple of Sin
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 2172 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Is it possible to feel betrayed by someone you don't really love ?



</question>



<answer from>



Hog Wash
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 6068 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I don't like or trust myself some days.  I guess that is a form of betrayal of self, whom I sometimes don't really love.



What I speak of, is when we look inward and don't really like what we see.  Not all the time, but on a given day.  There are times when we let ourselves down by failing to achieve, behave, or deport ourselves as we should.  We don't reach our "ideal" role model we have set for ourselves.



A betrayal of self by self, when you fail to love yourself for whom you really are.



I believe, also, we sometimes assume "possession" of others, in our mind.  A process wherein we find a friend and feel attached, or that we have a special relationship, but find they have other interests, and other friends.  Even though we assume the same privilege for ourselves, we can feel "let down" when we find we are not the center of attention of the other person.  Sometimes that comes as a shock to our ego.



We feel "betrayed", but is it by them, or is it by ourselves?  We love ourselves more than the other person, yet perceive "they" betrayed us!



Have we assumed too much?  Failed to take a realistic look at what is?  Not considered how our ego sometimes replaces common sense?  Lacked understanding of what "love" really is?



Strange, but very human behavior.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank you



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Geri9394...
Member since: 21 September 2007
Total points: 6615 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, that's possible.  When we enter into friendship along with that comes an expectation that we'll get certain emotional needs met.  Sometimes we think the other person feels the same level of commitment to the friendship as we do, when actually they don't.  When something happens to bring that fact to our attention we feel betrayed.  We feel our "friend" has misrepresented him/herself.  We feel betrayed.



Source(s):



Life experience



</answer>



<answer from>



India-Gr...
Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 697 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, I think it is.



It is possible to be betrayed by anything and anyone. Perhaps betrayed isn't the right word, but we don't have a better one at our disposal.



For example: there is a boy I like at school. I by no means love him, but I think he's pretty cool. recently, he told me he likes one of my closest friends. I felt completely and utterly betrayed. And of course, poor guy, it wasn't his fault - life doesn't work like that (one person loves someone, the someone MUST reciprocate genuine love), but it was still an incredibly painful experience anyway.



I think betrayal is something we as individuals, and as communities, have to come to terms with, because, often, it is inevitable. Yet we SHOULD all try our utmost to make sure we can prevent any betrayal that we can. It's all we can really do.



</answer>



<answer from>



Fuzzy
Member since: 18 January 2007
Total points: 11631 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The first person below stated it nicely.  Clearly this is about trust.



Thus a long term business associate with whom you have had dealings with and trusted will if he does something that hurts you by revealing secrets, stealing property, etc betray the other person.



Even a one time business transaction with a reputable firm that betrays your trust and cheats you will make you feel betrayed justifiably.



It has nothing to do with love at all.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 03 November 2007
Total points: 517 (Level 2)

<answer>



good question, after pondering on it I'd like to conclude that our intellect is something that 'nobody' can take from us. the ability to have 'intellect' is something we were born with and interactions with others simply increases your intellect or knowledge. BTW just because 'nobody' can take it away doesn't mean it can't be taken away... there are always freak accidents like falling off a cliff to consider.

I'm a servant to the house, cos I need to maintain it in order to call it home.
I'm a servant to my wife, cos I need to shower her with love or else she probably ran away.
I'm a servant to my job, if not I will lose it.
I'm a servant to money, cos I’m always slaving for it.



When it’s time for me to die,
Everything here, I’ll say good-bye.
I own nothing, whether dead or alive.



Geezs, I just wondering too, who is even bothered to take nothing from a poor guy.

<question from>



Mantra
Member since: 08 July 2006
Total points: 707 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What is the value of introspection? Where is it most effective?



Not a simple question.



</question>



<answer from>



HPvD
Member since: 09 September 2007
Total points: 898 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You could start by having a Free Preview of my brilliant little eBook that you can find via: http://hpshappy.blogspot.com



All  the Best,



To your Happy - Introspective - Inspiration,



HP



</answer>



<answer from>



Fortunata's Wisdom ©™
Member since: 11 December 2007
Total points: 26064 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



A simple question with a simple answer. Introspection is best undertaken when inspired rather than at a time set aside. In love we look deep within for the soul awakened and alive. In anger we reach into our fury to find the root of our rage and extinguish it or cure. In thoughtful moments of truth seeking we are supplicated sufficiently to probe deeply into the recesses of our psyche for ancient truth closeted within a case of our hidden aspirations, invocative thinking and slumbering love.



Introspection yields in measure of the seekers imagination. A multi faceted being will  approach the side of his tempered admission, and find his reflection therein, reason to be happy, causes for doubt, and basis for fear are echoes of man own orchestrated thoughts, lived, lying latent as sleeping unawakened dreams.



</answer>



<answer from>



More Te Vicar?
Member since: 08 November 2007
Total points: 1803 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



the value of introspection cannot be underestimated i find i do not pull the punches when in introspective thought - why lie to yourself?



if used in combination with the honesty of a good friend and an open heart one can hardly go wrong in matching your output in your life to the legend in your own mind that is your inner self.



"temet nosce"



Te



</answer>



<answer from>



Generali...
Member since: 14 July 2007
Total points: 16774 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



G Introspection is most effective in considering the contributions to circumstances made by oneself. After those contributions are considered, correct causes can be made.



</answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



Kormcocz
Member since: 08 February 2007
Total points: 468 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Loyalty is earned. I'll not give my loyalty to someone who doesn't deserve it. Much like friendship, it's also something that once lost, is not easily regained. You have many people who simply don't have the capacity for loyalty to anyone or anything.
I have no trouble being loyal to a person who's earned the honor of receiving my loyalty. It is their job to earn my loyalty, not my job to give loyalty (or honor for that matter) to them.



I am first loyal to my core values. These are nonnegotiable, and are the grounding for my life. If someone can compromise their principals, they're not going to be worthy of much loyalty by others.
In conclusion, "find[ing] it easy to be loyal" isn't the real question here. The question is do you know someone worthy of your loyalty.



Be well all.



</answer>



<answer from>



naughty
Member since: 27 April 2008
Total points: 11385 (Level 6)

<answer from>



l0u1se_8...
Member since: 03 May 2007
Total points: 249 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think the "it" is the idea that we are only given one life to live. The body you were born with, the family and friends, the education opportunities and career choices. You only get one chance. Some people feel the need to question if their life as a whole is all they are going to experience as a person.
That raises questions such as "is there life after death?", "have we been here before?" and "is there life away from Earth?"
I think it is human nature to want more and to experience more, and being told that you're only going to get one go, for an average of 80-odd years, with no ability to start again, rewind or fast forward, is not a satisfying thing to hear.
Hopefully you won't ask yourself this question too often and will learn to appreciate what you have and make the most of it, just in case this isn't a rehearsal :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Kisshoma...
Member since: 23 October 2006
Total points: 17289 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



This one is wondering who "they" actually are!



Do "they" have "it"?



May it be well with you.



</answer>

<question from>



Fallen Angel
Member since: 21 June 2007
Total points: 10700 (Level 6)



</question from>



<question>



Is there an Epidemic? ?



Is there an epidemic of apathy, inertia, ennui, pointlessness and hopelessness? If so; what can be done about it? If you think not, can you shed some light on how you personally keep them at bay?



</question>



<answer from>



Ravencal...
Member since: 31 August 2008
Total points: 7749 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



keep  good company....



especially with  the  angels



</answer>



<answer from>



courtney
Member since: 28 October 2006
Total points: 222 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I believe there is such an epidemic. The only thing that can be done about it is typically when one such apathetic person gets affected personally by something they were once careless about. For example, pain is something a lot of people are uncaring about. When one gets hurt, other say "I'm sorry," or "I understand," when really they aren't that sorry and they don't understand. However, when the apathetic person gets hurt, they expect others to feel sorry for them, and understand them.



</answer>



<answer from>



guru
Member since: 07 April 2007
Total points: 12368 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



What you describe are also symptoms of depression.



People have differing priorities. Because something is important to me, doesn't mean that it is important to you. Labeling it as apathy may just be a difference in priorities. Some might consider me apathetic about the environment. The environement is not a priority for me. Although it is for others. To claim that I am apathetic would be a disservice to what I do feel is important in life.



</answer>

</category>



<question from>



India-Gr...
Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 708 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Heaven/hell/afterlife in general?



Well, I personally am not entirely sure as to whether I believe in the idea of some kind of afterlife, but I thought this could be an interesting topic of debate:



What if THIS life is the afterlife, and we all died in some other life, but just don't remember it? That THIS is it - heaven, hell, whatever you want to call it?



There are probably thousands of holes in this 'theory' (I don't believe myself :P) but it could be true, right? And isn't it ironic that we all spend so much time thinking/worrying about life after death if it turns out this is actually IT? And there is no perfection, or paradise, or garden of Eden anywhere, but that this is as good as it gets?



What do you think?



</question>

<question from>

<question>



No it still does not move?

<question from>



O
Member since: 30 September 2007
Total points: 149 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why does Kant think that “the moral law just is the principle of a free will”?



</question>



<answer from>



Fortunata's Wisdom ©™
Member since: 11 December 2007
Total points: 26064 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Morality in a virtue of a free will, afforded to the morally conscious



The will can only be considered free when the mechanism or trigger inciting need desire or action is located and controlled. Until man hasn’t the ability to understand why he desires, wants, seeks a specific other than ‘because it is his will and impulse to do so’ , until he understand s what occasions the will, incites the impulse, he is controlled by forces unknown to him, with no great purpose of interest to his long term moral welfare of good.



Morality is not adhered to by fear of reprisals, public condemnation, or fall from grace, rather because it is understood matters immoral, promiscuous or illicit are the path and means to an ulterior end, rather than the goal and purpose themselves. If he chooses his path by reason, than impulsive lust and exploited chance he finds not the love and fals into a habitual search for titillation woefully temporal and transient.



This means man seeks peace, respite from stress, exhilaration, bliss, and the euphoric release of endorphins caused by a heightened state of joy or love. Immoral paths or means are questionable, and temporary in the quest for the end. If man seeks to accomplish the end, a perpetual condition of love and pleasure, his means must ne entirely aligned to his cause, and relegated to a path. If man becomes lost in the entrapments towards peace and liberation, he gains not the utopian state of paradise, rather finds momentary happiness from ill considered and designed places and motives and lapses into aggreivment at his inability to secure a path without knowledge of the end.



Source(s):



I have looked at your links and Kant is indeed in agreement ...



</answer>



<answer from>



TK421
Member since: 27 June 2006
Total points: 2396 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The above answer isn't Kantian philosophy.



First please understand Kant re-defined "free" and "will" and choice in his ethical system.  He would have said "NO" to your question, since moral law would be considered absolute and "free will" is derived from the knowledge of a moral law.  In other words Kant was a MORAL ABSOLUTIST.  The famous argument being, it is ALWAYS WRONG TO LIE, even if you are lying to a murderer about the location of his next victim.  In a sense such as the above, can you get the concept of a "free will"?  No, certainly though you can see choice as it relates to the moral law.



The point is Murder from your perspective could be considered a GOOD THING, supposing for an instant that the murderer was constraining your life in some way.  That is one of the problem with ethical systems (namely utilitarian).  Hence Kant's creation or re-creation (I should say) of an absolutist ethical system.



Look up the Categorical Imperative and Deontology



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Categorical...
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kantianism



Just for the hell of it, there was a Professor at University of Nebraska, he taught Kantian Philosophy and ethics for 20 years and didn't understand everything he taught until he read Will Durant's Story of Philosophy.  Kant is the most challenging of all philosophers in many ways.



</answer>

<question from>



Aphian
Member since: 04 March 2006

</question from>



<question>



How is cyclical time explained apposed to linear time?



</question>



<answer from>



Tahuti
Member since: 12 April 2007
Total points: 16729 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't believe in cyclical nor linear time. But, the "Wheel of Time" concept has been around since the Middle Ages, and likely in pre-Christian pagan cultures. (It seems classical to me) The idea that political, social, philisophical and other movements return is how I view cyclical time. Look at the classical art of the American revolution. But, I don't believe this means that one day again there will be an Atlantis, and a disaster, and eventually a return to barbaric, non-scientific cultures, then a return of Egypt, and Greece and Rome, and a fall, and then a new Enlightenment, etc. I don't believe in a direct wheel.



</answer>



<answer from>



Super Ruper
Member since: 21 November 2006
Total points: 20195 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Small amounts of time are measured - in our modern times - in a cyclical fashion.  Twenty four hour clock, 7 day week, 12 month year - all repeating itself.  Long term, however, is measured in a linear fashion - with time literally marching on - adding year after year.



I look at it as very cyclical, in my life - it seems that times repeat themselves frequently for me, and it is more comforting to think of it in those terms....



</answer>



<answer from>



Hari
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 2348 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Day & night change is cyclic time like birth & death also cyclic



</answer>

thomas_t...

<answer>



Here are what some noteworthy people have said of Jesus Christ:



*** gt The Greatest Man Who Ever Lived ***



The historian H. G. Wells said that a man’s greatness can be measured by ‘what he leaves to grow, and whether he started others to think along fresh lines with a vigor that persisted after him.’ Wells, although not claiming to be a Christian, acknowledged: “By this test Jesus stands first."
--Napoleon is reported to have said: “Jesus Christ has influenced and commanded His subjects without His visible bodily presence.”
--Will Durant argued: “That a few simple men should in one generation have invented so powerful and appealing a personality, so lofty an ethic and so inspiring a vision of human brotherhood, would be a miracle far more incredible than any recorded in the Gospels.”
--As one writer aptly expressed it: “All the armies that ever marched, and all the navies that ever were built, and all the parliaments that ever sat, all the kings that ever reigned, put together have not affected the life of man upon this earth as powerfully.”
--Yes, think about it. Even calendars today are based on the year that Jesus was thought to have been born. “Dates before that year are listed as B.C., or before Christ,” explains The World Book Encyclopedia. “Dates after that year are listed as A.D., or anno Domini (in the year of our Lord).”
--Even a Hindu, Mohandas Gandhi, was moved to say: ‘I love Christ, but I despise Christians because they do not live as Christ lived.’



</answer>

<question>



Why should mankind involve in activities that result in sufferings, terror, hatred, fighting, killings etc?



Suppose the average human life in today's world is not more than 60 years. If you analyse the break-up of activities associated with these 60 years of your life, you can see that it more or less matches with the following:



* 12 Years in Working



* 22 Years in Sleeping



* 04 Years in Routine Travelling



* 05 Years in Eating



* 03 Years in Bathing, Dressing etc...



* 06 Years in Useless Chatting, Gossip



* 04 Years in Sickness & Illness



* Balance ? Only 4 Years



Our only question to one and all is, why should mankind think, involve in activities that result in sufferings, terror, hatred, fighting, killings etc... in the short span of 4 years left to them. It needs to be utilized in a better way by doing all good things, helping others and thanking God for the opportunity given to us in being a human being... Live and Let Live.

<answer>



Love, schmove - civically speaking, marriage is an economic arrangement where 2 people share a household. Marriage benefits are society's way of encouraging that arrangement. That's all the gov't should be concerned with, right? Not their sex life, or their gender. If society is worried about the sex of the 2 people, then it must be interested in encouraging the reproductive success of people in certain economic arrangements. That's not all that unreasonable, actually. I think that's what the anti-gay-marriage position comes down to, for those people who aren't just homophobic. Well, okay, so most anti-GM folks are homophobic and those that aren't, explain their POV as if they were either homophobic, or confused about the roles of religion and state. But I think this is the "real" reason why people resist the idea of state-administered gay marriage.



Personally, I think it comes down to pure sex discrimination. I agree with you; think a person's right to be recognized as a family member of someone they share a household with, shouldn't depend on sex. As long as society approves of 2-adult households and encourages them economically in law, then it should approve them the same regardless of who the adults are. As a society striving to be egalitarian, we have a standard of fairness to uphold. Besides, there is no reason whatsoever to believe that gay people who adopt and raise kids, are somehow a bad influence on society.



</answer>

<answer from>



Argentino Errante II No racismo
Member since: 06 March 2008
Total points: 4507 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



he attitude towards homosexuality has varied throughout the different times and between the diverse groups and cultural sub-groups, oscillating between the acceptance (in old Greece), the tolerance (in the Roman Empire) and the absolute sentence (in many western and Eastern societies). Nevertheless, great part of the lack of understanding and the existing prejudices against homosexuality comes from their classification like disease in century XIX. The German neuropsicólogo Richard von Krafft-Ebing considered one " neuropática degeneration hereditaria" that supposedly one worsened by an excessive masturbation. Austrian psychiatrist Sigmund Freud postulated the existence of a constituent predisposition, although also she emphasized the determining effect of experiences during the childhood (like, for example, the lack of an ancestor of the same sex with which to be able to identify itself) and the frequency of masculine homosexual experiences during the adolescence, that considered like sexual deviation. The publication of two studies on the sexual behavior in men and women, that carried out the American biologist Alfred Charles Kinsey, refuted the hypothesis of the disease. Psychological tests realised to homosexuals and heterosexuals showed that it among them were no pathological aspects differentiators. Although some evidences exist - in studies of twin binoculars and that suggest them genes can be a factor in the sexual direction, other theories affirm that it is more probable that the determining factors are the experiences lived during the childhood. In 1973, the Psychiatric Association of the United States eliminated the homosexuality of its list of mental diseases and, in 1980, of the DSM, Manual of Classification of the Mental Diseases of the WHO.



Greetings from Argentina



</answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



123456
Member since: 04 July 2006
Total points: 3007 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Three types of tears are generated by the human eye. Basal tears protect the eye and keep it moist. Reflex tears flush out the eye when it becomes irritated. And emotional tears flow in response to sadness, distress, or physical pain.



Studies have shown that emotional tears contain more manganese, an element that affects temperament, and more prolactin, a hormone that regulates milk production. Sobbing out manganese and prolactin is thought to relieve tension by balancing the body’s stress levels and eliminating build ups of the chemicals, making the crier feel better.



But this minor physiological benefit aside, the most likely reason we produce emotional tears is because it’s a means of communication. Before babies can speak, they can cry. The only way for infants to express frustration, pain, fear, or need is to cry. Adults may use crying to bond with other humans. Expressing sadness can prompt comfort and support from peers. Different languages can provide barriers to spoken communication, but emotions are universal. There are also culturally acceptable reasons for crying that bring people together, such as at funerals or weddings.



Source(s):



http://scienceline.org/2006/10/23/ask-dr...



</answer>



<answer from>



Ethan Isaac
Member since: 28 April 2008
Total points: 818 (Level 2)

heather

<answer>



Crying is a way for your body to release emotion. If you think about it, you cry when your sad, happy, suprised, nervouse etc. It's a reaction your body has to all the hormones from emotion it's receiving.



ON a more scientific note, tears are used by your body to push unwanted substance out of your body. For example, if you get something in your eye, your eyes begin to tear, releasing whatever it was that got stuck !



I dont think there have been any life studies but that would be an interesting experiment to conduct. You should try it !



</answer>

grayure

</answer from>



<answer>



It's an emotional signal to others and it involves the excretion of manganese.  Emotional tears contain manganese but tears caused by, say, onions, don't.  I don't know why.  Contact lenses can become stained pink by manganese if the person wearing them cries a lot for emotional reasons.



Some people, me included, believe that humans went through an amphibious phase in their evolution quite recently.  The only other mammals to cry emotional tears are seals, and whales constantly secrete tears to protect their eyes.  It may therefore be a form of excess salt excretion, though why sweat glands and kidneys aren't enough i don't know.  However, this makes sense to me phenomenologically, as to me, emotional crying feels like excreting sadness and a release, rather like taking a dump to be frank.



</answer>

<answer from>



TK421
Member since: 27 June 2006
Total points: 2400 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



If this is the Afterlife, thank God I die...



Immanual Kant said (not exactly but something to this effect).  In order for their to be anything, there has to be JUSTICE somewhere.  We know that there is NO justice here, so it must be in the afterlife.



The problem with "the world" today is that we have lost our absolutes.  There is a MORAL ABSOLUTE.  TRUTH DOES EXIST.  TRUTH IS UNCHANGING.  JUSTICE DOES EXIST.



Because the above is true, even more so if it is untrue here, then we get back to the point of God and First Cause arguments.



Because the above is true, even more so if it is untrue here - I wanted to define this point, because I can't take it for granted that every1 will understand the point:



Mathmatics is a form of truth.  2+2 = 4.  So, we know there is such a thing and have seen such a thing as TRUTH, but it isn't everywhere, but it IS A GOVERNING PRINCIPLE in the universe.  So, if 2+2 = 4, why the hell can't people behave?  That is the point, eventually you get back to God and First Cause arguments.



</answer>

<answer from>



Squipy
Member since: 07 September 2008
Total points: 245 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



"What if I said no to the selfish and materialistic mind set of today.?



Wouldn't I be the only one? Wouldn't I be the animal? If the majority of the human race thinks opposite to the way I do, doesn't that make me mad? Doesn't that make me inhuman?"



No. Of course not. But suggesting that you're the 'only one' who thinks that way makes you sound a little contradicting to the selfish mindset of society. I don't completely understand why you perceive the world as such a horrible place. Yes, we're corrupted, self-absorbed, judgmental, we make mistakes constantly, we're too easily influenced and all of the above. But if we weren't all that would we be considered human at all? Being human doesn't necessarily mean that we should all strive to be perfect, after all, everybody has different views on what it means to be a human being. I agree that it's absolutely disgusting to see the extent of the damage that we're capable of, but the fact is -- it's inevitable, when you consider the diversity of society.



You can't insist on being the victim here. What I'm trying to say is that we can't help the corruption any more than you can. But although we can't reverse it, we can try to work from it. Don't be so ignorant for a sec. Look around, we ARE helping. We ARE making an effort, and that's what's important right now. Less focus on the damage, more focus on the future.



So, no. Wanting to help doesn't make you any less human or make you an 'animal.' Just remember to also accept that society is what it is, flaws and all.



</answer>

Turning the page will mean facing the future or even the unknown in life.



Yes, at times it would be so much simpler not to do it, just chuck everything out the window and have done with life's demands! But that's the easy way. Indirectly it also means you prefer to accept failure or defeat instead of meeting the challenge whatever it may be.



There's a saying, "You only fail when you stop trying." Personally, I don't intend to fail, not yet, not while I can stand up and be a living, breathing person! Maybe I'm stubborn but taking on the rough road makes one appreciate the smooth ride afterwards. We'll know the difference once we've navigated through the bumps in the road, true?

"There are no problems, only projects!

<answer from>



hopeless romantic
Member since: 09 October 2008
Total points: 419 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I believe that everyone, in at least one point in our lives, go through this phase.  Life is hard and problems will always be present.  It's just a matter of how we would deal with the problems we face.



Sometimes, we're still reluctant to turn the page because we're obviously still not ready to see what's on the next page of our book.  We're still trapped with the present situation and are still finding a way of how to understand the things that are happening in this current page.  But there are times when I feel that this will do us some good.  Because the more we stay in one page, the more we learn and understand about the difficulties in life.  So the next time we encounter them in the succeeding pages, we'll know how to deal with them.



Just continue on your book.  Don't do stupid things and don't waste your life.  Don't be too eager to face death.  We're all headed there anyways.



</answer>

He didn't understand it. Got it all wrong. Pliny was another twat.

<question from>



fireseek...
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 1031 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



What is Aristotle's view of happiness?



What would Aristotle say one would have to do to be happy?



</question>



<answer from>



Goxyღ
Member since: 14 April 2007
Total points: 25096 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Languages



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Aristotle believed virtues led to happiness. And virtues meant the act of achieving balance and moderation.
He spoke about achieving happiness which is not an emotional state; it is more about being all that you can, fulfilling your potential. The idea is that by living in a way that reaches your full potential you bloom or flourish and so display the best version of you that you can be.



So for him it was the act of living in balance and moderation that brought the highest pleasure. Not in the action itself, but in the way of life. It is this way of life that would lead to the greatest long-term value rather than just a passing amusement.



For him contemplation was the highest activity humans could do. Contemplation is the activity that refines and discovers virtues. Carried out continuously it allows you to reach your potential.



Source(s):



Read more about it:
http://www.radicalacademy.com/adlerarist...



</answer>

Anyone have there own philosphy about how we came into existence? ?

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I have several ideas/theories. I feel we were made by many Gods and Goddesses, not just one god like the Christan's and Catholics believe though. And they made the universe and all the planets and brought life onto one or two of the planets but the other planet(s) that had life on them didn't fare to well. So the Gods and Goddesses put their heads together sorta-speak, and made Earth and created all sorts of lives here. Over a long period of time, like an artist constantly going over his or her work. When they felt pleased with what they had done they left elsewhere possibly to continue it or to watch us as we are now.



Another one is that other forces, scientific ones or not, kind of like...accidentally created all sorts of life on the planet. This planet alone. And so that's how we got the various plants, bugs, animals, and so on. Any number of things could have happened to make us humans so different than all the other animals of forms of life. One could be that we simply adapted/adjusted better and quicker than other animals did. This could be because of the forces that made us.



Another is simply Mother Nature creating life. She's a mother, she wanted something(s) to take care of just like any other mother would. And so she created us humans and the other animals. She could have created us humans to do a job in caring for the other animals that she could not. But then she realized she needed something, some way, to balance it all out and so that's how we got two genders.



But this is all just my thinking and thoughts. Much luck.



</answer>

<original file>23261.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk114154.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



tera
Member since: 13 October 2008
Total points: 97 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the difference between a philosophy and the philosophy?



</question>



<answer from>



taikutsu
Member since: 06 November 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



think about the definitions of "a" and "the" and i think it'll become perfectly clear, dude.



</answer>



<answer from>



hairhorn
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 1700 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



for example:



"the philosophy of math" is a field of study



"a philosophy of math" would be one particular viewpoint.



.... although in practice professional philosophers don't really call their points of view "a philosophy"



</answer>



<answer from>



mindidio...
Member since: 23 August 2006
Total points: 540 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



A philosophy is a particular way of thinking about the world (or universe) around you. For example: Nihilism (is A philosophy)



PHILOSOPHY is the broad subject of study. For example: I would study (a philosophy) Nihilism in philosophy class (class touching on several different philosophies)



THE philosophy, could refer to many things. It could be the subject of a sentence (in this case a specific study). For example: "Let us go study THE philosophy of ethics."
Or THE philosophy could be referring to the ultimate philosophy. For example: THE tree (supreme, ruling, special) verses A tree (minor, mediocre) - THE philosophy (supreme, ruling, special), verses A philosophy (minor, mediocre)



</answer>



<answer from>



CogitoEr...
Member since: 11 July 2007
Total points: 8949 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Mathematics



</answer from>



<answer>



"a" philosophy is like Rene Descartes philosophy, or Platos philosophy... or even your philosophy.



"the" philosophy, on the other hand, is more like my philosophy - Objectively true and correct.



</answer>



<answer from>



WES
Member since: 20 January 2008
Total points: 49819 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



...the meaning...



</answer>




<original file>23262.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk114155.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



pumuckl_...
Member since: 27 February 2008
Total points: 911 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Truth trees / indirect truth tables ?



may I ask someone to explain very simply, the methodology behind constructing truth trees?



I get the indirect truth tables so I thought that truth trees were the same, but I'm not getting how I break down premises based on the truth tree rules I have in front of me?  Just not making sense, I need guidelines / explanation.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



All it is is a truth by contradiction proof... except that you take every avenue of possibility at the same time.  You are accounting for the truth value of every uncertainty that exists.  Only in contradiction does a "branch" fail.



This is used to prove the invalidity of an argument.



If you assume the falsity of the intended conclusion and add that to your premises, then you are proving or disproving the validity of the counter argument.  If the counter argument is proven invalid through contradiction in every branch, then you prove the original argument valid.



</answer>

<question from>



Mike
Member since: 04 May 2007
Total points: 144 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Summarize Thomas Nagel's "What is it like to be a bat?" ?



specifically, i need help on this part of essay.



Q: Why does the subjective character of experience defy the reductionist accounts of consciousness of the materialists?



any help is appreciated.



</question>



<answer from>



Doctor Why
Member since: 25 July 2006
Total points: 40519 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Heh.  The answer to that question is pretty much the entire essay.  But we can probably summarize a bit more briefly.



Probably the place where he makes the distinction best is where he talks about trying to imagine what it would be like to be a bat.  You can imagine that your arms are wings, that you have webbing between your fingers, or that you can tell where things are by listening to echoes.  But even if you imagine all these things perfectly, you still don't know what it's like to BE a bat... just what it's like to be a human IMAGINING he's a bat.



This difference is what he suggests defies reductionist accounts.  It doesn't matter how much you know about wings, because you can't know what it's like to really have them as part of you like a bat does.



Source(s):



http://home.myuw.net/himma/phil463/nagel...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks a lot, that actually really cleared a bunch of stuff up.



</asker's comment>

<question from>



Peace I

</question from>



<question>



What according to you the TRUTH is? Is it individual or unique & universal?



This is my effort to get thinking ability of different people.this is only for US byUS.



</question>



<answer from>



gonk123@...
Member since: 10 October 2008
Total points: 782 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Truth is what appears most similar to the most people.



</answer>



<answer from>



L B
Member since: 06 November 2008
Total points: 111 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



In Plato's "Meno," the fact we have opinions, some better than another, points at the truth. It is hardly contentious that a mechanic knows how to fix cars better than most people, or that a physicist understands celestial phenomena better.



Where the real argument lies is whether or not right and wrong, beautiful and ugly, honorable and dishonorable can be fixed in such a way. Again, the Platonic teaching does not allow relativism, even as it prepares the ground for debate - all societies aim at what is just, and despite their disagreements, some societies turn out to be more unjust than others simply. Nazi Germany was evil - period, end of conversation. People who look up to it usually want to cause harm.



The thing about the opinion/truth relation is that "truth" in moral matters is almost useless because the nature of politics requires expedience. So "opinion" 9 out of 10 times is good enough for us - we put you before the jury, they figured out you were guilty, let's get the sentence carried out.



"Opinion" is usually private, and "truth" is of necessity universal. But there are already complications with this scheme: there is "public opinion," after all. And if someone were a philosopher, their private world would encompass the universe.



That's my two cents. I think truth finally ends up being unique and universal. There's a discussion about how we access the "truth" through our education which might be of use...



Source(s):



http://www.ashokkarra.com/2008/05/a-spee...



</answer>



<answer from>



George Bush In Iraq-Barack Obama
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 4264 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



1.  Truth is that which happens yesterday, today, and tomorrow.  Example, the sun will rise today as it has risen yesterday and will do so tomorrow.



2.  Truth can be verfied again and again.  Example, put a glass of water in the freezer and it turn into ice.



3.  Truth never changes.



4.  Truth is seen under the microscope.



5.  Truth is repeatable in experiments.



6.  Truth is verifiabale by scientific analysis and scientific form of reasoning.



</answer>

<answer from>



guru
Member since: 07 April 2007
Total points: 12427 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Intersubjectivity.



Ironically, people can be "right" and still be wrong. There was a time when everyone agreed that the world was flat. It didn't affect our ability to sail around the planet, grow crops, irrigate the land, survive, and many other human activities. They were all collectively wrong, but under the belief that they were collectively right.



Intersubjectivity can be more easily detected with the ability of hindsight. It is very difficult to question one's own beliefs as they are likely to be a source of anxiety when challenged.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tiatia5
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 209 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<question from>

<question>



Don't you wish you knew what you were doing?

<answer>



I used to want control but then I realised I would never get it because there is just far too much chaos to even contemplate having control.



I used to want to know everything but then I realised that everytime I thought I knew something, something would come along to prove otherwise.



Now I just embrace the mystery and the uncertainty and I have to say, I fall in love with each day that I live because it's like seeing a beautiful girl smile at me each day. Some days I don't want to go to bed because I know I'll never see that smile again but then I think, I wonder what will happen tomorrow and I get exited again.



I'm glad I don't know anything. It makes my heart pump faster and that makes me almost certain that I'm alive.



But that's just me. I realise some people need to feel safe by having what they believe to be knowledge or control and if that helps them sleep at night, then fair enough. Being able to sleep is important. It helps us live longer. Not sure I'd want to live that long if I was doing the same stuff everyday but they must enjoy it, otherwise they wouldn't do it, would they?



</answer>

The universe is full of exceptions, and it's very hard to find anything that's average. For example, if we have a bucket of pebbles that "on average" weighs 145grams. What are the chances that any of those pebbles weigh exactly 145.00 grams? See where I'm going with this yet?

<answer>



Of course, unless I misunderstood what I read, this is only relative to objective, aposteriori knowledge. We cannot forget those things that we learn through apriori methods.



For example, you don't have to know what a variable is in an algebraic equation to manipulate the equation... even solve it.



There comes a point when, as interesting as these concepts are, reason and intuition should take front-seat. Just because I am not aware of every atom's interaction with every other atom doesn't mean I am incapable of buttoning my shirt in the morning...



</answer>

radicsho...
Member since: 27 June 2007

<answer>



Uhhh... December 31st, 1999 was the fear of technology failing, not the end of the world.



December 21st, 2012 is the day the Mayan calender ends. Now, there's no evidence at all that this might be true, but they say that disasters are going to occur.



One disaster many have their eyes set on is a Supervolcanic eruption actually. According to scientific data, in 2012, Yellowstone caldera's new "vent" if you will that is slowly breaking free from the magma chamber underneath will hit the surface and break through. Now at first, this was said to be a new hydrothermal vent which they were going to add as another attraction to the park, but later evidence showed that it was a magma volcanic vent which brought concerns that it might be the next vent to trigger a supervolcanic eruption.



Upon further calculation of such matters, they concluded that IF the current vent continues to expand at the rate it is, it will break land by 2012 and that has sparked concern of a violent volcanic eruption in that year. However, these are very rough estimates from USGS and are by no means actual proof that Yellowstone will be awakened by 2012 to cause havok on the world.



Another Supervolcano is Lake Toba which erupted 75,000 years ago and almost brought the human species to extinction. The volcano sent the world into a 10 year darkness according to ash fall data recovered from the bottom of the seat and land deposits.



The 2004, 2005 and twice 2007 Earthquakes of Sumatra were in real close proximity to the ancient Lake Toba vent and evidence has shown that those earthquakes, namely the giant 9.3 2004 earthquake has once again reactivated Toba and the Volcano could be more destructive that it was 75,000.



These are scientists predictions for 2012 that a massive volcanic eruption will occur, but until then, we can only predict and just have to wait and see.



</answer>

<answer>



Maybe, maybe not. But the Mayan calendar is a cycle, not a line with an end. The date in 2012 is just the turning of the longest cycle. It's no more an "end" than Dec. 31 1999 is on the Julian calendar.

Personally, since I have no reason to believe 2012 is any more special than 1999 other than superstitious excitement, I'm planning on living.

downwind...

<answer>
