<answer from>



j153e
Member since: 09 July 2006
Total points: 29366 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dream Interpretation



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



KM was not big on philosophy nor logical thinking.



He regarded philosophy as a kind of irrelevant exercise.



He illogically claimed to have proved a universal negative ("God is not"), which is a logical impossibility.



He ignored philosophy and logic in order to promote the goals of the "League of the Just," an Illuminist-oriented group which hired him to footnote its communist program.



When drinking, he ridiculed Communists.  He stated, toward the very close of his life, that he was "not a Marxist."



Since Marx, the philosophy attempting to develop Marxism into dogmatic doctrine has been extensive.



Given some assumptions (God is not, Matter drives evolution, Matter is eternal, etc.), Marxist "philosophers" have developed an elaborate and often-mutated system.



The writings of Lenin and Stalin were treated as scientific revelation, immutable law, during their time.



Adaptations of certain German idealist philosophers provide the most direct antecedents to Marx.  As Engels wrote:  "We German socialists are proud of the fact that we are derived, not only from St. Simon, Fourier and Owen, but also from Kant, Fichte and Hegel."  Feuerbach could be added to the latter three.



Would note that Hegel's method of reasoning, namely, an underlying telic which in-forms prior means (in his case, so-called Spirit of Truth infusing and completing human history), is used by Marx and Engels in the materialist perspective of Feuerbach--the so-called dialectic or dialectical materialism.  In other words, the perfectibility of man is promoted by Matter (Spirit is not perceived).



So, in a sense, Marxism is classical 19th century German Romanticism, i.e., holistic system-building, combined with a kind of Enlightenment (St. Simon, Fourier, and Owen) group progress of man.



</answer>

<question from>



Trinley
Member since: 04 May 2007
Total points: 393 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How does Bentham make moral decisions?  How does Kant make moral decisions?  ?



What information would they both want or require? [philosophy]



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



well Bentham is a Utilitarianist so he would need to know the outcome of the moral decision in order to make one. because that's all that matters in a consequentialist value theory like Utilitarianism, is the results of the action.



Kant would use his Categorical Imperatives to see if anything led to a contradiction in either the will or conception. of course this is super super summarized. but basically it boils down to this. the outcomes of moral decisions to Kant are not the sole deicding factor in whether something is morally correct or not, unlike Bentham. Kant has, pretty much, a deontological moral theory



Source(s):



phil major



</answer>

<question>



How is marxian theory relevant to today's world?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Marx believed in the redistribution of wealth among other things.  He identified socialism as the transitional phase between capitalism and communism.



Considering America will now have its first academic socialist president, I'd say Marxian philosophies are relevant.



</answer>

<question from>



norsechi...
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 115 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Is everything we do based on selfish motivation?



How often do you do things knowing that you are going to get nothing out of it? When I mean nothing, I also mean that you don't think that God is going to reward you for a good deed or something like that?



Think about this one more carefully. The answer is not as obvious as it may seem.



</question>



<answer from>



Peter G
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 1967 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Many many things that i do are based on selfish motivation. That includes friendships that i maintain and many other things but occasionally i do something totally altruistic like donating blood or paying for the toll for the car behind me simply 'cause it makes me feel good.
Hmmmm Is that a selfish motivation too? I'm not sure.



</answer>



<answer from>



Alexandr...
Member since: 06 April 2007
Total points: 303 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have had this discussion with several people, interesting isn't it? Every action we commit has it's reward, there is nothing so completely selfless that it doesn't have a benefit for us in some way.



What I have concluded is that the term "selfish" implies 'no thought of consequences to others'. Therefore, doing something 'good' for another isn't really selfish. We were created to feel good, doing good.



What we reap from what we do may be self serving, but it isn't selfish if what we do adds to the goodness in life.



</answer>



<answer from>



wiseman/...
Member since: 22 May 2008
Total points: 7200 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Everything that nearly everybody does is for selfish reasons.  Your three F's, fight, flight and f.... procreation, are the basis of human existence.  There are 9 levels of human beings and in human beings. Firstly my safety, than the safety of my family, with or without me.  There after the safety of the clan, country (those that speak the same language) and then the race. (white, black, brown, indigo.)  The thought of getting something in return for my selfishness does nor enter the equation.  It is immediate satisfaction of an immediate action.
Thus, payment is in the selfish action already, and anything else is a bonus, from whom ever, God the church or the neighbors.
Peace.



</answer>

<answer from>



Squipy
Member since: 07 September 2008
Total points: 219 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Our hearts don't have a 'mind' of their own... They generally react to desire, to the things we want. Therefore, if we only listened to our hearts and disregarded our consciences, we'd probably all be greedy, selfish people.



But since this is a Love quote, then yes, our hearts often tell us more than our consciences. But only in regards to love.



The heart is connected to the mind. Sometimes what we want, is not always right. It's the mind which gives the heart boundaries. And if we didn't follow our consciences, then what are we but lustful beings who are only interested in ourselves?



Some people suggest that the mind and the heart are one and the same. This is only true for those who believe that they are, without a doubt, doing no wrong whatsoever when they follow their hearts.



If we can't distinguish between right and wrong by our own estimations, then we lack self-guidance. It doesn't matter if the next person has different views on what's right. The beauty of having a conscience is that it's yours. No one can take away what you believe is right/wrong. If we don't follow our consciences, we lose sight of being human altogether. It's true, the mind can make mistakes, but only if you let it.



</answer>

<question from>



♪beatles...
Member since: 10 August 2008
Total points: 2688 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Why do people ask for your opinion, and then give you a TD? ?



I don't get it, why give someone a TD when they are just giving the asker their opinion on something? I know that everybody is entitled to their own opinion, but why give someone a TD just because they disagree with your answer??



</question>



<answer from>



The V formerly known as T.S.R.
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 10514 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



Other - Music



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I don't give anyone TD's unless they're rude.  Or chain-mailing.  Or unless I really, -really- hate their answer.  But it takes a LOT to make me really, really hate an answer.



I can't stand it when someone gets a TD on a question I ask--what makes anyone's opinion (as long as they're civil and reasonable) more or less valuable than anyone else's?



Sometimes I'll call someone out on a comment that I disagree with when I'm answering a question.  Most of these comments are directed toward ignorance, but sometimes I'm actually curious why they think that way.  If it's the latter case, then I won't give them a TD--it's their opinion.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I totally agree with you thanks:)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



peace☮ me
Member since: 20 August 2008
Total points: 1168 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think "Kisshoma" is right...you don't know if the asker is giving you "the finger" or some respondent that doesn't agree w/ you.  If it's a responder than it's ok, 'cause like "Alea" said, they're just showing they're on the other side of the fence.  If it's the Asker, then they're probably one of those people who feel, "If I want your opinion, I'll give it to you!" and are asking the question more for validation of their opinion then for getting yours.



</answer>

Jada Emerald

<answer>



The pressure cooker, our true test of faith.



Have you ever seen what happens when you put a lid on a pot full of something and turn up the heat? Eventually the pressure builds up so much that the contents in side spew out because it can no longer stay within its confined space. At this point you see the true nature of what was in the container. “6 For God, who said, “Let light shine out of darkness,” made his light shine in our hearts to give us the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Christ. 7 But we have this treasure in jars of clay to show that this all-surpassing power is from God and not from us. 8 We are hard pressed on every side, but not crushed; perplexed, but not in despair; 9 persecuted, but not abandoned; struck down, but not destroyed. 10 We always carry around in our body the death of Jesus, so that the life of Jesus may also be revealed in our body. 11 For we who are alive are always being given over to death for Jesus’ sake, so that his life may be revealed in our mortal body. 12 So then, death is at work in us, but life is at work in you.” 2 Corinthians 4:6-12 (NIV) [2]  For this reason we must not give up even though our little clay pots are boiling over. What spills out is the testimony of our true faith and character. Its easy to play church and say bless God or what ever is your favorite “Christian phrase” when things are going good but how do you respond when things are going bad? Is Jesus’ light shining out of the darkness?



</answer>



<answer from>



small
Member since: 21 September 2006
Total points: 35346 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Philosophy

<answer>

<answer from>



dmaud56
Member since: 22 October 2006
Total points: 5993 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It should improve you as a human being, and it should not be an exclusive country club requiring either blood ties, or pre-requisites.  In many ways, Judaism, Christianity and Islam are all country clubs when you think about it, with Judaism being the worst of them unless you think of Judaism as a religious faith intended to preserve the purity of the Jewish people so that the Messiah, the man identical in appearance, character, intelligence and strength to Adam, the first man, may be born, the purpose of Judaism being, so that said man could then rule the world with the preserved wisdom.



Judaism does not seek converts because to do so would be to change the bloodline of the first man.  The whole entire justification of Judaism, is rooted in the book of Genesis.  It is true that Adam had several children, and that he is the father of the whole human race, however also true, only one son per generation within that bloodline, is most like him.  First it was Abel, but he was killed and then it was Seth, down the line all the way to Enoch, from Enoch to Noah, from Noah to Shem from Shem to Abraham and from Abraham to Solomon, and from Solomon to Daniel, the next man in that bloodline, assuming they even exist, is unknown.



The appearance of that man though, according to Judaism, will usher in the end of days.  The word began with Adam, and it will end with the Messiah; that is the fundamental core of Judaism.  Well, the world as we know it anyway.  What makes the particular males in the bloodlines mentioned so special, is because all of them, supposedly, each and every one, is identical to the one that came before.  From Adam, to Daniel, according to the bible, they all looked the same.  It even said in Genesis, Seth was identical to his father.



See though, beautiful as the whole notion of a "true redeemer" as it sounds in the end it does not stop being a country club.  Moreover, the Messiah is supposed to be a male descendant, and God promised that "the bloodline of David would not pass from this earth."  Either God never said such a thing, or the ashkenazim are a bunch of liars, are recently they have been saying that there were never any Hebrews, some even say Abraham wasn't even real.  That is how thin their blood runs.



The Iraqi Jewish people, are the descendants of the Jewish community of Babylon; taking into consideration the breeding racism of various semitic groups throughout antiquity, as well as the later Islamicized Ishmaelite invaders, Iraqi Jews are possibly, after the Hebrew descended Muslims of Medina, the purest Hebrew people on this planet.  See though only Iraqi Jews can reliably claim descent from Daniel, because the prophet Daniel, lived in Babylon until he died.  In Judaism, in its most ancient form, you do not reach full manhood unless you marry, and successfully raise functional children to adulthood, only then are you considered a man.  If you do not posses enough skill in your craft to provide for your family, nor enough wisdom to do that, the ancient Hebrew people, did not consider you a man.



So what then, is a true faith, given all this?  Clearly, it is not a country club; wisdom should be shared with everyone.  What little good it did when Europeans got a hold of it though.



To me, a true faith is something that leaves you emotionally balanced, and resilient, it leaves you "buff" and physically fit, laser focused, and hopefully slightly smarter.  In other words, what makes a faith a faith, is the quality of its adherents; if they are all in shape, and well balanced emotionally then, we have a winner.  However if they are the opposite of that, you can not say it is a true faith.  Look at Orthodox Jews and the sheer number of dysfunctional people they crank out.  Look at hardline Irish catholics and all the alchoholics they produce, although, alchoholism among the Irish, personally, I think was due to the fact that in the "old days" "good Irish girls didn't...."  And because Irishmen weren't getting any, they turned to liquor and hookers.



Ultimately  though I think Yeshua (Jesus) said it best when he said;



"by their fruits, ye shall know them."



</answer>

<answer from>



Simply United
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 12025 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



Whatever could be a ‘true faith’, i.e. to qualify the possibility of a ‘false faith’? A fact is a fact, and faith is faith, even if it is in the being of a little ant, or a person a friend. Why not ask: ‘what is the true test of faith’ instead – ‘true’ meaning here the ultimate as any ‘false test’ would not do. So, if the question is as I understand it to be then, I can say the ultimate of test of faith is life, nothing more and nothing less, a life lived in complete devotion, acceptance, effort and gratitude, in observance of a faith, a journey of hope and noble enterprise.



But the question still seems ineffectual, still waxing the mind, as if asking is the true test of a true faith is an entire life of devotion, sacrifice, and love, and nothing less than that? But if not life, as that might be too general an answer, then what else in life: love, marriage, prayers, goodness of deeds and intentions, elevated thoughts, graceful mind, cleanliness, efforts for a livelihood, or dignity and righteousness of a conduct, or may be some quality like, gratitude, kindness, care, perseverance in the face of adversity, patience, hope, exactly what, may be everything? The true test of faith it seems is nothing less life itself, a life lived peacefully, kindly, happily and hopefully.



However, if the question is exactly the way stand, as it is posted here, then the test of for ‘true faith’ is in all the thing I mentioned above, and more, and also in it is ability to withstand oppositions and critical views of a comparison until it is able to remain a true in the middle of half truths, half lies, r even complete falsehood, until it can survive in the arena of the world by the reason of its truth.



</answer>



<answer from>



Graham P
Member since: 13 May 2007
Total points: 3738 (Level 4)

<question>



Does quality tend to disappear from computer projects ?



1/change a field from signed to unsigned, to save a small amount of memory.



2/allow the program tape to be recorded onto, supposedly onto blank trailing tape. (curiously the intended code to do the recording is mysteriously replaced by other code that overwrites the program)



A/(by daxbert):
&lt;&lt;Is this a question?



Changing a field from signed to unsigned results in no memory savings unless you actually need positive integers above the MAX value for the signed integer.



The second paragraph makes no sense.&gt;&gt;



To daxbert:



I. Person in question made a special appointment with the document custodian for the project. (Someone had had the foresight to ensure there was a secure copy of documentation -presumably to prevent this sort of foolery). So the secure copy was doctored, changed from signed to unsigned.
Later on it was realised the original design was correct, the signed field was needed.
What kind of person would bypass existing procedures to "save" memory.
Person in question is named Sandra White. May be still on the job. (this was 1979 in Canberra)



II. Program tape for a submarine.
Some fool decided to use the program tape as "black box recorder".
Unbelievable stupidity.
Funny coincidence that the planned code change wasn't the one that was issued. Hard to see how it could get worse than the stupidity of writing on the program tape. But it did. The code change, intended to allow writing, corrupted the tape. Culprits are presumably still on the job, raking in $$$



I never suggested there was a memory saving, or any sort of saving.



Apologies daxbert. In my original post I misspelt "trailing tape" so as you said my question made no sense.



</question>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



astronob...
Member since: 15 October 2008
Total points: 131 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I am writing a philosophy essay on Socrates and I am having trouble please help?



Socrates claims to know nothing, and adds that this is a kind of wisdom that sets him apart from
other people. But there are a number of instances in the Apology and Crito in which he seems to be
making certain knowledge claims. First, elaborate what you think are Socrates’ main claims to
knowledge (focus on two or three main ones). Second, determine whether these claims really do
undermine his thesis that he knows nothing. Can his claim of wisdom be defended? If so, show
how; if not, show why not. In light of your discussion, can Socrates’ life still be considered a lesson? please help me find instances where he makes knowledge claims which could be contradictory to his 'i know nothing statement'



</question>



<answer from>



aka
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 118 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



This is a really hard question. I think the place to start with is what he claims in the Crito, without looking at the text - he claims to know that trying to escape is unjust, that he must obey the laws.



Now what you need to do is look closely at that, and see if he is making a wise choice. If he is, then and only then can one go back and see how this stacks up with "knowledge of ignorance," which is really what your teacher means by "know nothing" (notice that to know how people can be ignorant would be the supreme knowledge - knowledge of how things can go wrong and what people are capable of).



I'm linking to a commentary on the Crito below, but my advice is just talk about the texts out loud before going into them and digging for quotes. This is a hard question, good luck with it.



Source(s):



http://www.ashokkarra.com/2008/01/an-int...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks a lot for feedback and link



</asker's comment>

<question from>



Sophie
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 129 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Rhetorical Questions animal testing?



For my R.E. project i am doing animal testing as my ethical issue and i need some rhetorical questions to put in. Please help! Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



Fallen Angel
Member since: 21 June 2007
Total points: 10694 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Have you thought about things like -



What are (human) rights and what do people gain from animal rights?



Are animal rights based on inane thinking or critical reasoning?



Is vegetarianism immoral?



Why did philosophers from ancient times to the Renaissance condemn animals?



Are animal rightists anti-human?



Is factory farming moral farming?



What is animal testing and is it good for people?



Why promote animal rights?



How does property status affect animals?



Is wearing fur good for us?



I can't think of any Rhetorical questions! It very much depends on the flow and contents of your text. Sorry I can't be more help!



</answer>



<answer from>



KORY K
Member since: 09 January 2007
Total points: 1665 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Should I only buy products tested on animal rights activists who volunteered to take the animals place?
How many times does a redundant test need to be run?
Is animal testing worth doing because it benefits humanity?



</answer>

<answer from>



Annaisje...
Member since: 17 May 2008

</answer from>

<answer from>



ioerr
Member since: 25 September 2006
Total points: 11666 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Evil is half of the abstract, "moral" dichotomy by which a great many people organize and evaluate their experiences in life, according to some spiritual or metaphysical framework of understanding, which in the case of many individuals may be barely defined other than in terms of this dichotomy itself.



This dichotomy serves a powerful social purpose, organizing and motivating the political activities of individuals all over the place.



This is why it's always around, like religion itself.  Things that serve no purpose tend to disappear you know.  And yet religion's been around probably longer than any other manifestation of human culture you can think of.



Although, as people routinely point out, there's a serious logical problem with the dichotomy of "good and evil:"  What's evil for one guy can be good for another.



This leads to all kinds of wacky mixups, and is at the root of a great many pointless philosophical arguments.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer from>



Shorty
Member since: 21 March 2008
Total points: 1332 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Evil as defined by Dictionary.com is something morally wrong, harmful, characterized by misfortune or suffering. Be it noun or adjective, "evil" is still an issue of value. Although there are "universal beliefs" that are generally accepted by society, there is always something that will have trust in the contrary. We live in a world where we try to understand everything in a binary system. In this system, one thing cannot exist without an opposite counterpart; to have something "hot" we must have something "cold" to compare it to. Just as we have something "evil" there must be "good" when respecting the binary system. Good as evil's counterpart is just as obscure at times. Each person has a different order of priorities which can render the generally accepted binary system more than useless.



I'm the kind of person that loves knowing how everything works, and with having such a grey area in values, I question where I should place my own. I know what I care about and what I tend to show apathy towards, but it just makes it so much more difficult to encapsulate (sp? it's 2 in the morning) "evil."



Looking at it from a more factual standpoint, since really the only thing evil at the moment is my friend that's taunting me, there is something that I agree with. We are all capable of evil..



There are so many things that get blamed for the bad behavior of others--video games leading to violence is a major one, media corruption... I'm too tired to think of others.. But the fact is that the evil seen here isn't caused by the video games or the TV. It may be inspirational, but it's not responsible for the actions taken.



Consider this...
What does a newborn baby want?... Milk, right?
It's natural for us to do whatever we have to do to get what we need/what we want. Babies will kick and scream and bite and grab and claw to get the milk.



Now what if a baby was born with the strength of an adult? It wouldn't be a pretty picture would it?



It is generally accepted by society that someone is responsible for a child, be it the parents, the uncles, whoever guardian, but they are responsible to raise that child and teach them the difference between right and wrong *yay value binaries* and basically turn them into a functional member of society, no?



Essentially we try to alter the child's perceptions. We won't be able to completely rid them of violent capabilities, but we can try to reprogram them and attempt to tweak their settings..
If a child is acting up or behaving poorly, it is commonly blamed on whoever is supposed to be taking care of the child..Meaning something isn't being done properly.. or effectively..



Since the "evil" is already there, even tho it is deduced by logic through unrealistic scenarios, something violent can't make something that's already harmful harmful... it can, however, be counter productive when it comes to teaching values...



I have no idea if I'm arguing evil or video games anymore, but I think I made my thought clear that we're born evil... even though we can value different things as time goes on...



Society tries to deal with it by teaching, and if it doesn't work it blames whatever there is to blame.... and punishes accordingly... or not at times...



Personally I'm content.. But then... I tend to either have high values or... not care... *we're not really goin into specifics here*
.... just because something's different doesn't mean it's evil.... but yea... there are some things that I don't agree with that are... generally not agreed with...



I agree with sleeping right now....



</answer>



<answer from>

Total points: 21619 (Level 6)

<answer>



freedom is choice.



The essence of freedom is fearlessness.  Even in a restrictive society one may act and do anything they like.  However, fear of consequences make one not truly free.  When one has choice and does not choose one because of fear of another, one is free.
Freedom is living anew in each moment.

<question from>



Pitso
Member since: 01 October 2007
Total points: 838 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Do the woes of Wall Street signal imminent collapse of Christianity’s eternal life theory?



The Christian Bible says in Deuteronomy 17:13, apostates should be stoned to death; those who detract from liberal capitalist orthodoxy are othered (NOTE: this is not a spelling error) as “dangerous,” or authoritarian or dictatorial. Sometimes these apostates, those who dissent to capitalist orthodoxy or who dare consider alternative approaches to social organisation, die or are killed under mysterious circumstances and are replaced by dictatorships that are friendly to the West – to the United States, in particular. This is what happened, for instance, with Patrice Lumumba, in the Congo (who was replaced by General Mobutu Sese Seko), and to Salvado Allende, in Chile (who was replaced by General Augusto Pinochet); they also tried it in Angola.



When all else fails, these capitalist fundamentalists like to tell us (ordinary people) that we simply don’t understand economics, how “an economy works” or “how markets work” or that we should learn mathematics – (seriously). As if these “markets” and market transactions are devoid of any human agency. As if we, humans, are atomistic things locked in place under a reified “economy”.
A few years ago, one of the West’s most respected capitalist economists, Paul Krugman, a darling of liberals in the United States, suggested that people who objected to cheap labour were simply ill-informed, or lacking in intellectual depth. Elsewhere Krugman hailed the use of mathematics and algebra as the only way to explain economics or “the economy”.



When taken together, his book Pop Internationalism and his praise for the use of mathematics to explain everything, or formalism, there is the suggestion that discussions or concerns about poverty, globalisation and even “the economy” is best addressed through a type exclusivism. This exclusivism is apparently homologous with the Christian variant, in terms of which there is only one way towards eternal life – through Jesus Christ. For liberal capitalists there is only one way to organise humanity – in all its complexity; the economic rationalist way as expressed in mathematical and/or algebraic formulation. Every other way of thinking is “unscientific” or lacking in rigour and should, therefore, not be taken seriously.



The US has now resolved to abandon its policy of “unfettered” capitalist “economy”. Will we soon see/hear of intervention where Jesus will no longer be the ONLY way to eternal life?



</question>



<answer from>



Scotters
Member since: 31 May 2008
Total points: 3034 (Level 4)



</answer from>

Are we that arrogant?



Frankly, the financial woes of Wall Street don't impact most of us.



</answer>

<question from>



xuigener...
Member since: 24 September 2007
Total points: 1652 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



How is/does self-actualization equal to freedom?



</question>



<answer from>



temerson
Member since: 23 May 2007
Total points: 3023 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



they are both concepts that exist only int the mind.



You may say for example "I am now free to be myself" but I say you have always been you and if you were not free to be so you placed the limitations.



</answer>



<answer from>



INTOTHEF...
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 460 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Self-actualization describes a person able to embrace reality and facts rather than denying truth, are spontaneous, are interested in solving problems which may include personal problems or the emotional conflicts of others, accepting of themselves and others and lack prejudice.
Freedom often ties in with the question of free will or the ability to act in accordance with one's own true self or values.
I think the 2 feed off of each other.



Not necessarily equal but compliment each other.



</answer>

<answer from>



Annika A
Member since: 16 December 2007
Total points: 475 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You do not taste happiness. Or are you asking figuratively. If you are asking figuratively, then.. Happiness is ice cream. It calms you down when your boyfriend breaks up with you. It is there when you fail a test. It is there when you are nervous. It is always there. Sitting in the refrigerator with such creamy goodness. Then, if you're not asking figuratively... Happiness is something that we feel. It has something to do with endorphins. Endorphins make you feel good. Happiness makes us feel good. That means we are happy. Happiness is something that makes us feel good inside. It lifts us up. Happiness is something that makes us live longer. Makes us smile. Makes us laugh. The one that makes us continue living on the earth.



</answer>



<answer from>



Somesh

<question from>



Glenn M
Member since: 29 July 2008
Total points: 367 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Is there hope for the future of our world?



Any ecosystem can only support so many consumers before it collapses.  With a global population rising exponentially, stripping the world of natural resources, destroying habitats, pumping pollution in to the seas and the atmosphere, competing for dwindling natural resources and land space?



With continued patterns of aggression between nations and religious groups across the world.



With major economic crises in the West.



As a race, humans seem unable to learn from the mistakes of the past.  What does the future hold for us all on this small planet?



Should we trouble ourselves to think of such things, or feel disaffected, unable to make a difference?  Drown ourselves in material possessions, screw everybody else.  I'm as guilty as many of feeling apathetic and just getting on with my own little life as best I can.  So I guess I'm a hypocrite... what do you think?



</question>



<answer from>



Twilight Brigade
Member since: 14 March 2008
Total points: 1642 (Level 3)



</answer from>

</answer>

<answer from>



Phoenix Quill
Member since: 15 March 2007
Total points: 12797 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The economic collapse is a phantom crisis fabricated by Democrats to win an election.  It will mysteriously vanish Nov 5.



The Dems have been forcing banks make 'sub-prime' loans for ~13 years.  ~1 Trillion dollars.  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1RZVw3no2...



Now this isn't a good thing but....



What's being called and 'eminent' collapse is 4% of these loans going bad.  With the purchased property being ~70% of the loan value.



So a bank of two will go under.  Some stocks will take a hit, some idiots in Washington may take a bunch of tax money to bail out the companies they victimized.  But that's about it.



The rest of it is mostly bullshit too.  Pretty much media sadists helping Socialist politicians convince you to vote Liberal.



There are genuine problems to fix, but that's just life.



So, spend your life in a state of phantom fear if you like, or open your eyes to the BS.



Wow, 30 years of Global Warming and the beach still isn't flooded.  Whoda thunk?



</answer>

<answer>



List all the things you're thankful for.



</answer>



<answer from>



William Turner
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 110 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Excercise.



Work Hard.
Pain is weakness leaving the body.



</answer>



<answer from>



Web Design Firm
Member since: 25 July 2008
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I do either anyone of these or a combination of these:
1. Listen to some of my favorite songs which have morale boosting notes
2. Read PMA (positive mental attitude) books
3. Share with my friends and seek their help
4. Retreat in a shell and talk to myself, pen a few lines in my diary or blog, just to get the negative feeling out of my system.



Source(s):



http://ezinearticles.com/?expert=Sonali_...



</answer>



<answer from>



naguru
Member since: 07 August 2007

Maybe the division of power, wherein one group have the wealth, another the reins of power, and a third sector of saffron or religious garbed individuals are assigned pastoral duties to the people. Maybe he has no desire to be second placed or servile, and would rather to his little brood be true.

Maybe he wishes the atheists would apply a little more effort, assert greater intelligence to the eradication of the God concept if they hold the great one in such contempt. Maybe those who feign reverence and declare themselves followers are more loathed by him than those who deny him

So many maybes, so many mood changes, such temperamental erratic behaviour and changeable fickle followers.

<answer>



God DOES exist!
1.The complexity of our planet points to a deliberate Designer who not only created our universe, but sustains it today.
2.The human brain's complexity shows a higher intelligence behind it.
3."Chance" or "natural causes" are insufficient explanations.
4.To state with certainty that there is no God, a person has to ignore the passion of an enormously vast number of people who are convinced that there is a God.
5.We know God exists because he pursues us. He is constantly initiating and seeking for us to come to him.
6.Unlike any other revelation of God, Jesus Christ is the clearest, most specific picture of God pursuing us.

If a person opposes even the possibility of there being a God, then any evidence can be rationalized or explained away. It is like if someone refuses to believe that people have walked on the moon, then no amount of information is going to change their thinking. Photographs of astronauts walking on the moon, interviews with the astronauts, moon rocks...all the evidence would be worthless, because the person has already concluded that people cannot go to the moon.

You can believe what you want, but as for me, the awesomeness of this universe is proof enough for me. This world could not have just came into existence. Someone must have created it.

I hope this helps.



</answer>

margaret...

<answer>



You're not asking whether He does exist as some members take you to mean.
You are not even asking a reason why He does (or does not) exist. Each to his own about the gender of God, by the way.
It sounds to me as if someone has asked you (or you have asked yourself) for proof that God exists and the best answer you can come with is, "Well, why not?"
That's the only reason I have ever been able to give for the existence of God and my faith in Him and to me it's the only complete answer. It's atheists that have a hard time of it because they feel have to prove his non-existence. Proving or disproving is an interesting philosophical exercise (wish I had time to go into it right now but I've got to go back to work) but analysing why people have faith in God - or any thing or ideal - rather misses the point, I think. The point is, that people need to believe in something outside of themselves no matter what form it takes. 
Existentialists say, "well, faith in a God is copping out on the responsibility that men should take for their own actions". Well, I would like to disagree with that but, as I say, I've got to fly now - the dishes (among other things) await me.



</answer>

<answer>



Yes. The sole cause of everything in existence is 'nature'. Who controls 'nature'. Who exercises influence on nature. There must be a person responsible for maintaining the balance in nature. Who does this? In our human body, we have mental faculty through which we can try to find some sort of explanation. Sometimes nature plays havoc, like cyclonic storm, tsunami, floods, earthquakes, heavy downpour, lightning, etc. Nature consists of five basic elements viz. earth, water, tejas (brightness), air and space. It is interesting to know about these five elements.

In the universe everything is made up of these five elements only. All creations are also made up of these five elements. The universal and individual aspect of these five elements have got some intrinsic cosmic relations. Universe is in macro level and the individual in micro level. If we know how to maintain a best correlation between individual and universal nature, we become highly qualified to lead a happy and peaceful life. The remedy for all individual problems can be found if one can maintain this relation. It is a secret knowledge. But secret never remains secret. Nature reveals it. We should know how to explore this potential form.



Source(s):



My own knowledge and experience

Nature is our mother, but who is the father?  At this point in our evolution we have a material body born from the material elements, but because we are conscious, sentient beings as well, our "image" is from the father, the Supreme Personality of Godhead. Yet we know consciousness does exist and without being conscious observations or speculations about life are impossible. Does a stone think?



So the answer is no. Because nature is not the source of consciousness, the essence of our life, then nature is not the source of everything in the world, what to speak of the spiritual realm where there is nothing but consciousness.

<answer from>



The Will 2 Defy
Member since: 29 September 2007
Total points: 1955 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, I would suggest the sole cause of everything in existence appears to be attributable to the temporal state of nature. I might be tempted to rephrase the statement "The sole *function of everything in *nature is *existence." The ability to exist more efficiently and defy odds seem to be precisely the qualities passed from generation to generation.

What I think we are talking about here Nietzsche called "the will to power"; which kinda means that which attains most power retains the right to exist. Nietzsche clung to this idea as his most fundamental when he said "The world itself is the will to power - and nothing else! And you yourself are the will to power - and nothing else!" He even went so far as to say that it is the closest thing in nature to aboslute truth.

Even though I cannot say what is true and false in terms of the basis of existence - prerequisite physical or spiritual phenomena, it makes sense that what we can be sure of is the right to exist is dependent on our forefathers ability to defy downfall and facilitate power and subsequently gain: prosperity. If I may use a church as an analogy: the church is there to promote its brand of religion [culture] above others. Therefore different churches compete for the right to exist and outlive opposing churches. Architects compete to find more solid structures to defy weather and gravity and strengthen the symbol of itself. Therefore, I would suggest that the sole function of the church is its ability to stay standing - the sole function of the church in nature is existence.

As you have noticed, I have replaced the term cause with function. This is because 'cause' implies a reasoning that precedes the existence of something. The idea that existence itself requires a sole cause implies that the cause exists outside existence.. something of a paradox.. solvable by spirituality [the creator] or in Niezsches case eternal return. To my mind that is the only queston that will always remain too big to attempt answering.



</answer>



<answer from>



Wisdom Tormented™
Member since: 11 December 2007
Total points: 20090 (Level 6)

<answer>



The soul cause of existence is energy. Whilst energy drives, inspires, empowers will, existence as we know it remains, simply transforming and manifesting in different variants of the life form know as mankind. The function of this will to power and existence is survival. The function of survival is to increase energy mass. The cause is transmission of energy to receptors likely to strengthen this energy.

Positive energy is Love, life giving m rejuvenating and cleansing. Negative energy is toxic caused by hate and the poisonous vigour it creates. These two dual energy forces prolong existence albeit constantly battling for dominance. This war is manifested within each individual, home and society as battle for dominance.

The will to power is mans versatility top adapt to his constantly changing environment whilst retaining cohesion with the underling unchangeable consistency. The ability to increase in measure of positive energy and the power and influence it creates albeit a control of one’s own will and mind, household and fraternity. The dysfunctional chaos degenerated into a high maintenance verging upon the ungovernable society we have at present is caused by a dangerous parity of both positive and negative energies not increasing independently but simply firing one another, neither growing or diminishing. An enduring vicious cycle of pain, gain and loss, birth, death and rebirth without progress or maturing in self sufficiency and the autonomy that creates a perfect society and world.

Indeed the church is evidence of this dual parity of the positive and negative. If any church were adept and competent it would ideally produce a creed of perfect individuals. We would all immediately convert to be party to this perfection yet this is not so. Churches now promote themselves on a singular edict upon which they seek to acquire a certain type of individual ultimately to sell out when failing to do so and adopt an indiscriminate policy, rendering the orginal beliefs defunct thereby.

Inspired by Will2Defy.



</answer>

<answer>



I know this is in the Philosophy section, but I felt like giving some insight from science.

In Physics, it is generally agreed that at one time or another every particle in existance was linked, due to a theory that is involved in quantum mechanics. This leads me to think that it is entirely possible that people can be linked, from means that we don't understand fully. I honestly do believe that some people are perfectly suited for one another, but they can also be happy with others, and therefore will not always find one another. Perhaps this is why some relationships aren't as happy and/or peaceful as others.



For the second question, I will take a religious point of view. Many Christians say that God doesnt appear to everyone, and cure all the worlds ailments because we have to have faith to fully understand him. We would take God for granted if he solved all of our problems, so to speak.

We would do exactly the same thing for soulmates. If we were born into the "new life" as you put it with our soulmates it would no longer be special and we would take it for granted. Thats what makes soulmates special. Finding that one person in the world that suits us, out of the 6 Billion that are currently alive is amazing.

Hope this provides some insight.
J.O



Source(s):



Personal opinion.



</answer>

bud85348

<answer>



What is a soul mate? The question indicates a lack of knowledge as to what Soul is.

For me I have been married to the same wife for 50 years and she is my best friend. We plan on continuing our relationship in the next life and through out eternity.

The idea of returning to this planet in some other body is an ancient view and one which is out dated.



An olden race was especially given to belief in transmigration and reincarnation. This idea of reincarnation originated in the observance of hereditary and trait resemblance of offspring to ancestors. The custom of naming children after grandparents and other ancestors was due to belief in reincarnation. Some later-day races believed that man died from three to seven times. This belief (residual from the teachings of Adam about the mansion worlds), and many other remnants of revealed religion, can be found among the otherwise absurd doctrines of twentieth-century fixed and backward thinkers.



</answer>

<answer>



I am not sure I lived a past life, or had a soul mate in a past life.  However, I do feel like I have found a soul mate in this life I am currently living.  A soul mate does not have to be someone you have an intimate, romantic physical relationship with. In fact, most people have soul mates that they are not married to.  A soul mate is someone you connect with on a much deeper intimate soul level.  You understand each other, and love each other just for being the person they are.



I wish more people would seek out their own soul mate, rather than deciding the person they marry must be their soul mate.  It just doesn't work this way.  So many people would find joy in their life to find that soul mate, no matter what the relationship and situation they are in.

Thanks for reading!

<answer>



Maybe the real question is "Is it necessary to destroy desire and will in order to be happy?"  From what I can tell, the answer is "no."  Thinking that you have to destroy parts of yourself...if it's even possible to do that...in order to be happy could mean that you are operating with less than all of the information about happiness that is available to you.  From what I can tell, being happy is about a decision you get to make about your life each moment that you are alive.  Desire is about wanting things, and whether getting those things will make you happy or not is another thing entirely.  Will is about your freedom to choose.  There is no reason to give up either of these things in order to be happy.  Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



Happiness need not be antagonistic to desire. After all desire is part of Creation/Nature. In fact, true experience of genuine desire ( not greed, not indulgence ) will eventually lead us the absence of desire, ushering in a higher quality of happiness. Key factor is awareness. Anything done with full/total awareness takes us to the choice- less  awareness, a desire -less state. Moreover, when the mind is given something that is more than the happiness due to satisfaction of desires, it moves away from desire. Meditation, often, gives such an experience of happiness that is a-causal, different from the desire fulfilled happiness.

<answer from>



Simply Reflect
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 11109 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



The question could be read in two different ways. Firstly, as if it is asking if we could destroy desire and use our will - if the word ‘will’ is read as a verb - in favour of some greater happiness. If this is what you mean then you have pitched desire against happiness, and by doing this simply meaning that desire and happiness are two things diametrically opposed, as happiness could be had if we, by the active use of our will, could control our desires, and therefore live for the purpose of some higher goals in view, as instead or merely seeking to fulfil the wants of our desire we could reach beyond carnal pleasures of our body to find true happiness.

If this is the case, then I would like to suggest first of all that any such notion of happiness is an illusion, an immaculate dream, unreal and unattainable in reality. I firmly believe that we are where we are, both mentally as well as spiritually, that where we are is where desires are rooted, or this means to say that it is by the very reason of our earthly desires rooted in the reality of our world that we are rooted. It is due to our needs and desires that we find this world a friendly place to live in, and also to live through. This is by the very reason of our nature that we cannot be happy without a reasonable fulfilment of our desires - then killing desire, meaning all desires, would only bring upon chaos and sense of dislocation in the mind. We might then be asking as what are we doing here? There would be no challenge, nothing to do battle with, noting to use to improve, and overcome, no way of knowing what we want, and how are we doing.

I therefore think that instead of killing desires the purpose of life is to find happiness in using them for living, as it is commonly said: not living to eat but to eat to live. Desires are instinctive and natural in the mind. They make us strong the way fuel brings an engine to life. When we come in this world we are all but desires and needs, a purely natural beings. We like to be liked and we like to have what we need and what we desire. But as we live grow older and learn the ways of our world we also learn the use of reason in the methods of fulfilling our desires. We learn to master our will but not become a needless and free from desire person but to become a refined person who would can manage to have desire without losing his sense of purpose.



In this sense, desires, especially when they run riots in our mind, or for the purpose of us seeking to know as what good use we can put them, what higher disciplines could we find to alternate upon them, to keep them in check, for without knowing nothing better then the materialistic objects our desires we would stay trapped in the baser realities of life, we would not know as if we find desires taxing and wasting then for what purpose and by what reason we should sacrifice them. I for instance would not be able to fast and pray - as provided the purity of my intention none of these would fulfil any of my desires - and keep sane if do not do this for some good purpose of my faith. And on the other hand if do not have desire then what would be there to sacrifice and use to make life a better life.

But the question could also be read as meaning if we could kill both desire and will, all in favour of happiness. If you mean this by asking then I ask what would you use to kill desire if not will, and once desires is gone then will would still remains, as just per instance. This way we reach a dilemma as will could only be killed by the use of faculties of the mind that do not need will itself as driving force, which of course is our instinctive urges, needs of desires. This in fact is conundrum of a situation as desires can only be circumvent by the use of will applied for some reason or purpose, and will can only be killed by desires, the it cannot be known as how to kill both without using any thing else, for happiness does not kill anything it only replaces sadness and sorrow.

This is not very clear as what exactly you mean by your questions: to kill desire and use will for the purpose of being happy, as living an idealistic, but desire free, life, or to kill both, desire and will, for the sake of some immaculate happiness, or. I person find more sense in the former, where I have elaborated that desire are fuel of life that could also burn and destroy if not handled carefully and rightly purposefully.



</answer>



<answer from>



shades of Bruno
Member since: 26 December 2006
Total points: 3869 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Happiness is the very goal of desire, or it can be said that all our desires are focused on attaining happiness of one sort or another, but desire by itself is but a dream if it is not crystyllized and given impetus by the will.

I think what you mean by happiness is innocence, and that is not brought about by desire at all, it is the very nature of those who have either not yet experienced the world or of those who have gone beyond it, which is not to say that they have 'destoyed' desire. The happiness which is attained by desire does not last - a desire arises,the will is joined to it,and is followed by success or failure in attaining the goal, but either way neither the happiness nor the unhappiness lasts.



That which you are refering to must be uncaused for it not to be a temporary effect of a cause,like the 'destruction' of desire.



</answer>



<answer from>



truthsee...
Member since: 15 February 2008
Total points: 373 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If we look a the lives of those who try, we can easily see the answer for ourselves. Many religious/spiritual practices are in favor of suppressing certain desires in order to achieve some spiritual affirmation or resolution. Its quite common for Catholic and Buddhist monks to practice celibacy or restraint from sexual desires. Although their reasoning's may vary, they both agree that it helps to eliminate suffering. But are desires the reason why we suffer? No, in fact desires are the only reason were able to feel happiness.While suffering comes to us by thinking only of our own desires and not of others.

But what are desires? They're something we feel as a lack or a need within us. And only by filling this lack are we given the sensation of happiness. Have you ever heard the expression "a woman is never happy until her needs are met." Well this applies to us all.

Well perhaps you've heard about this before or maybe this is nothing new. But what we so often overlook is how once our needs are met, once receiving the pleasure/happiness derived from filling them, our desire consequently disappears. Thus eliminating the source where happiness can be received.

So maybe the problem is not with our desires, but with how we receive pleasure from them. We go from one desire to the next, because our happiness is always short lived like a fleeting moment. But what if the true problem was in the way we receive or for whom we receive for? Humanity has looked in all fields and sciences in trying to figure out ways to make us happy, but do we have a science that deals with the nature of receiving it? If I receive for myself and my needs are limited, then so shall the happiness derived from them be limited too. But what If I was able to receive for others? Well below, I've attached a link to a short video to help answer those questions.

Cheers!!



Source(s):



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iRZZzUYIK...



</answer>

<answer from>



natalie nkay
Member since: 17 July 2008
Total points: 163 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Nobody is entirely free of society because society encompasses all. Even if you are a vagabond, a recluse, a pervert, a certified lunatic, an out-and-out iconoclast or even anti-social- society has a section of people like you so that individualism does not exist per se.

A free spirit, I suppose, is someone who lives within a society but lives by bending some rules of that society. A free-spirit cannot be defined then as the opposite of someone who conforms to society. Gypsies and cross-dressers, for example, are considered as free spirits but they certainly conform to other codes of society even though they may defy some. Someone who walks about town in a kilt and frilly blouse would be defying society in some aspect and could even be called a free spirit, but he is not someone who does not conform to society altogether.

So, my answer is- I am a free spirit who conforms to society when what I am conforming to does not clash with my principles.



</answer>



<answer from>



skycat
Member since: 22 August 2006
Total points: 7293 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes a free spirit Princess
I like to get my priorities straight. A free spirit is not the kind to twist and turn to meet your every need. You'll have to make it simple for them by coming to an understanding of what you want most out of a relationship and asking for that, and nothing else.



Don't sweat the small stuff. Things like punctuality, precautions, and any other kind of minor limit or inhibition will be of no concern to an independent mind. They like to flow through life, following their whims - and this often makes them extremely creative and fascinating individuals, which is what probably attracted you to them in the first place. By imposing dams, as little as they may be, you could very well suffocate the qualities that make this person desirable to you, if you don't manage to scare them off first.



Avoid setting rules. Restrictions are like chains, and will send this wild horse running towards the horizon. Get to know the person inside out. Study their tendencies, their quirks, their deepest desires, and their worst fears. Always be accepting and open-minded. Knowledge is power. The better you know this person, the less you'll feel the need to control them. Moreover, he or she will sense this and feel like you're the only person who truly knows them and thus, the only person they can be their uninhibited selves around. To a free spirit, this is the jackpot.

Good Night Princess xoxo



</answer>



<answer from>



robin
Member since: 07 May 2008
Total points: 1995 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



neither.  i go my own way in most things. but i can't call myself a free spirit because i strongly value my independence and that requires earning one's own living and being responsible for all one's own choices. i've always stepped back a moment when the crowds are rushing in one direction. hate crowds and rarely excited about anything most people are excited about. on the other hand, the crowd might be rushing towards something really wonderful or away from something awful.  in other words, i don't try to be different simply for the sake of being different. which in my thinking makes a person as controlled by others as following their lead.



</answer>

<question>



How can a philosopher have no ultimate goal?



Thanks for sharing your thoughts. Have a great day!



</question>



<answer from>



lt;I&gt;
Member since: 30 August 2006
Total points: 7521 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Philosophy is like a never-ending journey of discovery, the never-ending story in the making [it's NOT like going on vacation or trying to reach the Moon]; if you set an ultimate goal [a Destination] you have already ruined and tainted the trek.  One cannot do philosophy with a biased mind - the journey IS the reward [the trek is the destination, if you must - just ask James T. Kirk.  :-)].



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ipe5Ejcch...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jRM0yLxMi...

.



Source(s):



Great Question, BTW!



</answer>

<answer from>



ganesha_...
Member since: 25 January 2008
Total points: 1286 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I believe most philosophers do maintain an ultimate goal - however, dependent upon the philosophical style of analysis - that ultimate goal may be simple acceptance and understanding of the current state. An existentialist, by definition, is not looking for anything other than a marked comprehension of the factors and reasons which make us 'here'. Why, what, when, how, who - are all questions they may experience and investigate to better explain the purpose of our creation, existence and demise. A creationist or philosophical theologian may search for man's ultimate responsibility to god and god's creations.



Philosophy is the why of everything. Omnipotence, while lofty, may be considered the object of a philosopher's ponderings, however, are rarely the outright product.

Finally, I believe you might be hard pressed to find a philosopher who would be content stating that was their endpoint.



</answer>

<answer>



There is no doubt if you are biased then the conclusion you've reached is flawed. However you can't have any answers or discovery until you have a goal. Even if you are not aware you still have an outcome in mind . . . . a goal. If you intend on going to NY then that destination is your goal.

True within philosophy there is NO ultimate truth as each person seeks his/her own answer . . .  and we don't always reach the same conclusions. However you can not have an answer until you are focused on a particular aspect ie goal. Over the centuries many philosophers have tried to unlock the mysteries, tried to simply the basic questions; ie
where do we come from, 
is there a God, 
is there a difference between humans and animals,
Is our reality just an illusion,
What leads a person to kill,
etc etc

Each question in a sense is a goal, we must have a question, an inquiry before we can begin seeking answers. If there is no question there is no answer, and then there is simply no concept of philosophy!

The underlying base is 'curiosity, it is our curiosity that leads as to inquire, which then becomes a goal, something we need the understanding of. So among many things Philosophy is also basically 'curiosity' - as it is our curiosity that compels us to seek answers!



</answer>

psyengin...

</answer from>



<answer>



–adjective 1. last; furthest or farthest; ending a process or series: the ultimate point in a journey; the ultimate style in hats.



2. maximum; decisive; conclusive: the ultimate authority; the ultimate weapon.



3. highest; not subsidiary: ultimate goal in life.



4. basic; fundamental; representing a limit beyond which further progress, as in investigation or analysis, is impossible: the ultimate particle; ultimate principles.



5. final; total: the ultimate consequences; the ultimate cost of a project.



6. not to be improved upon or surpassed; greatest; unsurpassed: the ultimate vacation spot; the ultimate stupidity.



–noun 7. the final point; final result.



8. a fundamental fact or principle.



9. the best, greatest, or most extreme of its kind.



http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/u...

How to be human. Caring.



</answer>

<question>



What came first the universe or the laws that govern it?



and what was the point of laws when there was no one around to understand them , ( in the beginning.)



</question>



<answer from>



dettom
Member since: 06 May 2008

<answer from>



trprat
Member since: 24 July 2008
Total points: 214 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Both happened at the same instant.  Laws are not for individuals.  Wouldn't it sound stupid if laws were made only for those who can understand them?  Everything in the Universe (except perhaps, man) understand and obey laws.  (Men are more keen on breaking them).



</answer>



<answer from>



Destrii
Member since: 18 January 2008
Total points: 309 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Laws (of physics) don't have to have anyone to understand them in order to exist. For instance, you could argue that what's the point of, say, radioactivity, when only the dinosaurs existed because they couldn't understand particle theory? But it's still there.

I suppose what we call "laws" are really only "truths", which are always correct and always apply in our universe. The word law indicates that you can disobey it, but are not allowed to. With a law of physics, it is not a question of "may", but "are able to".

So, in conclusion, the laws which govern the universe were created at the same time; one did not cause the other. Perhaps they are, to a certain extent, the same thing? Besides, is this philosophy or physics? Do I need to get out more? These questions may never be answered.



Source(s):



... my brain...



</answer>



<answer from>



pɹɵpħɚɫ
Member since: 24 April 2008
Total points: 2184 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would say they both began at the same time. Without the laws, there would be no universe to govern. And without the universe, there is no need for laws.

"what was the point of laws when there was no one around to understand them"

I don't think there is a point to the laws of the universe. They just are. But without them absolutely nothing would exist.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sauwelio...
Member since: 21 April 2006
Total points: 3846 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The universe and the "laws" (necessities) that govern it are inseparable. Those "laws" are formulations of how the universe works. But the universe is not the subject and the "working" its activity; the universe *is* the working -- it is a *process*.

As to your second question: the so-called "laws" of the universe are not laws in the legal sense, which can be broken or adhered to. The "laws" of the universe can't be broken: they are *necessities*.



</answer>



<answer from>



Russ Z
Member since: 30 March 2008
Total points: 179 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Part 1: There are only six possibilities. (a) The universe and the laws that govern it came into existence at the same time, (b) The laws preceded the universe, (c) the universe preceded the laws, (d) The universe exists without the laws -- there are no laws governing the universe, (e) There is, in reality, no universe, just the laws, and (f) There is neither a universe or laws that govern it.

I personally favor (e) or (f). Our concept of the universe is a mental manifestation of our understand of the laws that govern it. Regardless of whether we understand the universe or even accept its existence, reality will go on.

Part 2.  The laws are absolute. Just because  one doesn't understand the law of gravity (for example), doesn't allow (or make them) go floating off into space -- the molecules of his body don't go flying apart due to the lack of any cohesive attraction. Therefore the laws exist regardless of our understanding of them.



</answer>



<answer from>



Skatta
Member since: 08 July 2006
Total points: 4100 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



they arrived at the same time. the laws are as much universe as anything else. before there was mass there could not have been the laws that mass must follow. though once mass existed as mass is, then it must follow those laws by the nature of its being.

there is no point of laws. the laws just are. it is the way things interact. the laws as we know are just us figuring out the way stuff interacts.

there is no more point to the laws now then in the beginning, though because of the laws we are able to exist as we are know, interact with the universe as we do now, and also use our knowledge of the laws for our own ends.



but technically the universe did not really come into being so much, and yet it wasn't always around, because time is also a component of universe and there was a point where there was no time, no space since the universe was packed as tight as is possible. in this case do you still say there was universe? well yes and no. was the universe around forever? well, yes and no, if it comes from a point where there was no time, then there is no before, no forever, no amount of time, no size no distance, was something there? yes and no.



</answer>

<answer>



I guess the same time.
The universe started out as a singularity of enormous heat and density.

The laws of physics work only up to a point.  Once you get to the actual beginning of the singularity, or try to guess what was "before" it, the laws of physics break down.



You get to a quantum level at that point, and we currently don't understand things at that level.  And they certainly don't follow the laws of physics



</answer>

<answer>

<answer>

deepred

</answer from>



<answer>



the place between



</answer>



<answer from>



Nice Vibrations
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 209 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I agree with Third P.

Also will like to add that in our daily life we are always being offered several choices for different issues. The heart does not think but it knows what is the best choice and always offers you the best possible choice but it sees no reason to show you why that choice is the best choice because it sees no reason why you would not make that choice. It feels that since this is the best choice then taking that choice must just come naturally to you.

The head on the other hand always want to see were a particular choice is going to lead it to. And often it cannot see where the hearts choice is leading to and so interprets that it may not be the best choice. It wants to take that choice which it thinks gives the greatest clarity of what the choice is leading to.

"Follow Your Heart". Thats what so many have tried to tell us. It means to take the choice that the heart has to offer and have no doubt that that is the correct choice. Clarity will always come as you follow that choice.

But 'following the heart' is also a choice and the head has a difficult time accepting that in the absence of clarity.



</answer>

<answer>



I think it all depends on the person and situation in which I am to be held accountable. If someone asks me to do something or to be somewhere, and I have no interest in the person or the activity, I might say I'm interested but I simply won't go.



However, if I AM interested in those things, I am highly reliable. I find that it's more of the people around me who are unreliable, rather than the other way around.

<question from>



Brent S
Member since: 12 June 2008
Total points: 224 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Will science ever have the same rights as Christianity?



In Creationism according to Genesis, God created the Earth in seven days, yet science says that the Earth was formed over millions of years. The laws of Physics forbid something to be made from nothing, as it happened in Genesis.
At the beginning of time there was only Adam and Eve. Are we all in-bread? Surely evolution makes more sense.

Why don't science and Christianity have equal rights?
The word 'God' is spelt with a capital G, as is Genesis. 
Why isn't evolution spelt with a capital E?
Christianity is spelt with a capital C so why isn't science spelt with a capital S?
Does religion have the 'copyright' for the term 'church'? There are no 'Churches of Science.' I would imagine there would be a big argument if a Church of Science did open.
Do you think science and Christianity should have equal political rights? Will religion always win? Could the two beliefs SOMEHOW be united in your mind or do they mix like oil and water?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I certainly hope that they never reconcile.  It's just way too much fun watching the Xtians try to slug it out with the Science types ☺

Doug



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



The trick to religion is not to read into it. My grandma once knew an atheist who read the Bible cover to cover- and said it was the best story he'd read. Faith is a matter of believing, science is a matter of fact.



As far as rights... Religion has been around a fair bit longer. It's earned some rights of passage. Also, religion deals with higher powers, more in depth themes, and is not truly of this world. Science is of this world in every meaning. As an earthly form, it drops the capitalization.

Because of the age of the religious books, and the fact they were spread by word of mouth, everything must be taken with a grain of salt. Also think of its purpose; doesn't it make God seem more powerful if he created the whole universe from nothing in seven days, forming man with a touch of his hand and the dust of the earth than if we gradually grew from monkeys over millions of years?

If you believe, you don't question. If you question, leave others to believe.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>
