<answer>



Atheism benefits none. The Almighty Father, Supreme Universal Spirit, he who is known as is attained by diligent endeavor, stealth and a lifelong quest. The receiving of Gods Spirit, and the incumbent faith and wisdom are the greatest gifts accorded to man, the highest goal of accomplishment.



Atheism is a modern day subversive anarchy.  Atheists having observe the receipt of God’s grace by ordinate souls, feel they have a right to *demand* evidence of Gods existence. ‘Evidence’ is actually the spiritual awakening and self realization of the world and its creator and is gained by arduous striving than demanded.

God is not a necessity to live life well. Rather love and goodness are essential virtues of living well. God is found where there is love, peace and understanding, therefore he is a necessity. It is the definition of God requiring clarification with precision prior to the declaration of essentialism.



Esoteric belief in man requiring sufficient knowledge to acquire peace of mind and to live harmoniously is fitting.
It is based upon the premise and principle line of thinking that mans need of sciences, religion and philosophy is to gain him the knowledge to facilitate the mastery of his own mind and world about him, towards a control of the same said resulting in liberation from the mercy of worldly elements.

Ultimately man seeks physical comfort, emotional security and to live in loving peace. Thought, thinking, contemplation of the world is the journey towards that still deep universal silence and release.



</answer>

lauratea...
Member since: 25 May 2006

This normal for people to develop a common sense of a physical nature, of possessions, of status, of physical power, of resources, and thereupon of lust, greed and avarice, but then such mind stays confined therein, unable to see beyond the wall of their containment, such mind fall victim all the vicissitude of mater, to it natural ebbs and flows of fame and fortune, disease and health.



A mind, that on the other hand, is raised to seek loftiness of its natural capacities, of high dimensions, through its heavenly dreams and divine visions, might live in the same physical world with other people, but will be seen differently.



</answer>

deknowsi...

Total points: 3811 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Inaccurate. Although, not necessarily wrong. In my opinion it is far to vague.



There are two issues I see with this statement.

1 - Evil is subjective. What you call evil others may see as good and vise versa.



2 - What do you mean "Love of the world"? Obviously 'Green peace' may believe that loving the world is a great and good thing. Others will assume that you are referring to materialism, so "Love of the world" means love of material objects and things. Buddhists may take this to mean attachment to anything at all, friends, loved ones, life even death. A Christian, or other theist my take this to refer to mortal life as opposed to spiritual life. A atheist may just think this absurd since what do we have other then this world?



So, it may be better to say, "To longing for materialistic pleasures is the root of all troubles."



After all, in my opinion, indolence, gluttony, bigotry & profligacy are among the leading causes of societies decline and all of these center on 'worldly' pleasures or points of view.

Hope this helps.



~~



</answer>

simplyun...

Contributing In:

<answer>



I believe all who live in this world love, or need to love to live. The world therefore is a place not merely for living, but also for loving. Where else do we go to find love if not in the things chosen from the world we have, in people who we like, and in ideas the tapestry of which is woven, and inter woven, the realities of the world? I therefore would not knock the love of the world as the ‘root of all evils’ I would say instead that when we lack some discipline in loving, we grow futile and vain in our affair with the world.



As a matter of fact I believe that love of the world is the only thing that keeps us sane and happy with our lot, for if we would love nothing of the world we have we would go mad, or simply would die of boredom or with sense of utter alienation. But this is it, as I believe that there in our love of our world are contained possibilities of divine love, the love of God and His entire creation that we are but a part of.



I think it in our capacity to learn to love the world the way it should be loved best, with in view not only what it is for us now, but also what it could lead us to. The physical dimension of the world is what normally remains most obvious to people, and it is most likely for people to indulge into materialistic pursuits of their daily lives, but the salvation comes what we realised spiritual potential of our apparently physical love.



</answer>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



djbennet...
Member since: 27 June 2006
Total points: 6 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is a straw man argument?



</question>



<answer from>



Al
Member since: 02 June 2006
Total points: 983 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



A "straw man" is a high-level outline of what you will be arguing.

This is to get the process started and give others an idea of what you're thinking.



</answer>



<answer from>



Joe S
Member since: 31 May 2007
Total points: 5830 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Politics



</answer from>



<answer>



A straw man argument is a weak argument that you project upon your opponent that you can then knock down.  The problem with using this tactic is that it is an argument that your opponent does not actually make.  The tactic is typically viewed as being dishonest.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Straw_man



</answer>



<answer from>



Woody Couder
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 152 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Staw man argument is a logical fallacy that involves taking another person's words out of context to counter the argument usually an extreme version of somebody's argument

set up example:
Person A takes position P
Person B ignores P and presents Q
Person B attacks position Q
Person B concludes P is wrong

Example:
Person A:
Laws on Marijuana should be more liberalized.

Person B:
No. Work ethic is lost and we would have a more corrupt society when we allow unrestricted access to drugs.



Person A proposed more liberalized marijuana laws, Person B took it to an extreme of 'unrestricted access to drugs' which is outside of the scope of just marijuana and also unrestricted access instead of just more liberalized.



</answer>



<answer from>



SDR-4X
Member since: 03 July 2008
Total points: 220 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



A straw man argument is where you misrepresent your opponent's view to the audience such that it seems obviously false. For example:

bob: We should disassemble our nuclear weapons

alice: NO, OF COURSE NOT! YOU want russia to bomb us to death. You want the world to be ruled by a bunch of reds? What's wrong with you? Does anyone else here want to be bombed and enslaved by another stalin?

Alice just used a strawman. it is a fallacy.

P.S. I don't mean to insult anyone with alice. That was just the first thing to come to my mind.



</answer>



<answer from>



timboban...
Member since: 24 November 2006
Total points: 317 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Straw manning someone is a debate "tactic" where someone misrepresents your argument. They'll take your basic argument and exaggerate it so that nobody could possibly agree with it, and then claim that it is your viewpoint and scoff at you for believing something so ridiculous.



</answer>



<answer from>



Stan W
Member since: 19 June 2006
Total points: 1324 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ok lets try this one more time.
Straw man falacy is where you misrepresent your opponants position, or he may do the same to you, thus providing an inargueble possition.
 in discussion of Hillery for president.
A: I dont think Hillery would make a good president
B answers So you dont think  a woman should be president.

Note that B's answer is not only Nonsequiture but it makes A's possition less defenceble and now A has to go back and restate his origional position and deny the Straw man fallacy, before he can even present his agument about  Hillery being president.



</answer>

Timaeus

<answer>



A straw man argument is a caricature of someone's position, which one presents as representing the other's substantial claims, and then identifies as being inadequate.



</answer>



<answer from>



george
Member since: 30 July 2006
Total points: 1528 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



A strawman argument is a statement intended to confuse an opponent involved in an argument, where he or she might have to give account for their own point of views. The strawman argument is a dialectical strategy where you take your opponent in his words but just to turn what he says up side down and blow everything out of proportion. The art of demagogy involves the skill of being able to coax your auditorium into believing that to hold some particular point of view always brings on certain consequences. Here is an example:

...At a very well known Swiss resort in the Alps, there is this debate on drugs policies and abuse strategies

A. Doctor Wilbert A. Zimmerman: Let us face it! What is it what we have achieved after decades of fighting against drugs? Is it not about time to address the problem?

B. Spanish politician David Quemacarrada, senior congressman and leader of the league for the protection of the people: You mean we should depenalize, as in making them “drugs” legal? For crying out aloud! With due respect doctor Wilbert, but this is the postulate that will lead us to this free-for-all society you stand for and which you take pleasure in pushing on us? And about the kids, when then shall we start them in it?

A. Zimmerman: As I understand, they are already doing it are they not?

B. Quemarracada: So you want to turn a blind eye on them; are we supposed to let them down so?

A. Zimmerman: It is actually this policy on drugs what is letting our kids down so. Under current legislations it becomes increasingly impossible to work with drug related problems and the so called “substances of abuse”. Men have been using drugs for millennia now and this ban on drugs is not putting any one off doing it.

B. Quemarracada: Prostitution and slavery have also been practised for ages have they not? Shall we then keep a blind eye on them too?

A. Zimmerman: They surely have, but prostitution is consubstantial with human nature as it is whereas slavery is not. What we are saying is “it is possible to free men from these chains”, but that the task cannot be done under current legislation. This society has a problem with drugs, but our proposal is not intended to make up for this situation: it is rather directed to a reduction of gun and knife crime and violence. What we ask for is “regulation”, for we do not like the factual “free-for-all” society this lack of policy is pushing on us. Only if we cut down on violence and crime will be possible to address the problem this society has with drugs, which is rather a medical problem.



B. Quemarracada: So you stand for total anarchy? Shall we then legalize crime as well?

A. Zimmerman: no; it is rather that we want to avoid it, out of fear for our kids. Drugs are at hand, they are everywhere, and it is also under current legislation that is seems to be down to criminal mafias to outline the market or tax the product. It is also under current legislation down to criminals to decide how pure a drug should be, who should be sold to, and what age group. Nowadays it is easier for a kid to buy pot than alcohol, as they usually ask you for ID when you buy it. It is precisely this anarchy for the UK you propose, available at hand as we speak, what we do not like. What do we need all of this blood for?

As you can see, any strawman argument can be turned against your opponent if you know your GCSCs. Please do note senior congressman Quemarracada here represents the political idiot, that is, a person who is well able with words but not with arguments, which usually require a good deal of studying and thinking.



</answer>



<answer from>



mtheoryr...
Member since: 30 November 2007
Total points: 9812 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



Others have covered the topic but I just thought I would share with you this list of common and distinct fallacies.



Source(s):



http://www.iep.utm.edu/f/fallacy.htm



</answer>



<answer from>



Fallen Angel
Member since: 21 June 2007
Total points: 9351 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



A straw man argument is an informal fallacy based on misrepresentation of an opponent's position. To "set up a straw man" or "set up a straw man argument" is to describe a position that superficially resembles an opponent's actual view but is easier to refute, then attribute that position to the opponent (for example, deliberately overstating the opponent's position).  A straw man argument can be a successful rhetorical technique (that is, it may succeed in persuading people) but it carries little or no real evidential weight, because the opponent's actual argument has not been refuted.

Its name is derived from the practice of using straw men in combat training. In such training, a scarecrow is made in the image of the enemy with the single intent of attacking it. Such a target is, naturally, immobile and does not fight back, and is not as realistic to test skill against compared to a live and armed opponent. It is occasionally called a straw person argument, straw dog fallacy, scarecrow argument, or wooden dummy argument.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Straw_man



</answer>

<answer>



Knowing an answer is not necessarily a good thing. If people knew the answer then there would be no need for Faith. All religions have tried to answer this question, accepting their answers is where Faith is needed. Suppose for instance we could prove God, the afterlife or eternity of spirit, through a mathematical proof. Well then high level math experts would be able to see the truth, but us layman would still have to accept on faith what they deduced. The same is true of  religious people. They must accept on faith what their prophets say. Whether Jesus, Buddha or Mohammed, The masses still have to accept  on faith what these prophets have seen.  About %90 of the world population believes in some sort of afterlife so each man must answer the question for himself. We never truly know anything, we just have a strong probability of truth in all things.

<answer>



Your assuming know one knows, but there are souls in the world that do know, only they find humanity not to their liking and stay at a distance working on higher planes to help with preserving creation. You can go to India, where they live mostly, and try to find them. They are at different levels of knowing. There are always 5 perfect masters, or God realized beings who are both conscious of God and the illusory world in which we live, but you would have a hard time finding them. It's more that they will find you when you're ready. I knew of THE perfect master, or the Messiah, who had this to say about creation.

This is a synopsis of a book entitled "God Speaks." The book was written in 1955 by Meher Baba and explains the meaning of life.

Life is a journey that God is traveling.

The first phase of God's journey is evolution. It is initiated from a totally unconscious God as if an infinite Ocean of Knowledge, Power and Bliss were in a state likened to deep sleep. This unconscious God speaks the First Word "Who am I?". This question disrupts the limitless, undivided, absolute vacuum, and its reverberations create individualized souls, compared to drops or bubbles within the Ocean. By speaking the First Word, God establishes the process of Creation, in which he assumes evolving forms to gain increasing consciousness.



Individuality is the vehicle of this quest. Evolution marks a series of temporary answers to "Who am I?" The soul traverses a multitude of forms, beginning with simples gases and proceeding slowly through inanimate stone and mineral forms. These early evolutionary stages obviously have only the most rudimentary consciousness and cannot provide a satisfactory answer to God's original question.



The original query thus provides a continuing momentum for the drop soul to develop new forms each with greater consciousness, including the many plant and animal beings. Every evolutionary kingdom reveals new dimensions of consciousness and experience. Each also offers opportunities to gain different kinds of awareness. For example, when the soul identifies itself with varied species of fish, it experiences the world as a creature living in water conversely, as a bird, it enriches its consciousness by flying through air.



When the drop soul finally evolves to human form, consciousness is fully developed, but an individual is still not aware of the potential of his or her consciousness.



So the original "Who am I?" imperative persists and inaugurates the second phase: reincarnation. Since consciousness is fully developed, there is no longer a need for evolving new forms. The individual's experience, gathered in early stages of evolution, is now humanized and expressed in countless lifetimes. The impulses gained in sub-human forms can play themselves out in the broader context of intelligence, emotions, choices, diverse setting and interactions with people.



But obviously no single lifetime can bear the burden of "humanizing" the entire evolutionary inheritance randomly or simultaneously. There must be a method for re-experiencing the pre-human legacy in manageable segments. The soul thus experiences alternately a series of opposites, organized according to themes. Accordingly, in different lives, the soul becomes male and female, rich and poor, vigorous and weak, beautiful and ugly. Through exploring the potential of these many opposites, one eventually exhausts all possible human identities and, therefore, has fully learned the entire range of human experience.



Here begins the third phase: involution, the process by which the soul returns to the full awareness of the Divine Force, which created him. As Meher Baba puts it, "When the consciousness of the soul is ripe for disentanglement from the gross world (the everyday world of matter and forms), it enters the spiritual path and turns inward."



Like evolution, involution has certain states and stages, consisting of "planes" and "realms." But individuality continues along this spiritual path, and there are as many ways to God as there are souls.

Each new plane denotes a state of being that differs from the states that proceeded it. The first three planes are within the subtle world or domain of energy, "pran." There follows the fourth plane, the threshold of the mental world, where misuse of great power for personal desire can lead to disintegration of consciousness.



The fifth and sixth planes represent true sainthood, which is understood to be increasing intimacy with God as the Beloved. On the sixth plane, the mind itself becomes the inner eye that sees God everywhere and in everything. "The loving of God and the longing for His union," says Meher Baba "is fully demonstrated in the sixth plane of consciousness."



The seventh plane marks true and lasting freedom. Impressions go. Duality goes. The drops burst and again become the Ocean. God answers his question of "Who am I?" with "I am God." The Infinite has returned to the original starting point. He now knows, however, with full consciousness and full awareness that he was, is and always will be infinite with infinite Knowledge, Power and Bliss. And he realizes that the entire journey has been an illusory dream, the purpose of which is the full awakening of his soul.



</answer>

When driving to a friends house out of state(for the first time)I had to follow a map.It led me to an area where it said to turn right at a place 50 miles away from the exit.(it is a very long road) I tried to remember what my friend said it would look like. (it was an unnamed hidden drive) I found it interesting that when I came to about the point he said a road would be I thought,"No, that couldn't be right." (because it isn't at all what I thought it would like) An hour and a half later, I found myself having a sinking feeling in me,"Will I find this, are there any roads not listed in this map?" Only after talking with a local, did I find that I had indeed passed my target many miles back. And all because I dismissed what was in plain sight, only because it didn't fit with what "I" thought it should have been. Never dismiss what is right in front of you, never throw solid instruction aside only because it doesn't "fit" with what you "feel" the truth is, the road I passed, was the correct road, even if it didn't look like it to me.

open4one

Contributing In:



Law & Ethics



</answer from>



<answer>



If you do not have a reason for what you do, you are insane. (Buying a Pet Rock).



If you have a reason, but the actions you take are unrelated to the result you wish to achieve, you are insane. (Buying Carbon Credits)

If the results you wish to achieve do not promote your own self-interest, you are insane. (Committing suicide)

If the actions you take to promote your own interest are performed at the expense of another, you are insane. (Robbing a bank)



</answer>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



Emily S
Member since: 13 April 2008
Total points: 561 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



A Question for Atheists, Agnostics and Believers of any religion



Okay combined group, what's your opinion of Pascal's wager? For those who don't know, Pascal theorized that one should believe in God because if God doesn't exist you never know differently and if He/She does it's like an insurance policy, protecting you from punishments given to non-believers.

Would any Atheist readers be willing to compromise their beliefs to follow this? Would any Agnostics make this their great deciding factor? Finally for the religious followers, do you feel many of your beliefs are due to a "fear" of God, specifically in dealing with punishment? Do you fear hell and thus do you believe?

This question has flaws, I know. I just want people to consider the thought. I'm putting it in the philosophy section as I think it'll reach a far wider, more open-minded audience. My owns beliefs in this don't matter, I'm just looking for yours (if you feel like sharing that is).



Thank you!



</question>



<additional details>



Good point, I suppose I'll pick whichever God or Gods one chooses. Plus I'm sure there would be no way of lying to God if they really were all-knowing, yet it's a wager, lie or make yourself believe in order to receive potential reward. It's all a bit sticky.



Plus thanks for your answer, I understand it's a silly question, I just thought I'd put the thought out into the world and see what others thought. Thanks!



Plus thanks for your answer, I understand it's a silly question, I just thought I'd put the thought out into the world and see the response. Thanks!



</additional details>

pɹɵpħɚɫ

<answer>



Which god do you suppose this wager should apply to? All gods or just one? How do you know if you pick the right one?

Assuming god is omniscient, wouldn't he/she/it know you're only "believing" to avoid hell. Can someone truly believe in something solely on the basis of 'just in case'?

Who says god rewards believers with heaven and non-believers with hell anyway?

No I would not be willing to alter my beliefs based on Pascals Wager, and I hope no one else would either. In my opinion, it really is a silly argument.



Source(s):



Atheist



</answer>

<answer>



I will state I am Agnostic and no Pascal's wager is not going to be the deciding factor in my belief. I understand the concept and *some* people do believe in a God because of this reason. Actually, I will tell you I went to church at one time in my life and followed the Christian religion and I will say the pastor sat up on stage and said this exact same scenario. He said and I quote “I am sure going to believe it if gets me to heaven”.  Looking back on it I wonder if his belief was really because he believed in what he preached or if the root of it was fear.



I have a belief that if God existed (and as Agnostic I cannot confirm or deny) and if he created me in his image, then why would I be damned to hell for using my intelligence and reason to pursue truth? I can give an example of this, such as, say with my 10 year old son. Say I tell him a certain *fact* in life and because it came from me he is to believe it without other inquiry and research. I cannot feel any less of him if he decides to use his intelligence and reason and actually look for other substantial probability to support what I told him is fact. Actually, instead I would be proud of him and that is because it would show his independence and the fact that he used intelligence to seek fact and probability to support what I have told him.



In the end if there is a God I just cannot fathom that he would punish me for using my intelligence to inquire and seek truth.



</answer>

<answer>



Regarding Pascal's wager, I would put it this way.  Saying you believe, and going through the motions, does not make one believe.  If there really is a God, according to all I've heard they would be all knowing enough to know I didn't truly believe, and therefore I'd be treated no differently than living a life of openly not believing.  I can't lie to my friends, how am I supposed to lie to God?  Basically, you can't hedge your bets when it comes to faith.



</answer>



<answer from>



Spinoza is right
Member since: 05 May 2008
Total points: 1206 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Pascal's Wager is a fruitless attempt to convince people to believe in the Judeo-Christian.  The problem is that you insert the name of any deity and make the same argument.

For example:

1.  One does not know whether Krishna exists. 
2.  Not believing in Krishna is bad for one's eternal soul if Krishna does exist. 
3.  Believing in Krishna is of no consequence if Krishna does not exist. 
4.  Therefore it is in one's interest to believe in Krishna.



</answer>



<answer from>



dr.kwack
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 1376 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



No.
I don't believe in God's words. I don't believe in his teachings. And if "God" would disown me because I'm trying to live my life in a way I see fit and humble and modest while accepting someone over me that doesn't really believe but is banking on pretending to, I wouldn't want to follow him anyway. Besides, if "God" were all knowing, he would know the person didn't believe in him anyway.

People always ask "is God real" but the real question is if I would want to follow him if he was.
*edit*
and if people truly believed in God, they wouldn't need a present at the end of their lives to convince them to continue believing.



</answer>

mtheoryr...

Total points: 9816 (Level 5)

<answer>



I actually subscribe to a personal variation of Pascal's wager. Where it is reasonable to assume that if god is the creator of the universe and the universe appears to be rational, then it is likely the case that god is a rational agent and in all probability would expect me to utilize my intellect and reasoning abilities to pursue ethical and moral standards, not to irrationally gamble on the odds of a particular religious morality as being the one of which god approves above all others.
Further that as a rational god he would not approve of any religion that does not base itself firmly upon reason and intelligence.
Nor would he expect me to profess his existence where I am unable to reasonably assert that this conclusion is absolutely valid.
Thus to live as though god exists is to rely upon rational thought, intellect and the power of reason.
Pascal had the right idea but he seemed to ignore that if god created the universe then there are some things we can reason about god by extension based upon knowledge of how the universe exists as an example of the works of the infinite agent.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 14 May 2007

<answer>



I think you've slightly misunderstood the wager, which doesn't say you have to believe in God, just to ACT as if there were one (any one).  After all, it isn't possible to just believe something merely by thinking it, because you would still know that there is no evidence, let alone proof, and you wouldn't really believe at all.

The question still remains about what acting as if there were a god actually means.  Constant lifelong worshipping and praying or devotion to making the lives of others better?

In the UK satirical/comedy magazine/comic VIZ this month there is a brilliant spoof letter, something along the lines of "'Acts of God' include things like hurricanes and Earthquakes, while 'playing God' usually means doing things like saving people's lives, yet stupid religious people are always trying to stop the latter."  Food for thought.

p.s. I am Dawkinsist when it comes to religion.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viz_%28comi...



</answer>

<answer from>



Alan Turing
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 5404 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Certainty is a difficult issue in philosophy.  Norman Malcolm wrote a book on it looking at certainty from Wittgenstein's point of view.



The object of philosophy is not certainty.  Instead it attempts to eliminate absurdity, nonsense, and silly things that people say and think.  It tries to show the contradictions that some things that people are sure of result in.

People like to be sure of things.  The more ignorant a person is the more they desire certainty.  That sets them up for becoming believers, who think they have absolute certainty and are very sure of their faith.

Yet the closer you are to certainly, the further you are from truth.



</answer>



<answer from>



thedrama...
Member since: 27 February 2006
Total points: 1486 (Level 3)

<question from>



Third P
Member since: 03 July 2007
Total points: 16905 (Level 6)



Contributing In:

</question from>



<question>



"Be honest" - but what is honesty?



Does honesty compel you to turn the one penny or coin too much change that the cashier-clerk has given you, even if doing so means driving back several kilometers or miles to the town where the purchase was made?

Thanks for sharing your thoughts. Have a great day!



</question>



<answer from>



small
Member since: 21 September 2006
Total points: 32215 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Good question!!

My answer is ... yes. Honesty is absolute and not relative.... whether it is a penny or a pound does not matter. And also the cost to maintain honesty can never be treated as too much.

That is the concept of honesty.... no wonder we practical people find it very difficult to be totally honest...... sometimes honesty looks like absence of common sense and at times, wisdom can dictate otherwise, for instance, if telling the honest truth is going to harm the person too much psychologically!!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Good answer. Thanks!



</asker's comment>

JoJo27

<answer>



Honesty
1.  moral uprightness: the quality, condition, or characteristic of being fair, truthful, and morally upright



2.  truthfulness: truthfulness, candor, or sincerity 
Example: "In all honesty, I really didn't know."



</answer>

Lisa S
Member since: 01 April 2008
Total points: 246 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Honesty is telling the truth. 
Honesty is straightforward conduct. 
Honesty is being sincere, truthful, trustworthy, honorable, fair, genuine, and loyal with integrity.
Accept responsibility for your own actions; don't blame others. 
Be honest about your feelings. 
Face issues as they arise. 
If you are considering lying, try to think of the consequences. 
When confronted with a situation, think of others. 
Honesty is the human quality of communicating and acting truthfully related to truth as a value. This includes listening, and any action in the human repertoire — as well as speaking.

Superficially, honesty means simply stating facts and views as best one truly believes them to be. It includes both honesty to others, and to oneself (see: self-deception) and about one's own motives and inner reality. Honesty, at times, has the ability to cause misfortune to the person who displays it.
Honesty means 
there are no 
contradictions or 
discrepancies in 
thoughts, words, or 
actions. To be honest 
to one’s real self and 
to the purpose of a 
task earns trust and 
inspires faith 
in others. Honesty is 
never to misuse that 
which is given in 
trust. 
honesty is a clear conscience "before myself and before my fellow human beings." Honesty is the awareness of what is right and appropriate in one’s role, one’s behavior, and one relationship. With honesty, there is no hypocrisy or artificiality which create confusion and mistrust in the minds and lives of others. Honesty makes for a life of integrity because the inner and outer selves are a mirror image.



Honesty is to speak that which is thought and to do that which is spoken. There are no contradictions or discrepancies in thoughts, words, or actions. Such integration provides clarity and example to others. To have one form internally and another form externally creates barriers and can cause damage, since one would neither be able to come close to anyone else, nor would others want to be close. Some think, "I am honest, but no one understands me." That is not honest. Honesty is as distinct as a flawless diamond which can never remain hidden. The worth is visible in one’s actions



</answer>

<answer>



If you drove miles back to a store just to return a penny then you'd be a fool my friend! Far better to pop the extra money in a charity box if your conscience is giving you gyp. Being honest is about personal integrity. Doing what you morality and conscience say is "right" "fair" and "just". Honesty with bluntness or malicious intent is no better than out right manipulation or bare faced lies. You have to have empathy and take other peoples (potential) reaction into account. People who say - I am telling you this for your own good; are never telling you anything you need to hear, its for spite, not your own good. Think before you speak and you shall never go wrong. Do or say things with a good heart and you know you are doing the best you can.



</answer>

Jim D
Member since: 13 June 2007
Total points: 12520 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Why not call honesty...the truth as you know it?

We may not actually know the raw truth but if we deliver the truth, as we know it, we are essentially honest, we may just be wrong.

On the coin, I would not drive miles back to return a small amount of change and if I knew that I would again visit a place, I would wait until my next visit to settle up.

I remember an occasion, years ago, in Frankfurt a Main having lunch with a friend and co-worker, we, somehow, left the restaurant without paying and no one stopped us. A couple of hours later I realized that I had not paid. I asked Chuck if he had and he said no. We were across town at the time and returned to pay the check; the manager was profusely appreciative and said that the waitress would be as well since, the amount would have been deducted from her next check.

n this case, not to have returned to pay would have caused a hardship to an innocent person and frankly, would have been...theft by taking.

I believe, all of us are obligated to be as honest with ourselves as our personality can stand and to apply this standard to our dealings with others.

I believe I do this,,,and I hope I'm being honest here!  lol



</answer>



<answer from>



Ben

<answer>



Honesty is to say what people want to hear.
Not necessarily that it should be true.



And honesty does not have to compel us to struggle that much to return a change of that size to prove that it is flawless.

Psyengin...

</answer from>



<answer>



It may also (and) mean to communicate your value judgment not to drive back to return the surplus difference of the calculation error but to mail it. It could also mean to drive back to return it when it suits your schedule. Rendering a judgment concerning values in consequence can not be and should not be assumed universal as that presumes competence where it is not and incompetence where competency for it actually exists, independent thought.



</answer>



<answer from>



Graham P
Member since: 13 May 2007
Total points: 3375 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Honesty is acting in a way as to not hide your true beliefs.

If you are given too much change hiding the fact would likely be dishonest.



A wider definition of dishonesty would be to act as if every action you made was open for all to see.



By  both definitions stealing money would be considered dishonest.

If you accidently act unfairly you should perhaps try to remedy the situation if you want a clear conscience. Gaining from such mistakes is considered by some to be wrong and donating the money to charity might be one way of avoiding gaining from an honest mistake.



Ringing up the person and appologizing, and asking what should be done might be in order if you want to avoid being dishonest.

If you don't care about whether you are dishonest then you can try to intellectualize the issue away but your whole thinking might go down a slippery slide to a way of thinking that turns you into someone you currently would not want to be.



</answer>

<question from>



meep meep
Member since: 11 March 2007
Total points: 29705 (Level 7)



</question from>



<question>



Is it better to start with no hope, or have hope and be let down?



I guess there's always a risk you take when you hope for something. So do you perfer to have no hope and just let it be, or do you hope and run the risk of being completely crushed?



</question>



<answer from>



Persephone! hates trolls
Member since: 14 July 2007
Total points: 16306 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think to have hope and be let down. Let's face it, that will happen to all of us at some point in our lives. To have no hope at all, seems very bleak.



I don't know that anyone can truly give up all hope. I think that somewhere deep inside we always have a tiny bit of that hope squirreled away . Sometimes we just hide it a little too well.



When you totally lose hope , you give up on life .



</answer>

<answer>



Optimism never truly lets you down. If you get your hopes up and something doesn't work out for you, then that is disappointing. However, the happiness, joy, and lack of stress that you get from being an optimistic person in general is far more rewarding than being the type of person who is always pessimistic. Those people, by nature, cannot ever be truly as happy or calm.



</answer>

<answer>



I guess neither. I hope a lot and usually get crushed. I think it's possible to take pleasure, satisfaction, and happiness from little sunshine moments during the day. Rather than anxiously hoping, place your faith in yourself and open up to the possibility of getting what you want or what you want done. Open up and let success floe like a little stream through you. When you try to stop the stream, your prize becomes routine, nothing special. your success becomes a habit. Prize each little sunshine jewel of a moment, knowing it can never be repeated exactly so.



</answer>

<question>



What did Marx think of homosexuality?



only answer if you know - else you may be reported
thanks



</question>



<answer from>

<answer from>



RED*
Member since: 20 February 2008
Total points: 30841 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



...he didn't tell anybody...he just did away with it...



</answer>



<answer from>



Amustaph...
Member since: 08 July 2007
Total points: 3708 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



He is not explicit.  You should read Engels' work, 'The Family, the State and Private Property', which portrays the nuclear family as being part of bourgeois society.  Extrapolating this, some Marxists say that homosexuality is a human aberration caused by the nuclear family and will die out in a socialist society.  Others say that homophobia is an aberration caused by bourgeois ideology.  In no societies has homosexuality been promoted as it is in the West today, so it is hard to find historical precedent.  My own view is that today's tolerance arises from the class struggles of the 1970s and was seen as a way to divide the labour movement, along with feminism, environmentalism, and all that other middle class tosh.



</answer>



<answer from>



Charles
Member since: 06 August 2008
Total points: 291 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Karl Marx collaborated with Frederick Engels on the Communist Manifesto, and were both known to be prejudice against homosexuals.



Source(s):



Karl Marx's Social and Political Thought by Bob Jessop and Russell Wheatley.



</answer>

Marx was a political thinker.He has not written anything explicitly about sex.Marx saw the feudal serf/land lords enjoying polygamy and lavish sex life.Yet he did not react to the sex factor in feudal system.It can be concluded that homosexuality was not an issue in his times.

<question from>



smileatl...
Member since: 04 June 2007
Total points: 159 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



When one considers the 'physics of biological existence' all existence is the effect of blind cell activity ?



With the whole of the sensation of existence an effect of blind cell activity then there isn't a moment after 'now-moment-continuum' as the so-called past and there isn't a moment before now-moment-continuum as the so-called future. All sensations of existence is the effect of relentless emergence as blind brain cell activity



</question>



<answer from>



Alan Turing
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 6006 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



You are getting confused because you don't understand that aggregate behavior can create higher levels of behavior that can be useful and have meaning.

For example, if I examined the random behavior of gas molecules I could not predict the concept of pressure, which is the statistical aggregate behavior of those molecules.  And if you just stayed at the level of the pressure you could not understand the concept of the steam engine or of the internal combustion engine.  If you just stayed at the level of engines you could not understand the concept of NASCAR races.  Get the idea?



</answer>



<answer from>



Carl J
Member since: 02 August 2008
Total points: 585 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not really, you overlook too much.



</answer>



<answer from>



JORGE N
Member since: 10 December 2006
Total points: 5173 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is easy to desintegrate the individual social being into some one or more of its more complex specifics such as that of considering it to be a carbon intelligence system whose most complex of activities is the quantum particle activities and that is all.  You could be correct.  No one really knows to what extent we are as real physical activity.  Those "now-moment --continuum's" could be higher coordinated periodicity and evidence shows that indeed it is.  But the reflective parts that must ideate into objective delineation of all pertinent phenomenon and are responsible for the determinations as to how this particular being is going to insert himself or herself in reality objectively enough to maintain the homeostasis of the individual social being.



</answer>

I stood there on stage, one of the teachers announced me as the "new champion" and everyone clapped for me.  My class gave me a standing ovation.

I was really happy and it didn't have a down side.  That was the one most purely happy moment of my life.

<question>



What is the Meaning of Life?



Why are we all here and what is our purpose in the universe?

An Alien experiment?

The result of a higher power?

Millions of years of science and evolution, here to continue the human race?

What do you all think - honest, open topic on the most famous question!



</question>



<answer from>



Jonny Napalm
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 238 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Life is an accident. People are no more than slightly advanced animals. Those with higher moral values are more human. Those with lesser moral values are more animal. Our purpose is to exist until we die. The end is final.



</answer>

<answer from>



Jayarama...
Member since: 17 May 2007
Total points: 33194 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



The philosophical question "What is the meaning of life?" means different things to different people. The vagueness of the query is inherent in the word "meaning", which opens the question to many interpretations, such as: "What is the origin of life?", "What is the nature of life (and of the universe in which we live)?", "What is the significance of life?", "What is valuable in life?", and "What is the purpose of, or in, (one's) life?". These questions have resulted in a wide range of competing answers and arguments, from scientific theories, to philosophical, theological, and spiritual explanations.

These questions are separate from the scientific issue of the boundary between things with life and inanimate objects.
Popular beliefs
"What is the meaning of life?" is a question many people ask themselves at some point during their lives, most in the context "What is the purpose of life?" Here are some of the many potential answers to this perplexing question. The responses are shown to overlap in many ways but may be grouped into the following categories:

Survival and temporal success
...to live every day like it is your last and to do your best at everything that comes before you
...to be always satisfied
...to live, go to school, work, and die
...to participate in natural human evolution, or to contribute to the gene pool of the human race
...to advance technological evolution, or to actively develop the future of intelligent life
...to compete or co-operate with others
...to destroy others who harm you, or to practice nonviolence and nonresistance
...to gain and exercise power
...to leave a legacy, such as a work of art or a book
...to eat
...to prepare for death
...to spend life in the pursuit of happiness, maybe not to obtain it, but to pursue it relentlessly.
...to produce offspring through sexual reproduction (alike to participating in evolution)
...to protect and preserve one's kin, clan, or tribe (akin to participating in evolution)
...to seek freedom, either physically, mentally or financially
...to observe the ultimate fate of humanity to the furthest possible extent
...to seek happiness and flourish, experience pleasure or celebrate
...to survive, including the pursuit of immortality through scientific means
...to attempt to have many sexual conquests (as in Arthur Schopenhauer's will to procreate)
...to find and take over all free space in this "game" called life
...to seek and find beauty
...to kill or be killed
...No point. Since having a point is a condition of living human consciousness. Animals do not need a point to live or exist. It is more of an affliction of consciousness that there are such things as points, a negative side to evolutionary development for lack of better words.

Wisdom and knowledge
...to master and know everything
...to be without questions, or to keep asking questions
...to expand one's perception of the world
...to explore, to expand beyond our frontiers
...to learn from one's own and others' mistakes
...to seek truth, knowledge, understanding, or wisdom
...to understand and be mindful of creation or the cosmos
...to lead the world towards a desired situation
...to satisfy the natural curiosity felt by humans about life

Ethical
...to express compassion
...to follow the "Golden Rule"
...to give and receive love
...to work for justice and freedom
...to live in peace with yourself and each other, and in harmony with our natural environment
...to protect humanity, or more generally the environment
...to serve others, or do good deeds

Religious and spiritual
...to find perfect love and a complete expression of one's humanness in a relationship with God
...to achieve a supernatural connection within the natural context
...to achieve enlightenment and inner peace
...to become like God, or divine
...to glorify God
...to experience personal justice (i.e. to be rewarded for goodness)
...to experience existence from an infinite number of perspectives in order to expand the consciousness of all there is (i.e. to seek objectivity)
...to be a filter of creation between heaven and hell
...to produce useful structure in the universe over and above consumption (see net creativity)
...to reach Heaven in the afterlife
...to seek and acquire virtue, to live a virtuous life
...to turn fear into joy at a constant rate achieving on literal and metaphorical levels: immortality, enlightenment, and atonement
...to understand and follow the "Word of God"
...to discover who you are
...to resolve all problems that one faces, or to ignore them and attempt to fully continue life without them, or to detach oneself from all problems faced

Philosophical
...to give life meaning
...to participate in the chain of events which has led from the creation of the universe until its possible end (either freely chosen or determined, this is a subject widely debated amongst philosophers)
...to know the meaning of life
...to achieve self-actualisation
...all possible meanings have some validity
...life in itself has no meaning, for its purpose is an opportunity to create that meaning, therefore:
...to die
...to simply live until one dies (there is no universal or celestial purpose)
...nature taking its course (the wheel of time keeps on turning)
...whatever you see you see, as in "projection makes perception"
...there is no purpose or meaning whatsoever
...life may actually not exist, or may be illusory )
...to contemplate "the meaning of the end of life"

Other
...to contribute to collective meaning ("we" or "us") without having individual meaning ("I" or "me")
...to find a purpose, a "reason" for living that hopefully raises the quality of one's experience of life, or even life in general
...to participate in the inevitable increase in entropy of the universe
...to make conformists' lives miserable
...to make life as difficult as possible for others (i.e. to compete)-



Source(s):



-



</answer>

<answer>



The mentioning of the end of time in the Bible is to me nonsense which is out of touch with reality. I'm not saying that this world won't at some time in the future come to an end.

We develop concepts about everything of which we are aware. That does not mean that our perception and hence the concept are accurate. The dictionary defines eternity as beginningless and endless time. Anything which does not have a beginning cannot cease to exist. But time is not physical because it is not spatial. It is the constant duration of the eternal now. But there is no past to go to and the future does not yet exist. Yet, there will be a future "now" because the now is not anything physical and therefore cannot cease to exist. All of the ways in which we have to measure time, such as clocks, are actually movements within space (even if it is an atomic clock, it is based on physical changes) which we intuitively along with our nervous system seem to move in consistently regular movements. But those movements are actually changes within time and not time itself. Even if there were no physical movements (changes), the continuation of a perfectly still universe would be during a time period. There just wouldn't be any way to measure that amount of time, because the only way we have of measuring time is anywhere from years (the revolutions of the earth around the sun) to the method of measuring time with an atomic clock (see: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atomic_cloc... where it is the movement of radiation which is used.



</answer>

<answer>



The nature of time cannot be contemplated without the physicality of its existence. I for instance would not know what time is, or, if there is anything in existence as time, if I would not have experienced its reality though all things subjected to changes and modifications in time. It seems clear enough at least in human perception that if there is no matter there would be no time, that time perhaps was created alongside the creation of all other things of the universe, as their common characteristic, or a governing principle for progression and change. I think that the thought that time is fallacious. I think time is just as much a reality in the existence of everything as matter is. There would be nothing in place without their specific physical forms, and there would be no thought or a human concept either without the facility of human physical brain to formulate, contain and process.

Then there is purely imaginative side to the matter of your question, as I may ask what if there is no time, as it has just ended? Then I can imagine that it would not matter indeed as there would be no way to realise that it has happened ever. Then from here we enter  into the wild world of metaphysical possibilities and wonder as what a world could be without time, without things changing in time, a world of pure reality perhaps where imaging would be creating, and thinking doing, a world where one could bring into existence entire universes with faith and then destroy them all through doubt. I see then that time is not only the concept but the concept of concepts, if we choose to look at it this way. Time is the reason of the world of matter and of things. It is what we have common with the nature of all things in the world. We can have our timeless concepts that we can conceive, develop and modify in an instant what can be so powerful as to change the nature of our world, where time in unchanging, constant and real, it is the nature the world.



</answer>

<question>



If a tree falls in the forest and no one is there to hear it, does it really make a sound?



</question>



<answer from>



KevinL
Member since: 15 February 2008
Total points: 189 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If someone punches you in the face when you're not looking, will it still hurt?



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>



<answer from>



dr.kwack
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 1376 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



This question is not supposed to be literal.
The point is if it isn't heard, does it matter?
If it effects no one or nothing else, did it happen?



</answer>



<answer from>



MichaelM...
Member since: 22 February 2008
Total points: 1084 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, but it does not make a noise.

Sound is objective, it is a wave of air and that wave can influence other things (say the flight of a butterfly) which can in turn influence still other things, and infinite pattern deriving from a single source.

A noise, however, is subjective and whether something is or is not noisy is entirely at the descretion of the listener.  No listener, no decision, no noise.



</answer>



<answer from>



Dr Lecter
Member since: 30 July 2008
Total points: 225 (Level 1)



</answer from>

</answer>

<answer>



Yes it does, whether you hear it or not, whether it affects anyone or not, whether it is recorded or not, or even if a human being never ever finds the fallen tree it still makes a sound. 
It has to, it lives on the same planet you and I and all the other animals with any sense of hearing. We hear because we are in an atmosphere that allows sound to travel regardless of who or what hears it. We know this happens because when you mother tells you to do something you "hear her". If you can hear her on this planet it's because of the atmosphere we have that actually allows sounds to be made, and travel. If that works where we are then you can be sure that it will work in the uninhabited part of the world as well.



</answer>

<answer from>



Madison C
Member since: 23 May 2008
Total points: 114 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I needed to get this out:

"If I shout 'I' at the heart of the world, and no one hears me, does it matter?"

What that question is is that of existence, not of logic. Kind of a paradox, if you will. Let's look at it this way:

The world was created by mankind. The world itself is desolate if it is not acknowledged by man. A species of animal never discovered does not exist if it's existence is not acknowledged. The universe would not exist if not seen by man. I exist, am heard, therefore I am.

Sound a little self-centered? Yes, but that's the root of the question. If we do not know about something, does it exist? If a boat sinks in the ocean and no survivors are around to tell the tale, has it ever happened? Would events in history exist if they were not written down and remembered?



And another quote:

"To see something is to acknowledge it's existence. Once that has happened it is recognized, therefore it now exists."

Things that we have no knowledge of happen all the time. Yet if no one witnessed these events, did they truthfully happen? If an animal species that is undiscovered dies out, then have they truly existed?



That is the tree question. If a tree falls and man did not hear it, therefore did not recognize it's existence, did it make a sound? No, because if it's existence is not recognized then it is not remembered. Events can occur, but if no one is there to witness them they did not happen.

However, this question has been around for quite a while. I think the tree that didn't make a sound is forever remembered, then.



Source(s):



Slightly embarrassing, but Kyon from The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya and a character from a book series that I can't place the name of.



</answer>

<question>



Is it true that the more a person knows the more intolerant they become?



Is knowledge breeding intolerance?



</question>



<answer from>



Kynysca
Member since: 09 October 2007
Total points: 2082 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



No, ignorance breeds intolerance. Experience and knowledge does just the opposite. Bigotry, which stems from ignorance, by very definition, makes reference to those who are intolerant of opinions, lifestyles, or identities that differ from one's own. So, perhaps, only thinking one "knows" breeds intolerance.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Fundamentally true. But some people believe that once they have enough knowledge that their problems will be solved. That isn't what happens. Some amount of ignorance is always present. Chaos is always a factor, and knowledge is insufficient. Does one embrace chaos or reject it? How does one use it?



</asker's comment>



<comments>



sassychi...



Some degree of chaos is present, even in the brain. The problem with knowledge is that it is difficult to come out ahead if one is accumulating knowledge for it's own sake. If I answer every question on jeapardy, do I really come out ahead? No. It is about how one uses the information.



sassychi...



As for reality, it is too big to take. In the words of George Harrison, "It's all too much for me to take.."

Relationships also involve people not knowing the other person fully. The lament, "Nobody understands me" is always true. Wisdom accepts other people without understanding them completely.



sassychi...



Can people be happy knowing that they are somewhat ignorant? Surely, many people condemn ignorance while being ignorant themselves. If a person is always intolerant of ignorance,such people are always in pain, since some ignorance is inevitable.



</comments>

<question from>



hullabal...

<question>

</question>

<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Infinity in "ordinary" usage is generally considered to be an extension of the sequence of "ordinary numbers". Infinity is not a number itself, and can't really be treated as one. So you can't define Inf.+1 or 2 x Inf., meaning that you can't sensibly talk about Infinity+1 being greater than Infinity.

However, as Andrew E remarks, the mathematician Cantor found some remarkable properties about the different possible kinds of Infinity, which can in some sense be compared for "size".

The first kind of infinity is the "countably infinite" kind. This is fairly easy to recognise. For example, the natural numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, etc are countably infinite. So, too, are the even numbers 2, 4, 6, 8, and so  on.  By "countably infinite" is meant that you can label each one in turn by a number, without missing any out or running out of label numbers.  Hence

Even numbers: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10,
Counted as.....: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, ...

In this way, you can label each even number with a "natural" number, and however far you go, you can always do this. There's never an even number you find between two adjacent numbers that you can't label, or count, in this way.

There are infinitely many even numbers, but infinitely many natural numbers, and though intuitively you might think there are more natural numbers than even numbers, the "size" is the same - infinite.

You can also do this "counting" with fractions, of the form a/b, for example, 1/2, 2/3, 2/4. 3/4, and so on. It is possible to construct a scheme for labelling every fractional number with a natural number, without missing any out. I won't do it here, but it's easy enough to find this on the web.

However, you can't do with with the set of all decimal numbers, that is, numbers of the form 3.14159265... or 1.33333 and so on. It can be shown that if you try to create a labelling scheme to account for all decimal numbers, it's possible to construct a new decimal number between any two others that cannot be labelled by a natural number. It sounds complicated, and in truth it requires a bit of familiarity with number theory to grasp it, but it shows that there is a new kind of infinity, called (naturally enough) "uncountably infinite", which is larger than the "countably infinite" kind.



This is the sort of stuff that Cantor worked on.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Infinity's just infinity. It means it goes on and on. You can't add one etc



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



The answer is hinted at in Andrew E's first sentence of the second paragraph.



Taking not only any finite number of things from infinity, but also taking an infinity any infinite number of times from it leaves infinity. To illustrate: there is a line with an infinite number of, say, beads strewn all over it. Somebody is allocated ,say,every tenth bead, somebody else every hundreth, still another every thousandth, and so on to infinity. All will have an infinite number of beads, because, in all cases, since the line is infinite, there will be no end to the process of the distribution of the beads, this leaving  the non-allocated beads also infinite.



We can apply mathematical- and philosophical-sounding phrases like: Infinity less Infinity equals Infinity, a fraction of Infinity is equal to Infinity and taking away the Infinite from the Infinite, the remainder is Infinite. l



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



This question was answered in 1886 by Georg Cantor, who in the process of laying the foundations of Set Theory, also answered many questions about infinity.

Infinity is when there is so many of something that taking any finite number of things away from it (or adding any finite number of things to it) will not change its size.  So infinity is the exact same size as infinity plus one.  Furthermore, infinity multiplied by infinity is also the same size as infinity, so the answer to your question is that all the options you listed are the exact same size.

However, there is more than one size infinity.  In fact, there are an infinite number of infinities.  The smallest infinity is called the "countably infinite", such as the number of integers.  We don't know what the next one is, but it is uncountable.  Cantor hypothesized that the next size was 2 to the power of infinity, but we have since learned that whatever the order of infinities is, we can never know it.  Cantor's Hypothesis was proved to be unprovable by Godel and Cohen in the early 20th century.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>

</answer from>



<answer>



Infinity, always 1 in front of you, no returns!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Infinity is not a number, so you can't add one to it or have an infinity of infinities.  Nor is there any such thing as "an infinity"; that is, it's not a thing.  One could say that infinity is the lack of finiteness, lack of boundaries, though that's not a very good definition either.  It's the emptiness that allows us to perceive something finite.  Finite/infinity go together like solid/space or sound/silence.  We can't imagine or perceive solid without reference to space or space without reference to solid.  Likewise we can't imagine a finite number without reference to infinity.  This is harder to see because it's more abstract, but I think it's true.  And we can only seem to imagine infinity in terms of finite numbers--which leads us to notions such as infinity plus one.  That's really just imagining a very high number and adding one to it.



</answer>






<original file>index;_ylt=AtGmfgwDfWOLAbcugoMvPH8gBgxa5d3.html</original file>

<question from>



g3pasamb...
Member since: 03 July 2007
Total points: 16641 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</question from>



<question>



Do you  agree that human desires are frustrating?



Thanks for sharing your thoughts. Have a great day!



</question>



<answer from>



simplyun...
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 10874 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Human desires I do not think are frustrating automatically, they could however be had in frustrating circumstances. There is time and place for each and everything for it to be of some good to the mind, and this is particularly true in case of desires. Desire I understand are the longings and yearning of our physical being that are made visible in face of some material gains. Desires denote our tendencies of a exuberant self, they signify our need to have something beyond the limits of our natural needs.

Then desires I see are in the mind just the way our dreams, ambitions and aspirations are, but desires have an earthly ring to their sound, if they are borne out of earth, the physical world, and as if they are good only for the physical world that they are borne out of. Where dreams can be heavenly, aspirations can be had highly, and ambitions for a better the purposes of a life overall, it is as if desires have nothing to do with what we dream, aspire or yearn to be, that they desire have a sole purpose of making us happy, us, for wherever, and whichever way we might be at a time. Desires are always homely with our current state of being. One could be in miserable and still nurture pleasing desires that would do nothing to eliminate misery.



Then this may be the reason desires are known to impede our way to a better, nobler and greater life. Where our dreams and ambitions might inspire us to forebear, to work hard, to overcome and sacrifice lowly delights, natural urges and desires might cause us to lose sight of our high objectives, for the purpose of instant gratification and momentary relief, if I must say so. We have desire to feel right and in control all the time for instance, where our endeavours of our faith and long-term enterprises of a career improvement might demand of us to go through longer periods of doubt, whereby our faith and resolves is tested, our desires might put us in need for constant assurance and reassurance in life.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Well said my friend. Thanks.



</asker's comment>

greed is the source of all misery...

<question from>



Global Geezer
Member since: 29 May 2006

</question from>



<question>



What spiritual things did you learn from a difficult phase of your life?



It could be a phase of unemployment, illness, depression, bereavement, poverty, unhappiness and so on.

Everything in our lives has something to teach us, and within every so-called 'disaster' there is treasure to be found.



What did these times teach you?



</question>



<answer from>



Robin
Member since: 20 June 2006
Total points: 2203 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Last April 2007, my mum who was 78 at the time, was suddenly taken ill. She was diagnosed with pnuemonia, sceptecimia and a perforated lung! We were told that she would not last more than a few days because of her age. In the same week and same ward, two people less than half her age died with only the pnuemonia. After a month in hospital and almost two months in rehabilitation, she came out a bit worse for wear, but very much alive. I personally, have always put it down to the fact that her 2nd great grandchild was born just two months before her illness and my son willed her to get better, watch him grow and be a part of his life. I believe there is always something to keep you going especially where family are concerned. I think my mum is living proof of that. x



Source(s):



Experience.



</answer>



<answer from>



Subcomandante Insurgente Steve
Member since: 23 June 2008
Total points: 2658 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



After getting my heart absolutely shattered by someone I loved, I learned about how time heals all wounds, and that it really is better to have loved and lost than never to have loved at all.



</answer>

shades of Bruno
Member since: 26 December 2006

I learned that there is no good reason to rely on supernatural help, you have to pick yourself up and rely on yourself and to a lesser extent your good friends and family (if your lucky enough to have any) to get through your problems.

I learned that believing in supernatural leaves you open to manipulation by people who don't always have your best interests at heart.



The most important thing I learned that time is a great healer and that even when you think things can never be good again, they will get easier to bare.



</answer>

<question>



What is your concept of happiness?



</question>



<answer from>



Kel
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 2071 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



My concept of happiness is varied. I see happiness as a progress and level. For example, getting a 100% on an exam could get me an 8 in happiness, while the Starbucks latte brings a 4 of happiness. Happiness to me is content. It is seeing my children grow and becoming successful in areas of their life. It is crawling into bed at night after an exhausting day and falling peacefully asleep, accomplishing a goal in my life that I have set for myself, during the moments of highest ecstasy while having sex, seeing a strangers smile, watching a sunset progress till the night sky bursts with stars above my head, learning additional knowledge and adding depth to my character, helping another individual just to see them succeed in life, enjoying the warmth of the sun on my body as I read a thought provoking book. I could continue on in book lengths because happiness surrounds me each day, I just have to be observant and appreciative of when the moment arrives to be aware to enjoying it for what it is.



</answer>

<answer from>



Kelsey
Member since: 21 July 2008
Total points: 1724 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Singles & Dating



</answer from>



<answer>



A simplistic answer might be the opposite of the alternative.



Concepts are a wonderful thing, in a general sense, and with tolerance, acceptance, and some sense of non degrading, modest compromise, we might all find "levels" of happiness. That certainly relates, individually, and might be as much like a Teeter Totter balancing, as anything set in concrete.



I could have just been run over by that bus, as I hurried to school. Is that a happy thing? OR is it more an alert, that I wasn't paying much attention, causing me a moment of unhappiness in my carelessness.



A gambler. Are they conditioned to HAPPY, just when they win, or don't lose? Are they happy if they lose, but don't lose everything? Are they so happy if they win, that they double up, and perhaps again lose it all? Thinking, "No biggie, wasn't "MY" money anyway.



Hmm. Intersting Q.

A.F.



</answer>

<category>



Arts & Humanities

</category>



<question from>

I think religious people will choose the latter.

<answer from>



simplyun...
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 10876 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



There is a small blotch of a shadow in the middle of the picture barely visible in the roughness of an uneven ground. The angle of incident of light in the picture informs us that the shadow is that of the human figure, probably a woman holding a human child in her arms. The shadow, I think, will no longer be there once the drama has reached the finality of its act. I do not think either it is hard to see and realise what impending poignancy is probable to unfold. Whatever it is going to be a moment later, I feel, is more in the way that it is now.



How am I going to deal with this? I am who is weak and vulnerable. I am who is childish and self seeking. I have not yet learnt to see deeper into the proper meaning of things and far enough into the consequences of events. I still need to admit that I become cold, indifferent and senseless in situations, situations that require warmth, courage and compassion. I let things happen to me, and then turn round to blame the world for all its ills. I remain very much in need most of the time, and my deeds are non-productive, they seldom surfeit the wants of my bare necessities. If I am like this through most of the situations of my life then would it not easy for me to be the same here? I think I will be like a child here too, the child.

I therefore prefer to be the child the woman is carrying. Firstly, I hope that the man with the gun would never pull the trigger. I feel I will be saved by the love of the woman, by her unwilling sacrifice of her life, by her being between me and our killer. Then, I hope that the soldier, as that is what he appears to be, would be stopped by his sense of humanity, or by the fear of God, Who will be merciful to me, and I would be left undone.



</answer>

<question from>

Member since: 11 July 2008
