</question from>



<question>



Who created God?



Something can ALWAYS be halved just as it can ALWAYS be doubled - the human mind has a problem comprehending this as to us there is supposedly always a beginning and an end to everything.
To suit this requirement, the primitive mind of humans (which is perpetually looking for answers) accredits their existence to a superior, infinitely knowledgeable creator.

There is always a bigger fish, lets not be so naive that we believe we are second from the top of all the universe.
Remember a few thousand years ago the Earth was flat and we were the only planet with water on? How many times do we need to be proved wrong before we stop putting such blind faith in unproven theories?

If a God exists; Where did this creator come from,what was their motivation, what gave them the inspiration, and who do they look to or worship?



</question>



<additional details>



Irrevocablexenophile I really wouldn't be suprised if you're right!!! It probably was my Mum!



Schtiel12485 - THATS WHY ITS A QUESTION....
Plus God (which for some reason you seem to know is of the male gender (probably because when the bible was writen, men ruled the world) - far more likely to be A-sexual or female) is NOT confirmed (the Bible is not confirmation - how about I right a book about the creators creator; does that give him confirmation NO!) Whether the Creator of a God has been confirmed is not pertinent as there is no confirmation for a God. Completely irrelevent! Dunce!



John W: "Not to be lead by our own understandings but the word of God" SHEEP. Sounds like; Don't follow your own conciousness and opinions, but the word that is written in this book which has been written by men! "The Bible is the word of God I hear you scream" Urgh! There's always an answer isn't there! Tablets from the mountains - bit of an inconvenient place to put them! Not terribly loving or considerate of the Lord Almighty!



"you know" - The only reason I couldn't understand your incredibly complex and obviously factual answer is your lack of correct grammer and punctuation!
Can you not see the hypocritical nature of you reply? I supposedly have the comprehension of a child but the only substanence for this opinion is because it differs from yours. You bellitle me because i believe something different from you. Well if to share the same views as you were to make me as moronic and narrow minded as you seem to be, well then I'm very glad that i don't!
Furthermore to the impropriety of your beloved fallacy, you say that humans are the only species with motivation (thereby proving yourself a complete idiot). Why do you think animals eat - through motivation to survive. How come you can train an animal; due to the motivation of a reward for doing something correctly. And can you please explain to me what an irraTional animal is?
Don't waste my time with you simplistic, narrow-minded, inert veiws.



Most of us are atheists really, we just don't know it yet. The only difference being that I believe in one less god than you!



</additional details>

<answer>



Philosophy question? Theological statements! God is how the primitive perceives natural forces that he cannot control, the sun, the night, stars, the wind, the sea etc. Once the primitive expands their language to include abstract concepts like truth, justice and mercy and also observes the effects of nature on agriculture and housing then these are combined with the elemental forces to create a unit that we refer to as a god (with a small g).



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



I do this all the time. What made us, but what ever made us had to come from somewhere, and then that had to come from somewhere. It goes on and on. Are we actually here? Did any of us ask to be here? (a much used argument) I think that is there is another intelligent being in the universe then we are meant to be here, if not then we are not. You can counter that by saying maybe we are here to multiply and grow, but with everything there is always another deeper reason that involves another thing.

Are we in a never ending spiral of creations, or is it all in a circle with us creating a being which creates a being which creates us, or thus n variation.

What is the meaning of life - and answer not even the "creator" can answer. There is gotta be more than us. We are nothing in the grand scheme but we believe we are everything.



Maybe I have created more questions than answers, but we need to think of the big picture as a whole, not lots of little ones like we do now, with out realising we are doing so.



</answer>

marconpr...

<answer>



There seem to be a huge variety of religious beliefs involving some sort of supreme being, or beings. All these belief systems seem to be trying for a set of processes to "get along" in the world. None seem to offer concrete proof of the supreme being(s)' actual existence, at least, credible to non-believers of that faith. So my "opinion" would be that humans have created supreme beings, in striving for their own betterment - which does not seem like a bad thing, in and of itself. Of course, being flawed humans, we seem to usually use our "faith" to put down others, rather than to get along with them!



Source(s):



History and Observation



</answer>

Nothing is impossible... because wishing is what you make seem impossible. "Oh, I wish I was rich" More importantly, be grateful for what you do have.

If you are suffocating or drowning your going to feel lack of breath.
Grabbing at your throat internally everything shuts down and eventually you slip away.

But death is a mystery,
I know as ive been revived before, that when you die, you can hallucinate and see things that may not really be there, just before you die i mean, you can see things, you arent exactly there its like being in an imagination or a fantasy film or something, its an odd feeling, so many things go into your mind then it all stops and you drift away into blotchy black sight.
But because i was revivied im not too sure if thats counted as death or not.

<answer>



Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary - Cite This Source - Share This 
Ignorance

Ig"no*rance\, n. [F., fr. L. ignorantia.]

1. The condition of being ignorant; the want of knowledge in general, or in relation to a particular subject; the state of being uneducated or uninformed.



Ignorance is the curse of God, Knowledge the wing wherewith we fly to heaven. --Shak.



2. (Theol.) A willful neglect or refusal to acquire knowledge which one may acquire and it is his duty to have. --Book of Common Prayer.



Invincible ignorance (Theol.), ignorance beyond the individual's control and for which, therefore, he is not responsible before God.



http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/i...

In its unwilled existence, ignorance is fearful knowing that needed knowledge is unknown.

Level two in human need: Safety issues.



</answer>

<answer>



Ignorance is neither bliss nor suffering....... it is a void that can in certain circumstances prove to be helpful and in other circumstances turn out to be a curse. However, in the longer run, ignorance is more likely to be detrimental than blissful.... the bliss of ignorance is rather temporary, just like a lie that can help us only for the time being in certain specific circumstances, and not for all time to come and in all circumstances. Knowledge and truth, even as may sometimes prove to be bitter for the time being, are the only weapons we can have in order to be assured of ultimately coming out victorious in life.



</answer>

<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



One may suffer in ignorance, and one may suffer due to ignorance. Sufferance, I take in fact is a forced awareness caused either by our own nature, or by some external agency, for something being wrong within the normal, and natural, formation of our personality in the mind, something being incompatible, inconsistent, imposing, or missing as suffering could also be in the having too much or too little of something. If there is dearth of insightfulness, knowledge and awareness than there would certainly be pain and anguish in the mind trying to come to terms with the realities of life, and if there is too much of some one thing that might cause disproportion resulting upon pain and discomfort, until the time natural balance of things is restored.

I therefore would like to maintain that suffering is in fact awareness in disguise, or it bring with it opportunities of new and better knowledge and awareness. However, sometimes the message is too strong and realisation too sudden and shocking that they take us by storm, and before we develop new abilities to deal with what is happening, they get the better of us.



If our awareness lags behind reality then the moments in between are often occupied with hurts, pains, delights, hopes, and suspense, and finally, when we do start to see things in the light of new reality, we realise that we could overcome our circumstances, we can see the light at the end of the tunnel, and that light have power to dispel hurt and pain.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



No, Knowlegde can be as well.



Depends on how Knowledge or Ignorance of a particular situation affects your life. If knowing the truth about something makes you feel worse off, then Ignorance is better. Unless you put more value on knowing the truth, whatever the cost, over feeling good about things just being the way they are, even if your perception of them is very far off from the reality.



</answer>

<answer from>



simplyun...
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 10871 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



Before I indulge myself in some fanciful thoughts and start dreaming about a world of perfect bliss, all full of joy, delight and comfort, with each moment a moment of perfect peace and happiness, liveable to the full, assuring for its present and at the same time promising for its future, let me remind you, let me tell you that the concept of imperfection in the mind is what stands right against that of imperfection. For if I attempt to see my life as perfect, then, being it being life as it normally is, I will also see imperfections, and everything more imperfect than normal, as when I will seek all things to be prefect. Your question, however, despite its hinging upon the word ‘perfect’, is valid, as it does invite us to think of the ways of improvement.

I think true perfection is to be found within the normalities of life in general, in its realities, and thereupon, also in our ability to live normally despite our love for idealism.



I think all people, their places and things, can be seen as perfect long as they are seen through their right reasons and use. The place prefect is the place right in the middle of all this, in the middle of life. A prefect life is a life that one could sensibility, happily and sustainability lead. This I think is the underpinning philosophy to use as guidance while trying to construct a ‘perfect’ day of my life.

To do this should be simple if is it has to be any good. It has to be at least as simple as its philosophy is sophisticated. So, this is what I would do to make my day a perfect day:



I would get up early in the morning, and then after some light breakfast, would sit down and carefully plan for the day ahead. I will think carefully, realistically and sensibly as how would I like to spend the day at hand, while making sure at the same time that what I aim for my day is slightly better than my yesterday, is reassuring for now, and is also promising for the day that is to come. Then once all things nicely mapped out, I will set out to turn it into a reality. I would know by doing this that I have live the day that I have had, that I will be able to happily own up to by the evening – perfect, or imperfect, in the eyes of the world, the day has undoubtedly been mine!



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 880 (Level 2)

<question>



How do you discern truths from lies?



Thanks for sharing  your thoughts. Have a great day to all!

<answer from>

<answer from>



Kelsey
Member since: 21 July 2008
Total points: 1724 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Singles & Dating



</answer from>



<answer>



Good Q, thanks.

Truth, like a bouyant thing, always rises to the surface of a pond. A lie is the stone that sinks, often dragging us to drowning with it.

That thought doesn't say that Truth sets us free, or won't have painful effects, but it sure means  we can stop lying.

A lie is like trying to dig a hole in dry sand. The "job" can hardly be completed, as the walls of the hole, keep falling back in on the "digger", creating more effort, and even more lies to compound.

A.F.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



You don't. No matter how real something may appear, appearances are deceiving. People used their senses to perceive that the Earth was flat. Those senses proved to be wrong.

What seems to work better is to acknowledge that something may be true at this moment, but in time, you may learn more information that disproves that truth.

Truth is fluid.

It was true that humans were Earthbound. It is now true that humans travel into space.



</answer>

<answer>



If the issue is important enough, demand proof. If the lie doesn't lend itself to examination by this approach, ask for the details. Ask for more details every other day or so. Very few liars can keep all the details straight, and then you can catch them in contradictions.
One long term method is an austerity from Yoga - this is to never lie yourself, not even for the smallest or biggest reason. This will develop in you the power of hearing the truth.



Source(s):



Friendly guy

<answer>



Transcending the mind/ego, which is incapable of telling truth from falsehood.  This is most commonly exhibited in the Eastern traditions of meditation, contemplation, prayer and devotional service.

Another way is to become proficient at kinesiology and muscle testing.  It is a known fact that body language indicates what is unspoken or used to discern truth from a lie.  Muscle testing with the kinesiology test tests the muscle response in the presence of positive or negative stimuli, or truth and non-truth.  The muscle will respond weak to falsehood and that which doesn't support life and strong to the contrary independent of personal belief



Source(s):



teachings of Dr. David R. Hawkins

<answer from>



Simply Reflect
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 11109 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



It is possible for people to tell lies most truthfully, i.e. to the best of THEIR knowledge, information and belief, where knowledge, truth and beliefs all can be faulty. It is possible for all people to be sincere hypocrites, i.e. to be living a lie but to be ignorance it the fact. Then even when we are along the right path, that is to say, have right knowledge, correct information and beliefs based upon true principles of human nature, we can falter and misconceived fact only to learn sooner or later that we have been wrong in this or in that. Then the general fact that our knowledge will never be complete to allow us to claim truth, we have to know what we cannot know through faithful believing. And when people believe in things that always remain beyond the rationality of reason, our common sense and comprehension our interpretation of truth remain a matter of dispute among people of different beliefs.

This all makes us an unreliable judge of truth, but then how do we manage? I think we learn to manage in our circles of understanding. And therein we set standards that help us ascertain as if someone is right or wrong. Then we can see that if a person who is right according to commonly understandable criterion of right and wrong is predominantly right then he must be telling what is mostly true, and vice versa.



What I mean to say here is that there is not other way for a truth or a lie to exist but in forms and functions of human life, and there is no way to see a truth unless the person who accommodates it or mediates the facts is known as truthful, and is truthful beyond doubt. In simple words it is character of the people that determines their truthfulness.



</answer>

<answer from>



Tootsie
Member since: 09 August 2006
Total points: 5083 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



To be betrayed, you must give trust.  If you do not give trust, then it is difficult to see how you can be betrayed.



Once a person, or group of people, have betrayed you you cannot or should not allow them the opportunity to re-offend.  Perhaps if they show repentance, some element of reduced trust may be offered.



Eventually they can, if the level of trust is rebuilt.  But I suspect, that the benefits of having trust will be appreciated more than it was before the trust was abused.

So the answer is yes, eventually.  However, people who bear grudges and who do not accept that people have to learn the value of trust, may not be able to re-establish a broken relationship.

It really depends on the seriousness of the betrayal!



</answer>



<answer from>



pkm trainer
Member since: 03 August 2007
Total points: 2539 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes  but you must make allowances for this person's flaws and not allow them to hinder or place stress on you own existence.



</answer>

A friend said he rated people  at '0' on a scale of 0-10 on trustworthiness on meeting them the first time, I said I give everyone the benefit, and more, of the doubt, giving them a 10, only for nearly all of them to plummet from 10 to 0 with their first shortcoming. With him, people climb the scale gradually, if they do, with time, so he'll have people with all 11 ratings.



My list consists of '0's but for a few exceptions, my '10's are all those I have not yet met.



</answer>

<answer>



Think we've all been there at some time or another.  Instead of looking at the bad things, look at the good.  My partner and I have 'lived on the edge' at times, struggling to make ends meet but we've always pulled through in the end.  The fact is, you've reached the age of 46 and you're still here on good old Mother Earth so you're obviously a survivor.  Have you got any hobbies?  If you don't feel you're good at socialising, try reading or cooking.  You don't have to be rich to enjoy them.  I do online surveys which can bring in a bit of extra cash (or in some cases pay in Amazon vouchers - which is how I can afford books!).  Cooking doesn't have to be expensive either.  I make my own home-made soups and jams (if you go to my profile you'll see links to a couple of articles I've written).

Whenever I'm really down, I look outside and think "well at least I've got a roof over my head and I'm not hungry, unlike so many others in the world" or, if you're near a park or out in the country, try taking a walk out and seeing what beautiful things are out there!!  Believe me, it is possible to drag yourself out of the doldrums.



</answer>

okay, true enough (I respect the challenge)...the printing press isn't a discovery - but the use and implications of language is to some extent - it is the extension into the metaphoric from physical abilities that are inherent and had only to be discovered and harnessed

electricity and magnetism and all of those other natural forces are amazing discoveries...but the discovery without the invention of the means to harness said powers is, while still amazing, ultimately without teeth...

evolution is a ground-breaking theory (and one I subscribe too), but it is just a theory that was proposed or hypothesized by Darwin who had discovered certain 'goings-on' in the natural world - he didn't discover it, as a matter of fact, he didn't even prove it (little hard to prove it with a timtable of millions of years)

<answer from>



simplyun...
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 11429 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



There have been three instances in the history of human kind when human mind was demoted, altered, and its fundamental beliefs changed for good, three epoch making times in the history of human civilisation when processes of scientific discovery led up to revolution in thought, i.e. science alone has caused three major shocks to the mind. I call them shocking discoveries. And they are:

The first Shokcing by Nicolaus Copernicus, the first astronomer to formulate a scientifically based heliocentric cosmology that displaced the Earth from the center of the universe. His epochal book, On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres, is often regarded as the starting point of modern astronomy and the defining epiphany that began the Scientific Revolution.

Before this discovery the Earth was believed to be the centre of the universe, thus the term heliocebtric. Galileo Galilei, an Italian physicist, mathematician, astronomer, and philosopher, played a major role in this scientific revolution and through his astronomical observations provide the support for Copernicanism.

The second shock by Charles Darwin an English naturalist, who showed that all species of life have evolved over time from common ancestors through the process he called natural selection a theory that came to become the basis of modern evolutionary theory.



The theory of evolution by Charles Darwin was a massive blow to the the theory of divine creation according to which all thigns were brought to exitence thourgh the act of creation some six thougsand years ago.

And finally the third by Sigmund Freud, an Austrian psychiatrist who founded the psychoanalytic school of psychology, best known for his theories of the unconscious mind as his most significant contribution to thought. Freud called dreams the "royal road to the unconscious", meaning that the logic of dreams is the logic of the unconscious mind.



Before Sigmund Frued it was believed that human mind is based upon reason, but with this new interpretation it proved shocking to know that human mind in its entirety rests upon som dark and unfathosmable ocean called unconscious, the place of wild instanctive foreces and darkes of desires.



Source(s):



Wikipedia



</answer>

<question from>



jamesduc...
Member since: 07 August 2008

</question from>



<question>



Are Human Rights a purely Human construct?



Are they discovered by us but existing in any case before we proclaim them, or are they totally arbitrary?



</question>



<answer from>



More Te Vicar?
Member since: 08 November 2007
Total points: 1472 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



the construction is purely that but the template from which they are constucted is the same universal quality that caused humans to evolve into soical beings the first place.



if other human colonies exist elsewhere i imagine they have some form of socialisation which will neede stratified managements of that social interaction such as having rights



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Interesting. I cannot see how evolution could produce absolute morals which transcend cultures, but accept that it is one respectable explanation. The other difficulty is that if you accept evolution in Psychology  or Sociology there are no final truths in any meaningful sense.Just survival waste!



</asker's comment>



<comments>



62,040,610 Idiots



We are social because we evolved from primates - that has nothing to do with human rights per se. It is impossible that there are Homo sapiens anywhere else in the universe - our genes are a product of our unique biological evolution.



62,040,610 Idiots



As for a final truth: as I offer, we are granted rights because we are capable of moral choice and that imparts an absolute value to us that is found no place else in nature.



More Te Vicar?



morality is quality is value - i assert that it is an absolute morality that produces evolution not the other way around. definitions are a reaction to quality rather than quality being a propery of that defined.

Te.

MOQ.org



</comments>



<answer from>



62,040,610 Idiots
Member since: 05 April 2007
Total points: 3246 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would say that in the absence of humans, human rights cannot exist.  So whether they are a purely human construct will depend on your view of humans:  do we have a solely material existence, or do we also have an immaterial immortal soul?

If we are purely material, then it seems to me that human rights are a construct of our material brains.  If we have a separate human soul, then human rights might exist as an eternal ideal regardless of whether they are proclaimed by our physical selves.

For me, it is enough to say that since humans have the capacity for moral choice, we have intrinsic moral value, and, therefore, are deserving of human rights.  It is not necessary that human rights are preexisting, nor are they arbitrary.



Source(s):



Myself



</answer>



<answer from>



foggisan
Member since: 13 September 2007
Total points: 3105 (Level 4)



Contributing In:

You only have to look at what is happening in the UK to reduce yourself to tears or laughter, depending on your veiwpoint.



</answer>

<answer from>



Rajatou
Member since: 21 August 2008
Total points: 363 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Those are some heavy questions and I am trying to see the relation between each of them.

People's dreams cannot be measured by size, nor by time, because the dream world is a world which is not governed by these elements. It often shows us from an inkling to a direct idea, a little of what may be going on inside of ourselves, in our psyches.

The true fundamental of living? I guess one would have to say that certain have classified all things into animal, vegetable or mineral, and since humans fall into the first on the list, a great deal of what is common to us, is common to other members of this group, the main difference being in the area of reason. Spirituality explains this as the ability to reason, to having a conscience which allows us to reflect upon the reasons why... So the fundamental of living would therefore be that we realize we are going to stop living some day, which is what we see happening in others, all forms of life, which makes life become an absurdity if the entire life process would stop at the point of death. This is why, I think, that people aspire to an afterlife, because the real nature of mankind, is not limited to the fleshly body.

As for free will, so many people have not thought this out, that they are not even able to use theirs... I would go so far as to say the majority. Many just "follow." Interesting you would mention obedience to laws. If first individuals would learn the laws of nature, there would be much less need for restrictive laws, because people would do what is good, naturally, or better said, do what is natural.



Is this world meant for the poor? Which part of this world are you referring to? the one that power-hungry people created and imposed on others? It is possible theoretically that there be no poor, but it is the system that mankind has developed, for whatever reason, which makes people poor. But even among the poor, there are many who are rich in spirit.

True judgement? Hmmmm...  everything is relative, depends on motivation, human judges may have difficulty doing a good job, for some of us, only a divine being can be the judge, now it is the responsability of each individual to investigate and reach knowledge of what is expected of us... look at examples around you... and please don't be too hard on yourself. Better days are coming.



</answer>



<answer from>

A dream has no restriction of size, time or anything else.  It is simply there to show the man that he can be the same.



</answer>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



Jon T
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 91 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is an a priori argument ?



Basic i need help on what its say above, but i need it in a simple form as im finding this particularly hard to grasp!

Thankyou x



</question>



<answer from>



David M
Member since: 02 May 2008
Total points: 7446 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



One that can be argued using reason alone without recourse to data or experience.

The usual example in many textbook is a variant of "all bachelors are unmarried".  Since a bachelor by definition is unmarried, you need to rely on no data or empirical experience to say all of them are.



</answer>



<answer from>



Robin T
Member since: 07 November 2006
Total points: 553 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Like the answer to a posteriori I just posted, "a priori" has the word "prior" in. Meaning "before". To remember this just think that homework has to be done prior to the lesson - before the lesson. Therefore, a priori can be remembered as before experience.



</answer>



<answer from>



hsrch
Member since: 08 July 2006
Total points: 1376 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Reasoning from cause to effect.



</answer>



<answer from>



los
Member since: 08 August 2006
Total points: 7781 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is a hermit arguing with himself in his cell while his courgette stew is cooking in the corner.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cherry Lips
Member since: 04 June 2007
Total points: 287 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



An argument made before any knowledge is gathered.



</answer>



<answer from>



More Te Vicar?
Member since: 08 November 2007
Total points: 1472 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



a priori's require nothing but intuition to know them



time and space are a priori - it is not present in the sensory data you recieve you have to intuit it if you wish to know about it.



without a prior concepts to filter our sensory data the world would appear to be a confusing mishmash of colours and lines



</answer>

<answer from>



Inca Yebail - The 6th profit.

</answer from>



<answer>



Wow.... so many people.  We've all heard of the bright light at the end of the tunnel, seen by so many before being turned back.  "Go back my son, this is not your time!"  There are many books available outlining our transition to the 'other' realm.  How can anybody possibly believe that 'this' is it?  'This' is all we have?



Having died and seen what awaits, far too many have chosen to report their findings in books for the afterlife to be simply discarded as the majority appear to do.  There are too many events indicating that body and spirit are not one to believe that physical death also means spiritual death.  In fact, it is easy to conclude that the spirit lives without ever ending.

This is a very complex issues for which 1000 pages wouldn't be enough to tell you what I know.  You'll have to buy books I'm afraid.
Robert Newton is a good author on this subject.  Danian Brinkley's book is also good.  The religious texts are very good for offering advice and guidance, but for the love of everything: that's all!

Read my friend, the answer to your question is a long one.



</answer>



<answer from>



sophist
Member since: 24 May 2006
Total points: 41982 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Words & Wordplay



Law & Ethics



</answer from>



<answer>



Apparently, I'm the only one qualified to answer this question with any authority having experienced an NDE. Yes, I saw the dark tunnel and bright light and was told to return. However, the uniformity of the experience in others, points not to a confirmation of religious belief but a confirmation of how we experience death and the resultant religious belief thereafter.



The dying brain is just now being studied and so far it indicates that what we experience depends on how blood and oxygen leave our brain. If the Cerebral Cortex goes first, things get interesting. All our memories flood out and we begin to relive our life. As death progresses, we see the tunnel, the light and a warm cozy feeling takes over as other parts of the brain begins to die.

If the medulla goes first, we experience instant blackness and our brain dies with no sensation. It is interesting to note that this is in the kill zone of an animal attack. Instant, painless death. Ain't Nature wonderful and even merciful in death?



</answer>

Jack F

<answer>



"Have we finally lost the English language ?"

The English language is constantly evolving.  You used the expression "kid" to describe a child, not so long ago people would be assuming that you meant a young goat.



</answer>



<answer from>



simplyun...
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 11429 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The purpose here is to interact with people, people simple, common, special, known, unknown, all sort, to communicate with them all freely, openly and instantaneously, or to get to the information we need fast. The state therefore is that of a light dream where we know many things could happen merely by the press of our fingertips.



The English we encounter here therefore is not the English of formal letters and printed books, it is in a state of virtual projection, projection to cast an image or avatar, and then, to create a friendly, and informal atmosphere around it. I think we think we could afford to overlook rules and decorum that we normally observe writing form letters. This in my view is the fact that the more we are able to twist the rules of spelling the more exciting our impression is likely to be - this however is by no means a rule of thumb.



But we must realise that this is the for the first time that we have learnt to read the written word electronically, without the use of solid state medium like paper or wood. And this is the first time that we have been able to get interactive with a great number of people who we do no know as who they really are.



Then there is the nature of language to consider: as a dynamic thing, much like a living organism that grows in time and responds to changes in its environment. There is no doubt that the impact of technological revolution is huge on the way we use English language.



However, there is no doubt that the certain misuse does look unsightly, i.e. when rule of trashed for some shallow purposes, as in chat houses. I personal would not stand there long if I realise that I have to use the same banal contortions, compressions, additions and obliterations. I never like to see a word illspelled



</answer>



<answer from>



foggisan
Member since: 13 September 2007
Total points: 3105 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Poetry



</answer from>



<answer>



You are preaching to the converted, my friend. I spend a lot of time on the poetry site and frequently see offerings in some abominable 'Txt Speak' patois. It really, really jars.

I recently had a huge, almost coming-to-blows-huge, argument with a teacher who maintained that the meaning of a child's writing was the important thing and not the grammar/punctuation/spelling. I replied that without the correct spelling/punctuation/grammar the meaning was lost. Just ask the boy who went for a wee in the Laddies!

I also despise the SpellThick function as it presupposes I am American and/or wish to spell everything in the American idiom.

I feel better for that!



</answer>

We live to create our own chaos, but to also prevent and stop natural chaos. 
We live because each and everyone of us has a reason to live and to be where we are. I believe one day (maybe not in our own generations) whether its after we've evolved even more into something else or after we die, everything will become clear.



Our meaning of our little lives could be to look after the earths life....



</answer>

<answer from>



King David
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 150 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Humans live because if you take a big pool of elements and heat them up (simulating how the earth was when it first formed 4.5 billion years ago), the elements bind together in random ways and eventually over many random occurrences will form what is called a replicator. This is a molecule that creates copies of itself (imagine a cookie cutter (replicator) floating around and creating impressions of itself when it bumps into some dough (primordial soup)). Different replicators form and "compete" for molecules to replicate with. This competition causes evolution, with the replicators increasing in complexity to beat out other replicators. Human exist because we are the latest model of weapon in the arms race of evolution. We are a shell built around a replicator (DNA) with the purpose of creating copies of our replicators through sex. So go find a sex partner, get it on, and enjoy that sweet sense of purpose, knowing that youre a slave to microscopic chains of nucleotides.



</answer>



<answer from>



lazy bum

<question from>



Jon T
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 91 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is an a posteriori argument ?



Basic i need help on what its say above, but i need it in a simple form as im finding this particularly hard to grasp!

Thankyou x



</question>



<answer from>



topher
Member since: 22 August 2007
Total points: 751 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



if your talking in terms of philosophy. a posteriori knowledge is knowledge from experience so if you apply it to arguments, you are arguing about experiences or you are using your own experience as reasons to argue.



Source(s):



philosophy A2 level student



</answer>



<answer from>



David M
Member since: 02 May 2008
Total points: 7446 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The above poster is correct but another way to look at it is a priori is something that requires no external input.  An a priori assumption would be "all bachelors lack wives".



You don't need to search for data on number of bachelors and number of them with wives, because by definition a bachelor has no wife.  This question can be answered by reason alone with no data.

On the other hane "40% of bachelors over 25 were once married" is a posteriori whether you have expereince of being a married person or even a bachelor yourself.  The answer comes from experience, sure, but to you it comes in the form of data.

By the way I have no idea what the number is.  I made up the 40% entirely as an example.



</answer>



<answer from>



Brian
Member since: 08 April 2007
Total points: 5608 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



an a posteriori argument is an argument which is based upon someone's experience of the outside world (through the five senses). it is a way of classifying an argument according to what type of justification it employs.



so an example of a posteriori knowledge would be all goldfish are gold, for instance. you had to get up and go outta your house and look at some goldfish to make that argument.



now just to be clear, a priori knowledge would be something like "2 + 3 = 5" or "all bachelors are unmarried". you didnt have to experience these at all in order to come to a justified conclusion. you can just sit in your house and come to those conclusions. they are a priori. (prior to experience)



</answer>



<answer from>



Robin T
Member since: 07 November 2006
Total points: 553 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



An easy way to remember this is that "a posteriori" has the word "post" in it simply meaning "after". All above posts are correct but if you remember you send post to another person they will receive it after you have sent it! Simple!



Source(s):



University Philosophy.



</answer>



<answer from>



hsrch
Member since: 08 July 2006
Total points: 1376 (Level 3)



</answer from>

</answer>

<answer from>



Mountain Dweller
Member since: 20 January 2008
Total points: 3786 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes in some contexts. If you deny giving someone life saving knowledge clearly you have committed a wrong. But imagine giving a widow at the end of life the knowledge that her late husband committed adultery. What good have you done? If you're giving information just to prove your superior understanding over another when you know the information is emotionally & personally harmful it is wrong.  This principle, of course, does not apply in the arena of ideas. Someone may find the theory of evolution emotionally upsetting but their emotions are not justification for not discussing it. The only knowledge that is bad to give someone is information that would personally harm them either emotionally or otherwise. Additionally it would be wrong to pass on information about another if it would harm them unless you're trying to stop them from committing harm. Example: Telling a little child that Santa Claus doesn't exist just for the sake that you feel superior. Outing someone as gay if they are not out. Telling a nazis in world war 2 were a jew is hiding. The morality of telling or giving information to another always is decided by context.



</answer>

"Raindrops on roses and whiskers on kittens 
Bright copper kettles and warm woollen mittens 
Brown paper packages tied up with string, 
These are a few of my favorite things.



Cream coloured ponies and crisp apple strudel, 
Door bells and sleigh bells and schnitzel with noodles 
Wild geese that fly with the moon on their wings, 
These are a few of my favorite things.



Girls in white dresses and blue satin sashes, 
Snow-flakes that stay on my nose and eye-lashes, 
Silver white win-ters that melt into spring, 
These are a few of my favorite things,



When the dog bites, 
When the bee stings, 
When I'm feeling sad, 
I simply remember my favorite things, 
And then I don't feel, so bad."
:)

Kerry D

<answer>



I shout at my husband a lot when we argue and I really should learn to stop it. Its hard though. 
I think it depends on the situation though, someone may be oblivious to what you say unless you shock them by shouting at them - a friend or relative perhaps - someone who is not used to you shouting at them. Still I don't really think that this would solve anything but perhaps lead to an end to it until people have calmed down enough to talk.
In a relationship I think shouting leads to nothing but more resentment. I know my husband never listens to what I', trying to say once I raise my voice. The only times we have got anywhere towards working things out is when we are both calm and open enough to look at things objectively - shouting is about as subjective as you can get!
So to answer your question, no I don't think shouting can solve arguments.



</answer>

<question>



Is fear the result of ignorance?



Thanks for sharing your thoughts. Have a great day!



</question>



<answer from>



s0nny80y
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If by your definition it were true, fear can be abolished if someone could explain what happens (if anything) afer death.

I liken the explanation to a holistic approach where I return to dust and continue Earth's life cycle. In that sense, I remain fearless. Occasionally I'm afraid but understand that's when my mind lapses into a state of jahiliyya (I could use Eastern terms for descriptive purposes too, right?). From there, I build up my personal philosophies on life over again and it comes up stronger; what doesn't kill you make you stronger right?



</answer>



<answer from>



Wisdom Tormented©
Member since: 11 December 2007
Total points: 22641 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Fear is undoubtedly based upon ignorance. Faith in life in others in the world instils courage, fortitude and moral fibre. Death is inevitable, life brings trials and tribulations, as the sun sets and the moon arises, impermanence and transience is the nature of life. So we look upon life as a transitory journey of many paths to two extremes and ends. Having options and choice is gained by awareness and understanding, without such life becomes a thing of dread, hate and uncertainty.

Pleasure, have a beautiful a day too ...



</answer>



<answer from>



gora
Member since: 09 June 2008
Total points: 1740 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes. Ignorance of our real self. If we fully realised and accepted that we are the eternal spirit that is animating this temporary material body which we are encaged in. Then there would be no fear. We would realise that the spirit self, us, is eternal and can never die, can not be burned, nor dried, moistened by water, withered by the wind, cut to pieces by any weapon, is eternal, ever-existing, undying, primeval and eternally the same.
Due to ignorance of the truth about ourselves, we fear so many things that can never even touch the eternal spirit. 
This ignorance is the root cause of our suffering. Due to that ignorance, we are accepting the material body to be the self and therefore are constantly trying in so many ways to become free from suffering and distress, or to try to satisfy the senses of this temporary material body without giving any thought or attention to the spirit self within. Therefore causing frustration and further desires. 
We have to look to the future and act in such a way as to put an end to the repeated cycle of birth and death in this material world. Otherwise we will go on suffering life after life due to ignorance of the real self.
Is it worth the price you pay, that fleeting moments gain, which in another day will only bring you pain. Are you wandering across the earth with no thought of times to come, have you thought of your next birth and all the things you've done?
Take care. Best wishes. 
GOURANGA GOURANGA GOURANGA be happy my friend



</answer>

simplyun...
Member since: 06 April 2006

<answer>



Our ignorance is unable to make us afraid if we are not made aware of it, as I think it would take slightly more than all that we know for us to realize that we are ignorant, or we are in ignorance, but once aware of our ignorance, our knowledge increases, however sometimes merely by means of fear.



What makes us really afraid I think is the awareness that there is some great knowledge that we do not posses. We feel petrified as we think and wonder what things we might not be seeing, or what sights we might be missing along our journey though life, in a out of its various situations, what good and what bad we might not be able realize. We might be rushing along like a blind person, we think.



Now, this is in common experience that when our rivals in thoughts and ideals come up with better arguments, stronger arguments, views and opinions more mature realistic than ours we feel strange. Now, I could not say as, exactly what I mean by strange as I think the feelings would highly subjective in nature and therefore dependant upon their people.



Than if I feel challenged, annoyed, or generally afraid under such situations then that does not mean I have been made afraid of my ignorance, as ignorance was already there, it is just that it never come to light until I met my opponent. I believe fear would come from my realization of how little I know in comparison with my foe, from the realization of my weakness, or from feeling intellectually, or simply argumentatively, inferior.



And this is not all, as I could see that my rival has a better point, his knowledge is greater than mine, but would I find it easy to accept? Would I be able to happily accept that a greater knowledge is at the heart of what I am not? This is the question that unmasking of which puts us in fear.



</answer>

<question from>



s
Member since: 11 April 2007
Total points: 527 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Do you think it's amazing the number of factors that are essential for life to exist?



Water has many properties that makes it an ideal and perhaps an essential substance to allow for life. Water is the only known non-metallic substance to expand when it freezes, making ice less dense than liquid water. This means water bodies freeze from top to bottom, preventing them from freezing over. Water is vital both as a solvent in which many of the cellular solutes dissolve and as an essential part of many metabolic processes, acid-base neutrality and enzyme function. Water is also central to photosynthesis and respiration. The conditions which allow the three phases of water to be present here simultaneously, would be far less likely to exist if the Earth were 5% closer or further from the sun than its current orbit; and the water cycle would not be possible.
http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/co...
http://www.lsbu.ac.uk/water/life.html#co...
The high specific heat and latent heats are also crucial.
The Moon also plays an important role for life on Earth, by stabilising the precession of the Earth's axis. Without the moon there would be an ice age and a heat death too often to allow life. The size of the Earth itself, which determines the surface gravity, and its rotation period and magnetic field strength are such that they allow perfect meteorological conditions for life.
The composition of the early Earth's atmosphere allowed the particular kinds of life forms to develop, that would photosynthesise to produce enough oxygen (again, because of the particular atmospheric composition) for multicellular life. The current Earth's atmosphere protects living organisms from ultraviolet rays and is dense enough to allow complex life.
The tectonic activity of the Earth provides a supply of carbon dioxide through volcanic eruptions and metamorphism of rocks that release gases into the atmosphere. This replaces that amount removed by the weathering of silicate rock by carbonic acid (CO2 and rain water); which eventually form marine carbonate sediment. This helps maintain the Global temperature. If plate tectonics were to cease, then erosion would, eventually, abrade down the mountains. Sediments removed by erosion, carried into the oceans by rivers and streams would eventually lead to a rise in sea level and a global ocean would cover the Earth completely.



</question>



<additional details>



There is thought to be a Galactic Habitable Zone in spiral galaxies, in the shape of an annular ring, within which life can exist. It is determined by the region in which abundance of heavy metals (for nuclear fission at the planet core) can allow the creation of terrestrial planets with tectonic activity.



There's no suggestion of the existence of God in my question. I meant to ask .... for life to have developed.



</additional details>



<answer from>



bookworm...
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 783 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, God is awesome.

=D

www.wayofthemasterradio.com

www.desiringgod.com

www.gty.org

.



</answer>



<answer from>



jtrusnik
Member since: 24 March 2007
Total points: 9085 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Religion & Spirituality



Fish



</answer from>



<answer>



If you're saying that the forms of life that can tolerate the conditions of the earth would likely have a difficult time surviving in other conditions, I agree...but amazing? No, it's just the sort of prediction you would make.



Fish wouldn't be found on planet without open sources of water, whales wouldn't be found without oceans, and giraffes wouldn't found on a planet with high gravity. All the fish, whales, and giraffes on "wrong" planets wouldn't survive and pass on their destructive genes to offspring, effectively going extinct.



</answer>



<answer from>



Andrew K
Member since: 08 October 2007
Total points: 6713 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not particularly amazing at all. Obviously all those factors are important to life developing the way it has here on earth, but on other worlds it's entirely possible self replicating organisms have arisen to suit their particular environments. 
That humans thing we're the be all and end all of the universe and are somehow created by an all loving God who has empowered us to rule this planet is the epitome of hubris.



</answer>

<answer from>



sophist
Member since: 24 May 2006
Total points: 41982 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Words & Wordplay



Law & Ethics



</answer from>



<answer>



It is fascinating to examine how the conditions for life came to be. But, bear in mind one of the laws of Natural Philosophy: That which can be, must be.



Each and everything that you cited is because it can be. It is the survival of events that causes things to "progress" from one circumstance to another. When they all come together, life is born. Just another "progression" in the chain of circumstance. Now life too, becomes a factor in the progression of events.



Note: progress or progression is in the eye of the beholder. All things progress in time, but not necessarily in state. You have devolution as well as evolution.



</answer>



<answer from>



simplyun...
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 11429 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The amazement might be only for the preliminary stages, as the better we know the better we realise that there is more to be explored and learnt. There might never be an end to what we could explore and learn but at the end of each stage there is a familiarity to be had.

In general life is perfectly logically in place in relation with the rest of the animals, plants, and the environment. Therefore there is no greater surprise in the way life is than in the way it has come to be, it reason to be. The one who would contemplate life’s beginning, its possible end, and its purpose would be able to stand aloof and observe things form beyond their natural folds, the one who would seek to know things beyond limits of time and space.

I say amazement might only be the preliminary effect of knowing as I am sure that there is more to life then amazement. When for instance I see a brick I can understand fairly accurately how it might have been made, i.e. there was a mould into which mortar was poured and let to solidify in time.



However, if I have had no idea as what a mould is then even the simplest cubical form of a brick would have a caused amazement, but since I know the fundamental knowledge about the brick I can now ask future questions, as for instance what use that brick could be for me.



The amazing nature is the amazing mould of a wonderful life, but who poured the stuff of life into moulds of nature and for what purpose is a questions that remains to be answered, as it always has.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer from>



pee-wee

<answer>



Hi dear beholder

It is an affair of of the heart, it is loyal in relationships, and does not seek it's own vices.



It does not manipulate circumstances to the detriment of others. It gives  comfort to others, but does not stifle or suffocate emotions.

Is willing to listen. Does not cast judgement readily, indeed is wise in assessment in all subjects, to the point of re-feral to those who could help in discretion. For none of us know it all, because of our humanity
often gets in the way.

What is the definition of love,.Surely love for one another with added respect not seeking it's own at anothers expense;



With respect



Pee - Wee



Source(s):



LIFES RESOURSES AND EXPERIENCES



</answer>



<answer from>



Debra B
Member since: 09 June 2008
Total points: 543 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Real love is work, hard work to sustain. It is rarely romantic or passionate when it is set in stone. To find true love is rare not because of singing birds, church bells, or meeting "the one" but because for someone to truly love another he/she must first really know himself/be self aware (which probably doesn't happen until adulthood), must love himself (a lot of people don't get here either), there must be overwhelming trust in the relationship (yep...most don't get this), and both people in love must be able to understand that love is not an emotion, it is a will, a choice, and when it is real, it becomes simple and banal...it becomes a fact.

I'm not saying that when I was totally head over heels at sixteen it didn't feel like love, and maybe for the time it was, but only now I know it wasn't real, wasn't lasting, was not "love" as I know it today. As I've grown I've learned that romance and emotion has little to do with love, it sounds harsh, but once you get past the bull****, you realize that love that just is, is the greatest form of love possible.

"For one human being to love another; that is perhaps the most difficult of all our tasks, the ultimate, the last test and proof, the work for which all other work is but preparation." Rainer Maria Rilke



</answer>

<answer>



That's only one way the material way it has no value beyond your mortal existence which is a waste if you don't survive to life eternal.



The possession of personality identifies man as a spiritual being since the unity of selfhood and the self-consciousness of personality are endowments of the supermaterial world. The very fact that a mortal materialist can deny the existence of supermaterial realities in and of itself demonstrates the presence, and indicates the working, of spirit synthesis and cosmic consciousness in his human mind.

All mortal concepts of reality are based on the assumption of the actuality of human personality; all concepts of superhuman realities are based on the experience of the human personality with and in the cosmic realities of certain associated spiritual entities and divine personalities. Everything nonspiritual in human experience, excepting personality, is a means to an end. Every true relationship of mortal man with other persons--human or divine--is an end in itself. And such fellowship with the personality of Deity is the eternal goal of universe ascension.



Source(s):



Page 1228 - 4  http://www.urantia.org/papers/paper112.h...



</answer>

<answer from>



simplyun...
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 11429 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



You see, this is the problem: one cannot have it both ways; one must make choices and learn to live with decisions one makes along the way. This has been my problem too. I too could not make up my mind. I could not see as how, or for what good reason, any of the many equally good things I could be sacrificed for the sake of only one. What if that one turn out to be wrong things?

If you had not had quite a few good things already on your mind and asked me the same question, I would have asked you to go right ahead, and do just that. This nevertheless is a virtue to have something in mind, but this is just the beginning, as things must follow upon things I life.

The reason often is that when we believe we have many option is when we do not have any option. This is confusing … or let me explain: If I mange to convince myself that I have too many things to choose from then I am more likely to be content with such ‘empowering’ belief, as long as I think that I have power to choose but do not choose I feel I am up to few things, which is a from of self-deception.



The fact is the when a ball starts to roll then it can follow only line of motion, however, when it was standing still the possibilities for it to roll along a huge number of lines were there. The best way to make up you mind there is to get up start doing something. If you things you could ‘get a great job’ then time to put this theory to practice is now.



The life that you live sitting upon options is a life of illusion, which eventually would come to nothing. To make like whatever life could be for someone, one must start rolling and avoid feeling great with what merely be optional in the mind.



</answer>



<answer from>

<question>



"Does [a] culture require authorities to comply with its rules"?



Along with this introductory statement "Morality is a rule of conduct a culture sets itself." the above question was sent to me by bud85348 in answer to the following question:

Is it possible to be in authority and behave morally?

It's a hard question.  Where do I begin?



</question>



<answer from>



barbie r
Member since: 30 May 2008
Total points: 277 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes. That's why we have the authorities because the the rules were meant to be broken.



Source(s):



rule breaker



</answer>



<answer from>



jas
Member since: 13 September 2007
Total points: 8223 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



i am very confused by your question i just dont understand the wording but i will answer it as i see it. just because you are an authority doesnt mean you dont have to follow the rules that are set infact youshould follow them even better because the only reason you should be put as an authority over such things is because you are better at it so you can help make others better at it. i think the only laws that should be set are laws or morality (right word?) we should all behave morally and we wouldnt have a problem but the problem is everyone has different morals and soem do not agree with others so we take the majority and make everyone else live byt them. an authority figure should most definitely behave morally if not more morally than a non authority figure otherwise what gives them the authority to tell u what to do if they cant even follow the rules.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kim K
Member since: 02 September 2007
Total points: 4866 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



An authority can be seen as " internal", like ones conscience.

Yes, it is possible to behave morally, especially if the only authority one has to answer to is ones own conscience.
When one attempts to "rule over" the behavior of another by asserting laws and such, the ruler starts to feel more powerful than the subjects.
The ruler finds it difficult to behave morally, as Power corrupts.



</answer>



<answer from>



subra
Member since: 06 March 2007
Total points: 1870 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Surely any culture doesn't require any authority if the people are truely believe in it . The system of authorities had been formed by people who want to exploit others for their benefits . So naturally the authorities will exploit .



</answer>



<answer from>



Benjamin Straight
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 1337 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



That is the base function of social structure.  The authorities must enforce and (hopefully) embody society's laws for there to exist a predictable structure for people to govern their lives accordingly.



</answer>

<answer from>



Gus
Member since: 29 July 2008
Total points: 193 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its all about evolution.
Each individual evolve. Some faster and become leaders. Or advanced authorities who create rules. Some evolve "further" /in any direction/ and breaking the rules in the name of creating new rules. Morality is very flexible. What was moral 100 years ago is in some cultures immoral today. 
To answer your question, civilisation /some individual members of the culture/ does its best to cut "tall poppies" /requires authorities to comply/ but these /authorities/ are evolving further to be one step ahead of the mob. 
What looks like breaking the rules, is in fact evolution.
Morality or rules are not rigid. How old was last queen of France when she got married? Homos are nurturing our future generation...



Source(s):



omh



</answer>

<question>



Is this true or do you believe to see Beauty ?



in others you have to see it in yourself first?(and or to see beatuy in urself it comes easy to see it in others)

I was in the supermarket sunday and I saw sooo many beautiful ppl it was crazy,weird I don't know they seem to all have a glow to them, and it wasn't cause they was coming from church(I don't think so)

Anyway I went shopping yesterday and ppl was really looking at me and seeing my beauty (as I was seeing it in other ppl the other day) Im talking about like whoa, some girl was trying to give me a compliment on my eyes and such, but got tongue tied and just was like your pretty.

I even seen a couple of girls that was pretty but they gave me funny look like she think she's cute and or what I had on (designer from top to bottom) dont think that had much to do with it.

I get my fair share of compliments but yesterday I dont know what was ppl seeing, some complimented my smile,face,cloBeautiful
Do anybody know what it could of been?? and why was everybody beatiful out sunday at the grocery store(lol)?? You would of thought they was hosting the next episode of ANTM.



</question>

<question>



How can I plan out my actions so that they will not fail(like Light from Death Note/like hitmen do)?

Like Light/L/Near from Death Note does, or like Hitmen do to guarantee a perfect assination.

How can I become more smart to do this?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>

You cannot plan for everything you see. You cannot account for every wind current, and ESPECIALLY for humans, we are unpredictable sometimes.

As for how to become more like this... stop watching TV and taking so much from it. It's made up, the creators MAKE it go according to plan because they can control everything in the book/tv/movie/game/whatever. If you could do this in "reality" then it would be easy but you can't so it's not "easy"



</answer>

no answerer details

no answerer details

<answer>



Sorry, I don't think reality works like this! You have been watching that killer with the bad haircut in No Country for Old Men!
I believe in Karma or natural justice. Read Dostoyevsky's Crime and Punishment to see what happens when a student murders and old woman for her money and gets away with it. It talks about his guilty feelings and how in the end he was overcome - not by the police or her relatives - but by himself.
If you just want something really badly, just hard work and perseverence will get you there.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



You're bound to fail in this.  Doing things so perfectly only happens in these stories because the whole idea is fiction.  There are other ways to ensure success though; any really smart person would only find a better way to adapt to the new situation, or simply take what he has at hand.  People like Caesar or Augustus.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



No battle plans survive the first engagement.life contains too many variables,the purpose of foreward planning is to minimise them.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Well for practical purposes I'd say what you have to do is look at various ways of planing, different processes, try to take all the best aspects from them and develop the perfect process. That way you don't need to be "smart" every time you just need to be able to fill in the blanks.
In philosophically terms I'd recommend the exact opposite. Blast the possibilities wide open, so that no matter what happens you are satisfied. Make your goal to simply try and you're fine from the start. Exactitude is a difficult thing to maintain whereas with complete and total ambiguity you can't go wrong.



</answer>

<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



SpazzyMc...
Member since: 13 June 2008
Total points: 4850 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Astronomy & Space



</question from>



<question>



Is it ethical to force people to be smarter?



Hypothetical situation: You are given a vile with a highly contagious virus that increases that will increase the average infected person's IQ by 20 points. However the virus will die in vile within minutes if you don't infect yourself and in turn everyone on Earth. Would you do it?

Do you have the right to force intelligence on others or is it better to keep the status quo? What if the virus caused the infected to be violently sick and though not technically fatal will most likely kill many who are already weak?



</question>



<additional details>



Sorry for that typo



*In response to laxy bum*
Actually viruses have plaid a large part in the evolution of man and might have contributed to some of our more important characteristics. For example, a virus may have caused a mutation that lessens the prominence of our ancestors lessening the strength of their bite. This may seem to be disadvantagious but without the large jaw muscles our ancestors were allowed to develop larger brains and not require our skulls to fuse until full adulthood allowing us to gain brain mass and learn for longer periods or our lives.

Evolution is not set in stone therefore there is nothing to interfere with.



Sorry I meant lazy bum... not laxy
Apperently I need to learn how to type =(



</additional details>



<answer from>



Doctor Why
Member since: 25 July 2006
Total points: 39746 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Value is pretty subjective.  YOU may think being smarter is a good thing, but other people may not agree with you.

This becomes clear if you think of other kinds of hypothetical viruses.  Vegans might think it grand to prevent everyone on the Earth from eating meat, theists might hope to force everyone to be faithful, and cat-fanciers might approve of everyone growing whiskers, but it probably goes without saying that most of everyone else would find the act tyrannical and heinous.

Why, then, is it any LESS heinous to force people to do or have whatever it is that you think is good?  That answer is that it's not.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I guess a better question would be "would the world really be a better place if everyone was smart"? I think so. You should try reading the Ender's Game book series, the last book Children of the Mind has just such a virus in its plot and is where I go the idea for this very question.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



grey_wor...
Member since: 04 May 2007
Total points: 6190 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



no... we wouldn't want that kind of responsibility... stupid people seam to have an easier time being happy... we could find arguments both ways... too bad its all or nothing because some surly would want to do it and others surly wouldn't want to do it... damn the majority and their tyranny...



</answer>



<answer from>



kasha_ka...
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 193 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Depends on the ethical theory we apply to the action.

Egoism(my favorite) would probably support that viruses release, as it would make life longer, and more productive.



</answer>



<answer from>



I fought the law &
Member since: 08 September 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



20 points- that`s not that much to be worth it. Besides, the IQ measures a very specific kind of intelligence, that has nothing to do with social, emotional intelligence or an overall mind curiosity for example- things that really matter. LSD will increase your intelligence in some ways, but I would never force it on anyone.



</answer>

<question>



If you have a partner who is like a mirror image of you?



in the opposite sex (or same sex, whatever), in personality and mannerisms, and thought, etc.  All your traits, that maybe you're uncomfortable with or embarrassed by, will be there for you to see in all their glory.



Is this much likeness and understanding a bad thing?  Or does it force you to face yourself as you are?



</question>



<answer from>



Wisdom Tormented©
Member since: 11 December 2007
Total points: 22641 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I haven’t met one such as I, to date, don’t know anyone who is like me, some have some traits, attributes, persona, in times gone by I had thought God hated me so he didn’t create another like me, I don’t resemble anyone in my family, my offspring have little or nothing in common, I am a sole entity.

Meeting someone who is an exact mirror image, nay veritable replica of oneself is heavenly if you have only love and adoration for the mirror, hell if you don’t. Those I meet who are similar I adore, I suppose this is the true test of one’s self esteem and standing, whether we could love one such as me, myself, I ...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Lol, I feel the same.  My offspring is the opposite of me.
I think to meet someone like this, there would be a powerful bond.  It would be only be a bad thing if you really disliked yourself.



</asker's comment>

Wisdom Tormented©

georgefe...

<answer from>



Someone
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 225 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Assuming I know they are me, I think it would drive me crazy. I wouldn't be able to ask them for advice because they would just say whatever I would.  What if I'm totally undecided on something and need a second option?  They'll be undecided too.  They wouldn't be able to help me with fears because they would be scared too.  When I got mad at them, I would become mad at myself  knowing I would have done the same.  Them always thinking the same way too would bug me, It would never make for a very interesting conversation, as they would always agree with me. They would never be able to explain a different perspective to me that I'm having a hard time seeing because they would share my perspective.  I already know everything about them so why bother even talking?



However, It would be nice to know someone who always will understand how you feel, and observing them could help you understand yourself better.  I think overall it could work out if you did not know they were you,  they just would not be a positive influence or make you a better person.



</answer>

of the body?
