</answer>



<answer from>



simplyun...
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 11429 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Perfection in appearance is a void concept. There cannot be perfection in appearance, as all that appears to be requires a medium for its being and a method in order to cast its impression in the eye. For instance, eye would use light that things reflect in order to see things, but all things cast shadows. Besides, there are dimensional limitations: limitations of time, space and of directions of focus. I cannot for instance see what is behind my head, and all that I see in nature is subjected to time and place: a rose has to come when there is time for it, and there is place for all things that make their appearance in nature.

There however is a second level of thought as when human will is involved in the act of observing. It is noticeable through out human history that there has always been a tendency to give expression to the very human need for perfection. There have been idols, gods and religion to make this possible for us to see in the mind, within widest sense of the meanings, what we cannot see realistically, or apparently.

When we look deep into things and seek to scrutinise the nature of their form, their relation with other forms, and finally the very nature of their matter, we go far beyond appearances and qualities and move into unknown depths of the essence. There is some perfection that has manifested itself in it various forms and their attributive qualities.



There therefore is just one truth, and that truth is perfection. The truth is in the essence of everything. The reason we do not see perfection in all things is once again due to limitative nature of our observations, i.e. we cannot see the full picture in one instance, for if we could we would see only one.



</answer>



<answer from>



robert.w...
Member since: 29 July 2006
Total points: 437 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Beauty is in the eye of the beholder, so by my train of thought perfection would be in the eye of ones lover.
 More commonly perfection is in a mothers view of her children.



</answer>






<original file>index;_ylt=Au0Q5RyBbbB_rfNo1h2X6c3uBwx9953.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk48412.txt</current file name>



<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



tina
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 97 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How can plato be criticised on his analogy of the cave?



</question>



<answer from>



Yazid H
Member since: 08 October 2007
Total points: 2260 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



he divided our one world into two, it's a great artistic way to push you to the light, but led to catastrophic results like christianity



</answer>



<answer from>



Robin T
Member since: 07 November 2006
Total points: 553 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It has several problems to it.

The first, and most major criticism is that there is no evidence to support his ideas. It is a leap of faith.

Secondly, supposing it is true, it leads to questions about the gradation of ALL things. If Plato believes that we see shadows of only some things (such as perfection) and leads to the idea that we are merely shadows, then it begs the question what other objects do we see shadows of? Are cats just shadows of an ultimate cat? A table the shadow of ultimate table-ness? Does it mean that our "perfect" design of a table mean that it is "less perfect" than the ultimate table which is the most perfect table one can imagine? Apply this to us humans it implies that our perfect actions of perfect unconditional love, perfect friendship etc are not, in fact, perfect at all!

These are just two simple criticisms of the allegory of the cave, There are many, many....MANY more!



</answer>



<answer from>



sokrates
Member since: 03 September 2006
Total points: 2020 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Plato's cave denigrates the material world. The myth or allegory sets forth the idea that the material world is inferior to the world of Ideas or Forms. We must escape from the cave in order to find the Good. The Good cannot be found in the sensible world. Another criticism of Plato's cave might be the epistemology that is implied by the allegory. According to Platonism, our knowing is hindered by life in our bodies. The body is a prison for the soul. Therefore, only freedom from this physical body will result in our having that which counts as knowledge. Authentic knowing does not appear to be possible while we're constrained by these bodies.



</answer>



<answer from>



jac the hat
Member since: 25 May 2006
Total points: 11687 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think it depends upon what structure Political religious economic social psychological ) you are balancing on - to read the analogy.

I didn't come accross it till I was training as a person centred counsellor and it is a perfect explanation of adapted behaviours and consciousness
of the self.

Given that Plato had pled for Socrates and come up against the might of the state, bent on killing off an innocent man on a trumped up charge out of fear - I am not surprised that he went on to write this enlightening story - Why would it have to hold water for every occasion so long as it helps anyone to understand where they are chained? Maybe a criticism is that he doesn't say how to get the bottle to leave the shadows.



</answer>



<answer from>



los
Member since: 08 August 2006
Total points: 7781 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Plato is beyond criticism. He is dead.



</answer>

<question from>



clive p
Member since: 02 May 2006

</question from>



<question>



Is to be in love an act of selfishness, or altruism? ?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I believe it's an act of pure and deep selfishness because what you PRIMARILY want is to get that person no matter what, however, once you've got him/her, you find your own happiness in making that someone happy, so it is  an act of selfishness that leads to the best example of altruism and humility.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



what more is being in love than expecting someone to love you back?

Someone you expect to be by your side and not kiss another, just you.

It makes you happy when someone follows them and it makes them happy to see you happy so they do so.
Vice Versa
It's a game of give and take
It's ownership
it's seeeelfish

<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



In philosophical sense to love would be an act of self-realisation, but in spiritual sense to love I believe is to live for the purpose of soul. In this sense love is not an act of selfishness, an act merely for the purpose of physical pleasure, emotional satisfaction, or genetic dissemination, but for the higher purposes of human soul.



We witness people sacrificing their possessions, their comfort and their lives for the sake their believes, but if love was merely for the fulfilment of physical purposes than how could they come to do this. This nevertheless is true that love does serve life its physical purpose too, but I think the ultimate objective remains to be spiritual.

One may ask, as what do I mean by soul, and what are its higher purposes? I really do not know, as I cannot explain. It is just that I observe all too often demonstrated through human nature some hunger that cannot be satisfied merely by physical means. Then there are aspects to life that we do not understand the reason of and yet cannot be without. We see that life is all we seem to have but there is no escape from its end, and therefore, no ultimate consolation in reason. It seems that we have ability to excel the limitation of our singular being and merge with other people, and perhaps this way to dodge death and see eternity to feel that life in love is a life forever.

The understanding of love, however, and mainly in most popular culture, has come to mean only passionate love physical union of two people. I think this too is fully reasonable, as what else one could reasonably need beyond the need of a partner, and a family?



The concept of spiritual love however may come to symbolise as some idealistic fantasy, or some form of idiosyncratic mysticism. I without an elaborate and extended notion of love, beyond the domains of reason, it become difficult for many to see as what is the true purpose of life, suffering and death after all, if not for the sake of some purpose that extends beyond life we know?



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



both :)



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It is an act of selfishness. I suppose at some deep level it is desire to ensure the survival of our genes. The love bit is just how this desire manifests itself at a conscious level. I am not sure I completely buy this in so far is this would not explain love between people of the same sex. However, I do think our sexual drive is basically an evolutionary imperative - pleasure from sex being the motivator as it were.

As one of the other responders has noted this ultimately selfish act can lead to acts of selflessness toward the object of our love. There are many recorded cases where one person has sacrificed their own life to save the live of a loved one - literature is littered for such stories. So although our love maybe selfish it can engender acts of great altruism.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details

<answer>



It may be both, but if you believe in love or the concept of love, you are someone who believes in 'value judgements' and non-material reality. I think there is a lot of rubbish talked on this point of altruism vs selfishness. Even if one accepts that physical love has some kind of evolutionary basis, I do not see that one has to go into 'evolutionary Psychology' mode or kiss the feet of Richard dawkins. I believe that the physical and spiritual meet in love and we are not in an either or but rather 'both/and mode'. That is part of the indescribable, but completely real mystery love presents us with.



</answer>

Unnikrishnan A

<answer>



As is the people so is the Nation.  A cultured, refined good citizentry can produce the best govt. which in turn makes a good Nation.  If we select the best as our leaders, we get a good governance in a democracy.  A corrupt leader is the product of a downcast group of people.  In the light of the above facts, we can define the leader as well as the Nation.  The best Govt. is which governs the least.  For that we should have very good citizens.  Democracy has the obvious disadvantage of counting votes instead of weighing them.  We should weigh the quality of our candidate and then elect them.  If we have good representqatives in our democracy, we can expect good governance.  No nepotism, no bribery, no fenaticism, no suppression of the down cast.  Intelligent people can define their leader and their Nation by observing them



</answer>

<question from>



Miss D
Member since: 10 April 2006
Total points: 647 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Who thinks that people like Thomas Nagel makes philosophy seem silly?



I just did Thomas Nagel's reading on the Absurd. I must say, that for a philosopher and a professor, he is rather wordy.  The points he was arguing were silly, and his replies or conclusions were poor.



Basically his 14 page reading was about how our lives only seem absurd if we view them that way, and a way to tackle this absurdity is with irony...whatever, see it's people like him that makes me hate philosophy, who cares!?! Who cares if our lives are absurd or not? Who cares if some people have or want meaning in their lives? I don't, so rather than waste his time (and mine) writing 14 pages of argument debating whether our lives are absurd or not, why doesn't he write about more important things like, cultural differences, or how we can achieve world peace? A philosophical perspective on those issues would be nice.



I think his own reading was absurd!



Honestly he makes Nietzsche's work look like they were written by a god compared to the drivel he was on about.



That's my two cents worth



</question>



<additional details>



Don't get me wrong, I enjoy philosophy too. But I have more appreciation for philosophers whose works contributed something to contemporary society, such as Kant and Nielsen.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Happy Hiram
Member since: 28 March 2008
Total points: 11586 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I feel this way about Bertrand Russell and Ann Rand, but to each his own. I guess if every philosophy were for everybody, then there would BE no cultural differences or impediments to world peace. Ironically, and you will pardon the word, it is our inability to tolerate one another's ideas that MAKES cultural differences and prevents world peace. So your dislike of Nagel is an example of the very things you want to avoid. What an, if you will pardon the word, absurd situation to be in.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Oh yeah you reminded me of Bertrand Russell too. How he got a Nobel prize is beyond me...



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Brian
Member since: 08 April 2007
Total points: 7030 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



LOL.



I actually enjoyed "What is it like to be a Bat?", and I think it makes a good case for the existence of qualia. I don't think it's silly at all. In fact, that's the kind of stuff that I like about philosophy. However, I've never read his writing on the Absurd. Sounds like you enjoyed it though, so I'll have to check it out.



Source(s):



Phil major



</answer>



<answer from>



mtheoryr...
Member since: 30 November 2007
Total points: 10993 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sometimes a postulate in one branch of philosophy can offer you a fresh perspective in a different category.
So that looking at personal meaning and who a particular philosopher reasons about that topic would give you insight into how the would look at more abstract issues, like cultural differences or a way to achieve world peace.
It may not seem like there is a connection, but existential philosophy is often closely linked to morality and ethics.
I find that most good philosophers are not so much addressing an audience with their arguments but instead are detailing their own reasoning as objectively as possible so that they know why they think the way they do about some other philosophical inquiry and that if we are both inclined to be in agreement about some other fundamental point that I am willing to forgive minor deviations in how one reaches a particular conclusion.
It may also be that you are not connected to the philosophy in the proper context. Historical context, the prevailing attitudes of the time the work was composed also provide insight into a philosophers analysis.
It sounds like this fellow is attempting to rebut absurdism.
But I have not read his work so I do not know the way he attempts to refute it.
It also sounds as though you have already decided on a stance regarding the answer to the question of meaning for human existence.
Unless you read the work objectively it is not surprising that you were not able to take away much from it.
It may be that instead of analyzing the arguments you analyzed only the conclusion.
This is not a reliable way to determine the strength of an argument and I would caution against this form of hasty rejection.
For instance I would be inclined to agree that seeking to find some ultimate purpose for the existence of consciousness may indeed by a pointless endeavor with regards to objective reality.
But the simple fact is that humans do this almost instinctually and so there is likely some benefits in doing so.
Also I do not extend my nihilistic attitude about the existence of intrinsic value regarding the ultimate meaning of consciousness to other branches of philosophy.
I am not an epistemological nihilist for example.
Nor am I a social anarchist.
Based on the length of the work you sight it is likely that a great many things are assumed to be known to the reader and this might also make the work seem less coherent if it turns out that you are not well read in philosophy.
But I do not often encounter works that I consider "silly".
And I certianly do not consider philosophy itself to be a pointless endeavor.
As for a philosophical perspective regarding cultural difference's and world peace.
I am willing to bet that you should be able to hazard a guess about the authors thoughts by the work.



</answer>

You don’t see chickens hanging around in drug gangs, do you? No, you don’t see a chicken strapping some guy into a chair and hooking up his nuts to a car battery, do you? When’s the last chicken you heard about come home from work and beat the s**t out of his hen, huh? Doesn’t happen, ’cause chickens are decent people.

All you have to do is look at slavery, the Middle East, the Crusades, the Inquisition, the Holocaust, and the World Trade Center, and you'll see how seriously the religious folks take "Thou Shalt Not Kill." <question from>



Glenn  Harvey Fingler
Member since: 16 May 2008
Total points: 933 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Is there anything more to risk than the possibility of loss?



In other words, is risk never anything more than an evil to be eliminated or avoided?



I really think that many Americans, in particular, think that there is something positive that attaches itself to risk just by the nature of risk.
Needless to say, I think that they are wrong.



I think that it is impossible for the wise man to avoid all risk (to quote St. Augustine), but I think that some are positively attracted to it.



"He that loves danger shall perish in it." ---Sirach



"...many boats..." ---somewhere in the Bible



</question>



<additional details>



But also consider: "If the highest aim of a captain were the safety of his ship, he would keep it in port forever."---St. Thomas



</additional details>



<answer from>



Unnikrishnan A
Member since: 04 June 2008
Total points: 538 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The ability to risk anticipating a positive result is the mark of industry and growth.  Jump in the water to learn swimming, but don't get drowned.  That is the modus operandi of risk taking.  For achieving success in any field, one should be prepared for a change and this change has the inevitable risk attached to it. Dare develry had been the  mark of success.  "Let there be no Alps" said Napoleon to his army who hesitated to climb the snow covered mountain.  They obeyed and succeeded.



</answer>



<answer from>



subra
Member since: 06 March 2007
Total points: 3004 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



No loss is a real loss . Take risk and try to succeed without affecting others .



</answer>






<original file>15301.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk5894.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



Andie
Member since: 25 March 2008
Total points: 224 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



State your opinion on--Designer Babies?!?



"New reproductive technologies are giving would-be parents more options -- if they can cough up enough money. One day, some experts say, parents might be able to order blue-eyed, academically inclined, cancer-free kids."



Frankly, I'm utterly appalled! I just finished reading this online article about how parents may someday be able to create their own super-kid, features including: choice of some physical traits and personality attributes, such as hair color, level of optimism, if they are athletically or academically inclined etc etc.



Does anyone else agree with the fact that this is sick and twisted?!



Now I agree that the advances in technology and science can be wonderful. For example, helping parents have healthy children without birth defects. However, allowing wealthy adults to be able to create their own robots or monster is not fair to the child! It's not up to the parents to literally force their decision on what another human being should be like. I mean, parents now have an influence on their children, but they can't scientifically alter them to be their perfect child.



Now, I know the whole nature verses nurture theory will, of course, take affect on any child, whether they are a creation of just the parents, or a creation of science; that even though a child may be programmed one way, the things that happen in their life will make them individuals. It’s just...I do not believe that we should be able to change someone to our liking before they are even born.



Your thoughts?



Article---http://articles.moneycentral.msn.com/Inv...



----
Also, I know that mothers are already capable of affecting a child before birth with their own life choices, such as drugs or alcohol or diet. I know this will affect the child in many ways. Parents are one of the main influences in a child's life after birth as well, and affects who we are today. But that is a discussion for another time.



</question>



<answer from>



Sℸ eupraxsophist
Member since: 26 July 2006
Total points: 11258 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Every parent (every competent parent, at least) wants the best for their child.  This really is no different than choosing which school your kid goes to, what TV shows he watches, what hobbies he gets interested in, whether he grows up to be responsible or irresponsible, etc.  Parents "force their decision on what another human being (their child) should be like" all the time; it's what parenting is all about!



I must very strongly disagree with your contention that "designer babies" would be "robots or monsters."  Actually I recall that the same thing was said about the first in-vitro babies.  Genetically modified babies would in fact be exactly the opposite of robots or monsters, having been given all the _best_ qualities of humans.  (BTW, there's no reason a child couldn't be academic _and_ athletic.)  If you could tweak a gene to make your child more creative, would that make him more, or less like a robot?  If you could give your child a heightened sense of empathy and compassion, is that turning him into a monster?



Genetics is not playing god any more than giving chemo for cancer is.  There is nothing divine, magical or supernatural about genes; they are just another part of your body like your pancreas or that wart on your hand.  Tweaking them is no different than using glasses to correct your vision or working out to increase your strength and health.  You said yourself that genes are not all there is to a person, that their upbringing and environment can also play huge roles in shaping a person's identity.  Gene therapy & modification is just another factor out of many, so why not put it to beneficial use?



Also, who says this will only be for the wealthy?  Like computers or plane trips, it may start out expensive early in its history, but as the technology matures and becomes more efficient the price will fall considerably until most anyone can afford it.



You might want to check out "Liberation Biology" by Ronald Bailey at your local bookstore or library.  It's about the coming revolution in biotechnology, and has a whole chapter devoted to the subject of designer babies.  I think you may find it quite interesting to read.



Source(s):



http://www.amazon.com/Liberation-Biology...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Very insightful. And I'll be sure to check that book out! :)



</asker's comment>

<answer from>



Phoenix Quill

</answer from>



<answer>



DNA functions like a  computer program, so in a very real sense it has 'intellegence'



And gist of Evolutionary theory is that Random Mutation & Natural Selection  behaves like intellegent design.



So one could say the interaction of DNA with Natura Law (Logos) constitutes intellegence.



But the assertion that mutation requires communication is wildly innacurate.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mel
Member since: 21 August 2008
Total points: 422 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The article you cited is an absurd and dreadful misunderstanding of DNA (among other things). I'm just hoping that the original authors were joking or under the influence of LSD or similar.



The notion of DNA mutations requiring communication is inherently flawed at its core. DNA mutations are the result of damage, for example from radiation or the sun, or can be the result of copying errors. Symbolic "communication" can occur within the cell, however these are the result of signalling pathways, as opposed to some linguistic property. The cell does not say "Oops! We're no longer at homeostasis! Someone fix that please!" The conditions within the cell trigger a cascade of enzymatic reactions, which can then restore homeostasis through the generation or degradation of proteins.



Even if we do assume that the alkalines of our DNA,which is a strange statement, I could understand basic nucleotides, but alkalines?, is true, it does not necessarily follow that language developed from that.



</answer>



<answer from>



d_chanak...
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<answer from>



Lucie B
Member since: 21 April 2008
Total points: 273 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



No.  Genetics have no consciousness and there is no form of communication required for mutation because it's not a collective activity.  Any genetic mutation is completely random and survives only if it causes a reproductive advantage in it's phenotype (i.e. the creature that the DNA makes up part of).



I think at best, the author of the article has misinterpreted whatever evidence they have read.  I tried to follow the link they have posted as a reference but it dosn't work.



If you are interested in understanding more Richard Dawkins is a good place to start and this link lists a number of his articles on this and related topics.



http://www.simonyi.ox.ac.uk/dawkins/Worl...



Be careful what you find on the web on this topic as there is an overwhelming amount of complete bunkum on the subject.



</answer>

<question>



Would a safety-critical project normally possess automatic test software which is validated by a manufacturer ?



and used to develop and set to work a subsystem ?
Would there be a high risk that someone on the team will misconstrue his own job, and doctor the automatic test software so as to agree with the subsystem under test.



(His intention may have been to then seek accreditation for the modified test software).



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Generic stooge "counterspy" persists particularly well in a talentless vacuum because legitimate inquiry occurs, most generally, elsewhere. Turgid mantra is thus fundamental to reinforcement of the dubious project: instead of writing ad copy for an external product that can be regulated by society, counterspy employs the specific technique to relentlessly reinforce, but not specifically exposit, and so accidentally corrupt, the general view (Gk. doxei) that the particular communicative medium is legitimate (not questionable). While I do not question the legitimacy of the generally accepted view, per se, I do indeed question, as an individual with no self-interest, the pernicious techniques employed by the conscript YA stooges to manipulate the target audience, i.e., regulate the general view as a means of avoiding regulation.



</answer>

Can philosophy ever lead to science and religion?



i dont think so, a friend told me that philosophy will lead to religion and science in the end, and i think he has not understood philosophy at all especially existentialism



can you present any arguments to support me?



</question>

Warman

<answer from>



steffi
Member since: 25 January 2007
Total points: 2717 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The answer to your question is yes, it already has. Study Socrates and Plato, etc. Does ALL philosophy lead to religion and science? No.



</answer>



<answer from>



randomwr...
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 213 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Philosophy is actually (historically) the foundation of science, look at all the philosophers of the classical times, they observed, and then formulated a theory on how this works, and supported this with their arguments. Science nowadays has more tools to determine the cause of something, so it is more accurate.
But all the sciences (Biology, Physics, Chemistry) started with people philosophizing about natural phenomenons.



</answer>



<answer from>



Eoredd
Member since: 20 November 2006
Total points: 28430 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Philosophy thinks science and religion, in the form of epistemology and theology. Science and religion are objects of the philosophical thought and commentary, but philosophical discipline doesn't lead to science (which is a very specific field of knowledge, very specialized) and doesn't lead to religion either, for religion is based on faith, living experience of the divine, and thought, whereas philosophy implies doubt, research and reason. Some philosophers were believers though, but they never confused their philosophical work with their personal faith.



</answer>



<answer from>



Old guy
Member since: 20 September 2007
Total points: 6078 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



No, I think your friend is correct.  The study of thought can naturally lead to study of the brain.  Study of the brain can naturally lead to the study of consciousness.  The study of consciousness naturally leads to two camps; materialism and religion.



</answer>



<answer from>



Robert K
Member since: 18 May 2008
Total points: 4871 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Such things as philosophy, science and religion do not have to be in conflict.  In fact, it's possible for all of them to "work together."  It just could be that many of us are considering the same things, but we're approaching them from different viewpoints.



</answer>

<original file>138.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk76134.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



Kim Lynn
Member since: 26 August 2008
Total points: 127 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Are undemocratic regimes anti-philosophical?



</question>



<answer from>



Mountain Dweller
Member since: 20 January 2008
Total points: 5911 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Not really since many undemocratic regimes were founded on certain philosophies. However, since the advent of modernity, during the French revolution, democratic regimes have believed in the Enlightenment philosophy of universal rationality expressed via the vote. Undemocratic regimes have rejected this Enlightenment notion, which makes those regimes seem anti-philosophical. They are actually anti-enlightenment not anti-philosophical (however, some really are anti-philosophical).



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Good answer



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



michael
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 341 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Philosophy is an area of inquiry, not a specific viewpoint.  As such, no, undemocratic regimes are not "anti-philosophical" because there is no such thing.  Plenty of philosophers have put forth proposals for systems of government that are absolutely not democratic.  Nietzsche, one of the greats, is AGAINST democracy.



</answer>



<answer from>



old lady
Member since: 18 May 2006
Total points: 83437 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Words & Wordplay



History



</answer from>



<answer>



Every political belief has a philosophy and undemocratic regimes have just as resounding philosophies as democratic regimes do.



</answer>



<answer from>



Happy Hiram
Member since: 28 March 2008
Total points: 13896 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



No. Fascism is a philosophy.



</answer>

<question>



What does this mean to you?



Humilty is the highest virtue

Any idea's? thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



Barbarat...
Member since: 11 April 2008

<answer from>



avisie

<answer from>



Tracy T
Member since: 17 March 2007
Total points: 1098 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Exactly.  Humility is a very valuable characteristic to have.  Usually with humility, you always know that there is room to improve.  Prideful people tend to be the opposite.  They live life as if they know everything and as if they are always right.  Humility is the highest virtue.  It is the most humbled person who tends to have the loudest unspoken voice.



</answer>



<answer from>



Michael O*Leary
Member since: 28 August 2008

<answer from>



davray2

<answer>

<answer from>



biggi
Member since: 01 September 2006
Total points: 2382 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Humility is a very nice admirable virtue to posses. BUT as the word  derives from Latin HUMILITAS... meaning submissiveness and lowliness. These are qualities which have to have one other quality in toe: assertiveness. If these qualities are not reasonably well matched, one might land up being walked all over and not being heard at all. So be aware of when to show humility and when to be assertive.
There are so many different walks of life were one needs to apply both qualities in almost equal measure. Hope that helps a little.



</answer>



<answer from>



Siddhart...
Member since: 07 December 2006
Total points: 3749 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The firm, the enduring, the simple, and the modest are near to virtue.



Confucius, The Confucian Analects
Chinese philosopher & reformer (551 BC - 479 BC)



</answer>



<answer from>



coolange...
Member since: 01 March 2008
Total points: 111 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i agree with you



</answer>



<answer from>



Lucie B
Member since: 21 April 2008
Total points: 273 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Literally it means that being humble is the best characteristic you can have.



I think it's also making a more sophisticated point that if humility is the highest virtue then it is wrong to brag about any of your other virtues/talents.  Even if you were say, exceptionally courageous and told everyone this, the person who said nothing (and was therefore more humble) would be more virtuous than you.  So I think it's really making the point that just because someone is humble and doesn't brag about themselves does not mean they are worth any less than someone who makes their virtues/talents known.



</answer>






<original file>1827.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk76631.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



layzt14
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 138 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Good guys or Bad Guys?



Nice guys finish last, am I the only one who believes in this saying. It seems true in quite a few aspects of life.

<question>

<answer from>



allyn.sa...
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 416 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Maybe you have to go around doing something in a way most people wouldn't.  More than likely you did something risky in a solution some people would consider off or a waste of time.  When I bought my house the previous owner painted over natural oak in several places of the house.  I decided to strip it in some areas and not others, stripping is time consuming.  So everyone says, it takes forever just buy new, which is what most people do.  But I stripped it and the end result was worth it.  But basically, it is there to make sure that before you decide you want to do something make sure the outcome will be with your risk or time.



</answer>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



Live is short, how we can make it longer?



Keep on smiling, nothing remains for ever



</question>



<answer from>



annie
Member since: 16 July 2007
Total points: 290 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



a long life may not be good enough



but a good life is long enough.



love well and you'll be living well  ,



life is not measured in the number  many breaths you take but the no. of moments which take your breath away.



life is measured by memories.



each day, he'd stack up the letters he'd write .............tomorrow



and think of the friends he'd fill with delight ...................tomorrow



it was too bad, he was busy today, and hadn't had a minute to stop on his way



more time, i'll give, to others , he'd say................



but the fact is, he died and faded from view and all that was left when the living was through,
was a mountain of things, he intended to do ..................tomorrow



</answer>



<asker's comment>



That's true life is measured by the good moments that we live



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Luci V
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 430 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



live a healthy lifestyle
don't smoke



be active socially... being around people and interacting with them gives older people something to look forward to each day
have a good outlook on life (if you don't then chances are its going to show in your body's ability to fight off certain infections)
and you're right keep on smiling ..smiles are one of the few things in life that are contagious but that are still good for you



Source(s):



my great grandmother lived to be 113 years and when I asked her the same question this is the answer that she gave me



</answer>



<answer from>



phoenixc...
Member since: 09 November 2006
Total points: 5234 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The best way is to become as aware and enlightened as possible.



For example, one of the most important things is to live in the moment - and, "BE HERE NOW!" You still plan for the future but you must live as much as possible in the moment.
Learn from the lessons lived from your past, but do not dwell there - especially upon negative events. The past does not really exist except as a somewhat fuzzy, faded and distorted memory. It exists in your mind alone and it is you that always brings it back. It is usually a vast waste of time and energy.



The same with the future, it is always unfolding into our NOW moments, but we can never know or see them before they happen. Worrying is not only a great waste of time and energy, it actually shortens life.



Live life to the fullest, enjoy every day as if it were your last and savour every moment of you eternal NOW moments.



Finally, get outside of "self" by focusing and loving others unconditionally.



Source(s):



Readings in psychology, philosophy and spirituality; and, personal life experiences.



</answer>



<answer from>



B33R
Member since: 12 June 2008
Total points: 317 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i'd like to cite a little text:



"Once there was a man, who was always happy, you never saw him worry or be sad. All the people around him wanted to know his secret, so they asked him.
He said "When i'm sitting, i'm sitting. When i'm standing up, i'm standing up. When i'm walking, i'm walking. When i'm running, i'm running."
All the people where rather disappointed and weren't really happy about this answer. One man said "But when we're sitting, we're sitting too! but yet we aren't as happy as you!"



So the old man corrected him:
"Your wrong, young man. Your problem is, that when you're sitting, you're thinking of standing up. When you're standing up, you're thinking of walking. When you're walking, you're thinking of running."



Live the moment.



</answer>

<question>



Question i'm still pondering...?



G'day mate..
a question i been ask,but i still can't found the solution...
here we go..
Thirteen teachers are in Paradox, New York attending a math conference. When they arrive at the Enigma Hotel to check in, they are told that only 12 rooms are available. Since their school had made reservations for 13 rooms, the teachers are a bit upset that they will have to find another place to stay. As they are preparing to leave and find another hotel, the manager comes out and asks if there is a problem. When she hears of their situation she assures them that the Enigma Hotel has enough space to accommodate each teacher in his or her own room. She takes two of the teachers to room #1 and promises to come back in a few minutes and take one of them to another room. She takes the third teacher to room #2, the fourth teacher to room #3, the fifth teacher to room #4 and so on, taking the twelfth teacher to room #11. She then returns to room #1 and escorts the extra teacher waiting there to room #12. All of the teachers are now happily settled in their own rooms. Is this possible? Why or why not?



</question>

<question from>



Red Phantom
Member since: 30 June 2007
Total points: 5489 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



What do you think of this Haile Selassie quote and its application to America and religion?



“Outside the kingdom of the Lord thee is no nation which is greater than any other. God and history will remember your judgment.”



</question>



<answer from>



guru
Member since: 07 April 2007
Total points: 12261 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The quote is in direct conflict with the concept of national pride. To be proud to be from any nation, one must consider themselves 'better than' those of another nation. The quote suggests that we are all equals and not to treat each other as equals has its consequences.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tangle Elfshimmer
Member since: 30 March 2006
Total points: 3372 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I like it. I think what it is saying that we are all ONE.



</answer>

Tusia

<answer>



Good question. Try to look at the facts objectively, try to look objectively at your own and other people's thoughts, feelings and actions related to those facts, and make unbiased conclusions about how our minds, emotions and reality interact. Think of what you observe, in other words. And compare your conclusions to the existing phylosophy. And maybe you can improve it. In any case, you will improve\enhance your own understanding of what the guys before you were talking about, which is an advantage in itself.



</answer>

Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



Annie Biznatch
Member since: 19 January 2008
Total points: 743 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What is social darwinism?



</question>



<answer from>



minu
Member since: 16 January 2008
Total points: 1064 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



survival of the socially adaptable, death of the socially inept



</answer>



<answer from>



Little Miss ♥Cutie♥™
Member since: 17 January 2008
Total points: 20601 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Comics & Animation



</answer from>



<answer>



Darwin proposed that Evolution would select for organism and creatures whose genes would enable them to best cope and adapt to the changing environment around them. Those that survive or were more adaptable would thrive and past their genetics onto their offsprings and those offsprings would thrive and populate in the new environment.
In simple terms "survival of the fittest"



Social Darwinism is a perversion of Darwin's Evolution concept, "Survival of the fittest" and applying it to people via social status class, race and creed, and financial-economic stature. It had nothing to do with genetics nor actual evolution, although people who used it try to pretend to be scientific in their excuse.



Examples:



a rich wealthy person deserves to live longer than a poor person, hence access to health care services and organ transplant should be given priority.



a white person should not marry someone of a different color, culture or creed, because he/she would be diluting his/her superior genetics.



a man is superior to a woman, women process weak whimsical genetics that make them incapable of wise decisions such as voting and politics.



</answer>



<answer from>



theorego...
Member since: 15 April 2006
Total points: 5003 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is an odd question ......but i like it so i'm gonna give it a try here.
#1. Either everybody agrees with Darwin: or
#2. Everybody wants to agree with Darwin: or
#3. those who are socially agreeable are the majority and the others simply die off  (which is impossible)
#4. Everybody agrees that Darwin was an idiot and so they all gather in a stadium and have Darwin "pun-offs" and the winner gets a trophy that gets better and more hi-tech each year.



Source(s):



obviouly it has to be this way!



</answer>



<answer from>



Russ DG
Member since: 16 December 2007
Total points: 1894 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Social Darwinism is a theory that principles of natural selection and survival of the fittest that apply to individuals and groups (villages, states, countries, etc.) also drive social evolution of the species in the groups.



In generic sense, it can apply to all sociable species but most often it is used in reference to human species. After all social evolution of human species is the most advanced and interesting to study. Social Darwinism expands the study to social aspects like politics, economics, ideas/ideologies, cultures, etc. even morals and values.



There are many other theories on social changes but Social Darwinism has a unique characteristics derived from Darwin's biological evolution principles. For example, it theorizes that the social evolution may accumulate/enhance physical and mental strengths of individuals in the society that over a long period of time the species themselves could be considered changed.



</answer>

<question>



Does moral philosophy rest on a mistake?

<original file>8.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk81661.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



Simply United
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 11961 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</question from>



<question>



Can anything be considered good or bad without referring to the consequences?



Thanks for your thoughts!



</question>



<answer from>



epiphany...
Member since: 28 May 2008
Total points: 831 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



you can make a moral assumption on good/bad in some situations based on the nature of the action rather than what affect it'll have



edit



no actually becuase your assumption would have sprung from what you percieve the consequences to be or from previous experience/knowledge



</answer>



<answer from>



boozemus...
Member since: 24 June 2006
Total points: 2111 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



words can be bad, not because of their consequences (they are like all words in that they are simply a string of morphemes put together and assigned a particular meaning). In the case of a bad word, its 'badness' is intrinsic to it, coming from the meaning assigned to the word, not because of what happens when we say the word. The consequences of saying a bad word come *because* the word is bad.



Im having a hard time thinking of an example for good, but if i do ill edit my response



</answer>



<answer from>



TR
Member since: 19 October 2006
Total points: 25001 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, yes.  There are two main types of ethics: consequentialist, and non-consequentialist.



The consequentialists are the ones who look at outcomes--those are the utilitarians, the hedonists, the epicureans.



Some non-consequentialists look at moral authority, such as Christian ethicists or Kant's moral philosophy.  Others fall into the "virtue ethics" category, where they presume that if a person simply possesses or cultivates the proper virtuous traits, the consequences of the person's actions will be proper; Aristotle and Phillipa Foot contribute to this category, along with the absolutely untrustworthy, self-indulgent, un-virtuous William Bennett.



</answer>



<answer from>



Gavin R
Member since: 08 February 2008
Total points: 10101 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is at the core of the dispute between the absolutists and the relativists. For the absolutists, something is good because God said it was, and wrong for the same reason. They won't take into account consequences - if it is morally right in their view, the consequences don't matter, even if it means that hundreds of thousands of people will die.
Relativists deny that morality comes from God. The Relativists have a somewhat flexible view of morality. Times change and people change, and relativists take this into account. For them the results matter a great deal.
However, both sides have serious problems. The absolutists tend to be crusading fanatics, whereas relativism can slip into the view that morality is all a matter of opinion. Since one person's opinion is as good as anyone else's, the whole thing is a tangled mess, so why not just live for yourself?
For thinking people these arguments are quite a knot.



Source(s):



Amateur philosopher



</answer>



<answer from>



astra.ma...
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 492 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Of course! Actually, whether something is good or bad does not even rely on its consequences.



I mean, you cheat in a test and don't get caught and do alright. No bad consequences! But is that "good" then?



You pick up money on the ground and return it to the wrong person without knowing. The consequence is bad - someone lost their money, but does that mean that the action of returning money is bad?



So I don't think anything can be judged by its consequences.



</answer>



<answer from>



naguru
Member since: 07 August 2007
Total points: 6588 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



Psychology



Mental Health



</answer from>



<answer>



Any action or deed can be either good or bad. Good or bad is decided based on the intentions and motives behind each action.



For instance, a knife is being used by a Surgeon Doctor for curing the patient and removing certain unwanted substance in the body or rectifying the area. The same knife is used by a murderer to kill. The action in both cases ins use of knife.



In the first case the intention is clearly to cure  the patient. In the second case, it is for ulterior motive. So, any action can be either good or bad based on the intentions and motives behind that action.



Source(s):



own



</answer>



<answer from>



kyala c
Member since: 24 January 2007
Total points: 6931 (Level 5)

<answer from>



small
Member since: 21 September 2006
Total points: 35221 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



Good question!!



It is indeed consequence that defines good or bad...... that is why good and bad are always relative to the obtaining circumstances that have an impact on the outcome. Does that mean that good and bad need to be determined only post facto? That would be evaluation of the result rather than the action itself. In order to avoid this dilemma, we decide on the basis of expected outcome which in any case is based on past experiences and our conviction that the cause and effect relationship is inviolable. Incidentally, I have answered for good and bad in the general sense as applicable to any individual rather than in the moral or ethical sense that relates to the wider social context.



</answer>



<answer from>



elenchus...
Member since: 25 June 2007
Total points: 233 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think that in so far as anything exists, it is good.  What are the consequences of being a molecule or a mountain or a man or the Divinity itself?



I've heard that good and evil are in human acts and the consequences of those acts.  I also know that Kant argued that the only thing that is good in and of itself is a good will --- although Genesis mentions that God looked at everything He created and exclaimed that it was very good, whereas the human will to know the difference between good and evil caused a ton of evils, including death as the consequence of that desire/will to know the difference.



So what can I conclude?



Shouldn't a fella at your level of Answering questions, be answering this question, rather than asking it?



Kevin

<answer from>



Smile =D
Member since: 24 July 2007
Total points: 7263 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



When I think of good/bad, the most obvious bad action is killing someone and the most obvious good action is being kind to someone.



When i think further, i think of actions as good/bad as defined by society and the law. but sometimes, in the grey areas, im forced to use my brain to judge.



and when i judge, i dont judge of the consequence alone. i consider all points: the intention, the action, the consequence.



for me personally, i always think the intention is the main big difference that can change the good/bad standing of the case. reason being my intentions are usually good (to help somone) but i normally balls thing up with a consequence being somone not talking to me. obviously i went wrong somewhere, but that doesnt make the action bad. just very poorly conducted.



so on a personal level, yes. things can be good or bad without referring to consequence. simply refer to intention.



many muslims believe that we will be judged on the day of judgement by our intentions.



thanks for the thought =)



but to judge intention, we need to base it on something. i normally base it on what my morals and logic tell me. i dont rely totally on religion or the law to tell me if something is right or wrong.



and where do i get my morals and logic from? well that would be the world around me =)



</answer>

<original file>123.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk82392.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



psychicb...
Member since: 01 January 2007
Total points: 349 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Descartes Proof Of God?



I think I have to be the worst philosophy student alive!  Lmao.  I think I must read Meditations over a thousand times and I still don't get it this one part. I even went to a weekend workshop that how bad I am. But all they did was read it over but really explain it in detail. Which Is what I need. So I'm asking all you smart people here on Yahoo Answers.  You helped me name my son and decorate my new bedroom apartment so why not this? Lol.



Anyway can someone explain to me  Descartes proof of God's in his 3rd and 5th mediation. I'm just little unclear. I understand to a point but not enough that I can participate in any class discussion's without feeling like I'm making a fool out of myself. And I'm a honors student here! :(



Thanks in advance. I really appreciate it.



Dee.



</question>



<answer from>



Katie
Member since: 17 July 2008
Total points: 780 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The Ontological Argument offered to us through Meditations 1-6 sum up to say that God necessarily exists. Because Descartes had the IDEA of God, there must be a God to receive that idea from. The definition of God at such point of writing was "that greater than which can be conceived." In other words, something greater than you can imagine.



Descartes riddles on about God's 'objective reality'--the representational qualities and content that make up the idea of God. God is explained to be infinite, independent (was not created), supremely powerful, supremely beneficient, supremely intelligent, and the creator of everything. All six of these qualities added up to be the idea/concept of "Perfection".



So this brings us back to the Ontological Argument, also often referred to as the "Inheritance Idea".



God exists---&gt;God is perfect---&gt;God is not a deceiver---&gt;Therefore the Light of Nature (God) can be trusted.



It is kind of a bad argument because Descartes does not go on to tell how theories against the existence of God are wrong.



There is also the explanation of the problem of Evil. If God is supremely good, one would assume that there is a supreme Evil to balance it out, right?
However, Descartes explains that: If God is supremely benevolent and supremely powerful, then he wants there to be no evil, and there is non.
Mistakes are false judgments, and free will allows mistakes.



Fuuuuurthermore.



You will likely, (and hopefully), discuss in class something that Descartes mentions nearly obsessively: minds & bodies. Descartes is a Dualist, and believes that the two substances the world is made up of are minds and bodies, and humans are the only creatures with minds.
I'm not sure if it's discussed in the fifth or sixth meditation, but there is a mind-body problem. How are they connected? Unfortunately, all Descartes says about this are that they are tightly joined, yet separate.
Many philosophers over the centuries have tried to come up with the ideas of how minds and bodies are connected.



Okay, I'm tired of writing... so... if you have any more questions, you can email me.
: )



Source(s):



Descartes' Meditations 1-6



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you so much! That really cleared it all up for me! :) I really appreciate the help. The Mind and Body dualism is tomorrow's lecture so I'm really excited now that I know something in advance and will be able to participate. I really owe you one!



Dee.



</asker's comment>

<answer from>



lazy bum

<answer>



Grow up. That's how you manage it. The world does not necessarily think the same way you do. To you something may sound good, but to another it may not. Get used to that, because that's pretty much what life is all about. If someone disagrees with your point of view, there's not a doggone thing wrong with them--or the disagreement. It only means they AREN'T YOU. You're being extremely immature, and if you ever want to be listened to as a reasonable adult, you should learn to tolerate differences in opinions and viewpoints. Otherwise, you'll have this problem for the rest of your life, and you'll be pretty miserable.



</answer>

<question>



What is life without love?



what would it be like!



</question>



<answer from>



Regina O
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 2670 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



A life without love is no life at all



You would still be living but it would be a miserable existence for many.  Love keeps us happy, its a reason to stay alive, it gives us a purpose, it makes us feel like we're wanted, it gives us hope and peace.  Without love we would be lonely, very lonely, especially if you're talking about the absence of a family's love, a husband/wife's love, friend's love, pets love, people love, etc.  There would be no one to share your life with, you want to enjoy the pleasure and joy of life with someone otherwise you're just living for yourself and you're alone.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank you so much for your anwer!



</asker's comment>

Once love enters your life, that's when you realise the power of it, and the need of it. It then becomes a necessity and you cant live without it, coz  it adds that jazz to your life.



</answer>

<question>



Why do you you think desire and belief in oneself is important to accomplishing goals?



</question>



<answer from>



Dawn L
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 168 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



First, without desire there would be no goals.  Belief in oneself is the same thing (kind of) as confidence.  You need desire to have goals and confidence in yourself to carry those goals out.  If you don't believe in yourself, you will never meet any of your goals because you will not even try.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



valer
Member since: 26 November 2007
Total points: 167 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think people feel a responsibility to themselves to believe in themselves because they understand that other people won't....and don't HAVE to. We've grown accustomed to being failed by people around us for whatever reason, so if nobody else is going to push us to achieve our goals or believe that we can do anything, the only people we have left is ourselves.



We can't blame others' unbelief in us for our failures. We can, however, blame our own.



</answer>



<answer from>



Real American Against Socialism
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 170 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you have no desire then you have no reason to reach your goal.  Only problem, desire comes and goes, it is a feeling.  One must also have discipline.  You much also believe in yourself because without that you will quit when it gets tough.



</answer>

<answer from>



jac the hat
Member since: 25 May 2006
Total points: 13350 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes this is what I balance my life around - the uncertainty principle I am really happy not to know, it feels such a safe place - I most often dont need to know.



I can see it is damaging for others to know - It always surprises me when people say they will never cross a picket line - I always think 'never' is a big word and there might well one day be a reason for me why I would cross a picket line.



Psychologically a fixed position is probably fine whilst your e on the winning side but when  the man made psychological edifice crumbles with the weight of introjects needing support the mind is at risk.



I suppose this could be borne out in the 19th century english social history - when the working class didn't get their political demands met they turned to religion.



</answer>

<question from>



Morpheus
Member since: 30 May 2008
Total points: 79 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



For those of you who watch artificial Intelligence?



~Is David a person?
~Do the swintons have the moral obligation for the care and well being of David?
~Does society have the moral obligation for the care and well being of mechas?
~IS society justified in the way they treat mechas?
~If you were in the same situation of the Swinton family, what would you do and why?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



~Is David a person?
In the strictest definion no, but, A.I. asumed the "soul" doesn't exist, so, if all it takes for there to be a person is a complex enough brain, by that definition then yes he was.  Within the atheist context of the movie, yes, David was a person, if all it takes to make a person, is a complex enough brain.



~Do the swintons have the moral obligation to....
As a sentient being yes they did; they had no right to just discard him when they got their own son back.  Most white Americans have the attitude of "its mine; I can do whatever the hell I want with it."  Well if we are gonna use that logic; Osama Bin Laden's terrorists are his, he can do whatever the hell he wants with them.  Right?  Its hard to put that logic into words, but I'm sure my illustration made the point clear as to the moral obligation of the Swintons.
~Does society....
Here is my most cold hearted answer; for the environment's sake, yes.  Using and discarding mechas like that created gross amounts of pollution.  Some of the most dangerous objects to the environment, the biggest land and river killers, are none other than computers.  Computers as complex as mechas would do unbelievable harm to the environment and the irresponsible manner in which they were discarded was not just disgusting, it was also dangerous and stupid.  A single mecha probably had enough toxins in it to kill half a forest; the chemistry involved to make just one of those things has to be complex right?
~Society justified?
Am I justified for taking a dump in the glass I use 5 minutes later to drink milk out of without removing the feces first?  Again, this goes back to the environmental issues; more because of an environmental argument, than their, ah, "humanity," I would be for sanitary disposal of the mechas at least, and to satisfy emotional people, painless deactivation.
~I probably would have had David deactivated; knowing full well he would outlive all of my family, crap man, put him out of his misery!  I mean, the argument regarding David comes down to the same arguments regarding abortion; a woman cold hearted enough to do that, should not be breeding to start with so I say let her do it, let women have a choice.  Rather than have the state Penn fry her serial killer son, as evil women raise evil men, it is better if she did law enforcement's job well before any lives were taken.  A woman, can badly wreck the emotions of a man if she has had a lifetime to do damage to him; if there is a blood relation, the damage has got to be unreal.  Me?  I suffered from abuse by a psychotic whore all my life, but I can be cold hearted about it and brush it off, simply because we are not blood relatives.  Now, if it was my own biological mother who did to me what that psycho did crap man, let me tell you, I would probably be hurting, and BAD.  Probably bad enough to be a serial killer; when someone unrelated does something, it hurts, but only a superficial level you will eventually forget unless its something serious like rape, however when a blood relative does something bad and hurtful to you, it can smart for years.  The fact that I am not a criminal psychopath in prison from having canibalized someone is one of the ways I knew, suspected, a long time ago, that we were not related, figuring that if we were, the abuse would hurt badly enough, to make me angry enough to actually kill.  However I have not done that, and I still have my sanity, at least most of it.



I know from bitter experience that sometimes it is better to not be even born, especially with malicious baby stealing ashkenazi whores running around; I swear to God man, ANY ashkenazi woman gives me crap, I will f*cking destroy her, tear her f*cking head of verbally.  After what one of them did to my mom, I am not ready to take bratty b*tch **** from ANY of them.  Israeli and American Jewish men may be big enough p*ssies to bend over and take it, but I sure as hell won't.



My situation, was indeed very similar to David's in fact I think my real name is David.  As someone who can speak for the character, more or less, I say, he should have been shut down.  There are people out there, who would psychologically abuse me, and physically assault me, knowing what happened to me, what was done to my family but its alright though, its alright; I am almost hoping they will physically assault me so that I can cut loose.



Sorry about that; the movie made my blood boil, with me it hit a little too close to home.



</answer>

<question from>



Sweet Lux, Apple of Sin

<question>



Do you ever think that some philosophical doctrines are vague enough ?



As if they make no sense....?



</question>



<answer from>



Trip Fontaine
Member since: 27 September 2008
Total points: 215 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm sorry, what did you say? Trip got distracted by those legs ..... do they go on forever? ...



Source(s):



Trip wants you.



</answer>



<answer from>



Clo is a smart Turkey
Member since: 04 June 2008
Total points: 5600 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Etiquette



</answer from>



<answer>



No. I am not an expert in Philosophy but whenever I read something related to it and I don't understand the concept, I do my research and it's funny but so far, any explanation I have found, makes perfect sense. Of course, each description of any philosophical word, means something different to each person.



</answer>



<answer from>



TR
Member since: 19 October 2006
Total points: 25058 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Kierkegaard, anyone?



I think that there's a level of vagueness that seduces the reader, one that makes the philosophy flexible enough to conform to many readers' personal biases.



It's also true that professors like to have big, complicated stuff to lecture about.  How are you going to go on for 50 minutes at a time if the philosopher's primary writings are no harder to understand than a cookbook?



So I don't think that they make NO sense--but that their vagueness does fill a desire for some readers.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cosa Nostra
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 923 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm sorry, what did you say? Cosa Nostra got distracted by Trip's answer ...



Source(s):



Cosa Nostra is looking for you.



</answer>

<question from>



I am Father of God worship me
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 82 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Philosophy and Science Students please explain me How  Sun do Stuggle with his Gravitational force whole life?



i know that sun conversts 600 million tons of hydrogen into 595 millions tons of helium in one second



but i not understand how sun do struggle with his graviation force whole life



please explain me in most simple way friends



</question>



<answer from>



elenchus...
Member since: 25 June 2007
Total points: 289 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Philosophy and Science Students please explain (to) me How (the)Sun do Stuggle (struggles) with his (its) Gravitational force whole life?



i know that sun conversts 600 million tons of hydrogen into 595 millions tons of helium in one second.



COMMENT:
Wow!  If that is a true statement the sun converts 5 million tons of mass completely into energy every second.  Destroying about 4 or 5 ounces of mass blew Hiroshima and Nagasaki out of existence in World War II.  Just think what would happen if the sun's gravity did not hold the sun together by preventing it from blowing apart.  About 8 minutes after our huge "natural hydrogen fusion bomb" blew itself apart, the effects of such an explosion would reach earth and blow earth apart as the atom bombs did to 2 Japaneze cities in WWII.



They weren't even hydrogen fusion bombs.  Just nuclear fission bombs.  Hydrogen fusion bombs are exponentially more powerful.



QUESTIONER:
but i not understand how sun do struggle with his graviation force whole life.



ANSWER:
It's matter of the balance between a hydrogen bomb's explosive outward pressure and the enormous gravitational forces which tend to make our sun collapse into a black hole.  The balanced and counteracting forces result in a nice round hydrogen bomb that does not blow itself apart and does not collapse into a black hole.



ASKER:
please explain me in most simple way friends



ANSWER:
That is the best/simplest I could do.  Doesn't your monikor suggest that you really don't need simple explanations?



Source(s):



No sites.  I took some Physics courses (when the sun had a heck of a lot more mass than it does now --- way more mass).



</answer>

thanks buddy nice answer



</asker's comment>

<answer from>



Happy Hiram
Member since: 28 March 2008
Total points: 11586 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Look for self-forgetting below:



Lord, make me a channel of thy peace,
Where there is hatred, I may bring love;
Where there is wrong, I may bring forgiveness;
Where there is discord, I may bring harmony;
Where there is error, I may bring truth;
Where there is doubt, I may bring faith;
Where there is despair, I may bring hope;
Where there are shadows, I may bring light;
Where there is sadness, I may bring joy.



Lord, grant that I may seek rather to comfort than to be comforted;
To understand, than to be understood;
To love, than to be loved.



For it is by self-forgetting that one finds.
It is by forgiving that one is forgiven.



That is my answer: self-forgetting.



</answer>

<answer>



Technology always has a good and a bad trade off.



Even when writing was invented, it had the negative effect of taking away oral tradition. This does not necessarily make the technology good or bad, but you have to way the pros and cons.



Computers: getting people addicted to online gambling, or allowing underprivileged to access materials to allow them to learn, like MIT's OpenCoureWare or the Project Gutenberg online library?



It's all a trade off.

<answer>



There are always two sides of a coin. While technology has enabled us to do things faster, as well as communicate with people across the globe, it has reduced our quality of life too. Do you ever notice that because of the efficiency that comes with using computers to do our assignments/work, we put more pressure on ourselves to perform even faster? And do you ever notice that because we are so readily contactable all around the hours 24/7, we get less rest time and get occupied even more?



</answer>

<answer from>



toogethr
Member since: 05 July 2006
Total points: 11158 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes you do need a thesis.  What you have posted as your question is very confused.  Science and Morality are two separate and entirely different things.  It is not the purpose of Science to save human kind (what ever that means).  Save it from what?  Morality does focus more on human kind but it is more directed at how to live peacefully in a society - again not the 'saving' of it.  Science deals with learning about the natural - meaning the real physical - world that we live in and are a part of.  It might be a true statement to say that Science can't save humanity, but that is deceptive because Science doesn't even seek to do that.  Its like saying the game of Golf can never find the cure for cancer.  That is a true statement, but Golf doesn't seek to find a cure for cancer so what is the point of saying that?



</answer>
