<original file>13119.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk86772.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



EP
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 89 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What are the theories of Ontology?



I have a philosophy test today and i hate this class, my professor makes it so boring and confusing. anyways, he mentioned that he is going to give us an essay about 4 Theories of Ontology, i can't find them anywhere, can someone PLEASE help me , thank you



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Basic theories of ontology
The spectrum of ontology research spreads from account of existence in the world by philosophers to building models of concrete targets by computer scientists. In spite of its wide spectrum, each enterprise needs firm and sound basic theories such as mereotopology, theory of identity, and theory of dependence. All the three theories collectively provide us with guidlines in building concrete ontologies of interest and in investigation of definitions and operation of basic semantic links such as is-a, part-of, instance-of. Thus, the three theories play important roles not only in the basic research but in application settings.



We are currently involved in establishing an ontological semantic theory of semantic links. The following are the current topics of interest:



What is the difference between instance-of and member-of links(a class　and a set)?



What is the difference between is-a and part-of links?



What is the difference between meta-object and super-sub relations(instance-of and is-a)?



How many types of part-of links do we need?



What is an instance of a relation?



Can't the concept of "husband" have an instance?



Source(s):



http://www.ei.sanken.osaka-u.ac.jp/engli...
(there is alot more info here)



</answer>










<original file>13121.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk86775.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



spokenfo...
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Construct a proof.... HELP!?



1. (~K & N) &gt; [(~P &gt; K) & (~R &gt; G)]
2. K &gt; N
3. ~N & B
4. ~P v ~R /G



it should take six lines



</question>



<additional details>



I checked the problem again, and I've copied it down correctly. ?



</additional details>



<answer from>



CogitoEr...
Member since: 11 July 2007
Total points: 8264 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Mathematics



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Im pretty sure something is wrong with your premises.



The only way to arrive at G is is through Disjunctive Syllogism in K∨G with a ~K.



The only way to arrive at K∨G is through Constructive Dilemma in
(~P ⊃ K) • (~R ⊃ G) and ~P∨~R. You already have the latter of the two.



The former of the two can only be proven via Modus Ponens in a true antecedent. But the antecedent is obviously false, since it is a conjunctive statement and N is false.  We know N is false because ~N is a conjunct in your third premise



See that? G is hidden in only one spot... in the consequence of a conditional.  Since the premise is false, there is no way to assert the truth value of the consequence



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks to all contributiors! No wonder I was so confused!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



bigsky_5...
Member since: 08 January 2007
Total points: 15701 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Cogito ran into the same problem I faced.  I notice that B is a premise that is simply stated but plays no role in the rest of the argument.  Did you perhaps forget to include a premise that involves B?



</answer>



<answer from>



Philo
Member since: 05 March 2006
Total points: 28252 (Level 7)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<question>



The pursuit of happiness?



in your opinion, do you think the 'pursuit of happiness' is just that? always a chase without an end? do you truly think that you can find complete and total happiness with another person 'forever' ? or with anything for that matter.



</question>



<additional details>



it just seems a lot of people are too scared to follow their heart and what they truly feel...so in turn they aren't satisfied or happy...i don't look as life at ending in happiness, i think it's a journey, lessons learned along the way..joy and sadness...just wanted to hear some other people



</additional details>



<answer from>



milly_19...
Member since: 11 May 2006
Total points: 50510 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Horoscopes



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



~*~ Happiness ~*~
*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*
"Happiness is like a crystal,
Fair and exquisite and clear,
Broken in a million pieces,
Shattered, scattered, far and near.
Now and then along life's pathway,
Some shining fragments fall;
But there are so many pieces
No one ever finds them all.
You may find a bit of beauty,
Or an honest share of wealth,
While another, just beside you
Gathers honour, love, or health.
Vain to choose or grasp unduly,
Broken is the perfect ball;
And there are so many pieces
No one ever finds them all.
Yet the wise, as on they journey,
Treasure every fragment clear,
Fit them as they may together,
Imagining the shattered sphere,
Learning ever to be thankful,
Though their share of it is small;
For it has so many pieces



No one ever finds them all."
*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*
Reach for your Happiness!



Love & Blessings



Milly



</answer>



<asker's comment>



that's just about as true as it gets :)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Robert K
Member since: 18 May 2008
Total points: 5001 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The way you ask the question offers limited options.  Yes, you can pursue happiness, but there's absolutely no guarantee that you're going to find it, and, let's face it, a lot of people don't.  From what I can tell, our lives are works-in-progress, and maybe we're a bit naive in thinking that we should be looking for an end point in which we'll always be happy; maybe what life is about is enjoying the ride, and being as happy as we can with whatever problems and opportunities life offers to us.  If you're willing to unconditionally love, and most people aren't willing to do that, then, yes, you can have happiness with another person forever.  It really helps to love others if you love yourself first.  It's also possible to love yourself, others and everything else that exists in creation.  After all, what do we really know about our capacity to love?



</answer>



<answer from>



Happy Hiram
Member since: 28 March 2008
Total points: 14009 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



You have happiness, the emotion confused with the phrase "the pursuit of happiness" which means freedom to live your life as you see fit.



Happiness is an emotions, "the pursuit of happiness"  is a social contract. Following your heart has everything to do with the second one and nothing to do with the first one.



</answer>



<answer from>



Dawn L
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 604 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am going to give the most simplistic answer possible.



You walk by Bloomingdale's and gaze in the window.  You see something that catches your eye.  (It may not even be sold there - just a window prop.)



You think to yourself - I want that.  You save up, track the item down, buy it and bring it home.  Do you like the way it looks once it's in your home?  Did you stop looking in the Bloomingdale's window?  Are you satisfied with that item and now don't have to buy anything else ever again?



How many times have you thought you wanted something and then once you had you realized it wasn't what you'd thought it would be?  The perfect guy for you turns out to be not so great after all?  Those shoes that would go perfectly with that dress just didn't seem to really work out like you wished.  That fantastic job became mediocre at best.  That trendy bag stopped being trendy the minute you bought it.  You can apply the same logic to material goods as to deep relationships - sometimes we think or hope things will be better than they truly are.  Sometimes we get bored with perfection and seek out something messy.



It isn't always about fear.  Sometimes the perfect thing today, isn't the perfect thing tomorrow.  Yesterday the perfect meal would have been down home Southern BBQ ribs and pulled pork sandwiches.  Today I'd rather have oyster Po'Boys and a salad.  Tomorrow, I think I'd like Thai food but I'll settle for a tunafish sandwich on seven grain bread (which is what I had today for dinner with miso soup).



The point is happiness is a state of mind.  It is very much a "now" phenomenon.  It doesn't matter if you were happy before.  What matters is how you feel now and what that will do for you later.  That's why happiness can seem so elusive.  It's not something you can plan on in advance.  It either happens in the moment or it doesn't.



</answer>



<answer from>



LadyBug
Member since: 19 November 2007
Total points: 22128 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Philosophy

Yesterday's Dream . . . Tomorrow's Memory."  That about sums it up for me.

<answer from>



Simply United
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 11961 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



It seems that all things have their specific purposes, and their own places, among all things: plants, animals, insects, microbes, ocean, land, clouds, wind and rain, all, as though all are connected to one common purpose, to one singular being; as though all forms and their subjective functions are but the manifestations of the purpose of one reality, and all performances, specific duties, special roles, and acts of specific meaningfulness, are within some grand unison of one universal design.



This is as if there are many strings of various lengths, and vibrations, or many keys of various notes, on an instrument, but in the mind of the virtuoso incognito all notes, their tones of vibrations, come together in a single symphonic rendering, of a jingle or a song. Then the jarring effects of natural causes that to human’s ear sound out of tune, barring human senses from its delight and appeasement, to the levels where, ease of thought, of a fantasy or a dream, begins to shatter, and breaks into pieces, the jitters of unanswerable questions, aiming at nowhere and pointing at nothing, but there all the time nevertheless, as the very reality of the mind.



There is nowhere in the universe to be found an existence questioning, perpetually perplexed, dubious, and marred by self-doubt, other than that of Man; all things except have their purposeful capacities, and no room for a questioning thought about what may lie beyond their nature, except for Man. Man would question, the human mind would explore possibilities beyond nature, beyond natural form and natural function of our heart and body and mind. Man alone have additional room for thought, for questioning, and the purpose of questioning seems to be to question all purposes, to find what might we have in us aside what nature has fixedly set.



We seek to know as what is the purpose of our being in this universe, and then with that, what is the purpose of the universe itself, of existence, and of life. These, and the questions like these, even before they are considered for any answering, I think, reveal a great deal about us, i.e. perhaps about the presence of the very thing that we feel is missing, the answers. We need answers, as the reason, of our being, ‘on this planet’.



Ø	We reason: if there are the questions then where are the answers?
Ø	We see that there is nowhere that answers are to be found, aside ourselves who at least have questions.
Ø	Then let us turn back, and meditate upon life, for the questions we have, a little longer.
Ø	As, why only we have the questions?
Ø	May be we are the answers ourselves, i.e. would we not find it amusing if the answer would be looking for itself, with a question standing in the way each time?



I think what hinders our searching is the same things spurs us along to find, the questioning mind that stand in between the mind exploring itself, between us and us waiting to be found, and in this the loftier the questions we ask the higher the expectations become that we have about ourselves. We would never be fed up being here, being alive, and being inquisitive, as all the searches in their ultimate points to us, and all the wildest paths of our searches are laid to eventually lead us back home.



</answer>

Poetic license. So, what is the difference between a story and a lie? If all stories and rhymes MUST be fact, we will lose most of the world's great literature.

<answer from>



cosmick
Member since: 30 May 2006
Total points: 1691 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Poetry is an art form and as such the whole point of poetry is that it simply SOUNDS good. And that is what people are supposed to appreciate. Of course the more impressive the poem is the more emotion it can evoke in the reader who might believe it. But the fact is it does not have to be factual at all.



In my mind, your question would get more nods if you substitute the word "poets" with journalists or politicians.



</answer>

<answer>



What makes you say that poets don't write the truth? Often poets express the grievances they face with their countries, such as social porblems, as well as their own issues with their family, culture, identity etc. I think poets are honest through their poems, if they seem otherwise, it is usually due to their deliberate use of sarcasm which seems to indicate the opposite view, even though they may mean an entirely different thing.



But anyway, if your question is not about poets, but it's about journalists, then yea there probably are more of such people in the media who tend to hide the hideous truth from others. But US journalists are pretty honest, I think, since they uncovered lots of scandals. =)



</answer>

<question from>



Marla S
Member since: 26 January 2008
Total points: 398 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How many Identities...?



How many identities can a person have? Are those thousands of nicknames we thousands of different personalities that we use on the internet, part of ourselves? Or are they only the expression on how we see ourselves? Or how we wish people to see us? And even if it was an illusion, isn’t it at the same time part of us, or maybe or real, hidden self, because we have created it in the first place?



</question>



<answer from>



dscharge
Member since: 30 March 2007
Total points: 435 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are 3 identities:
The one how the world sees you
The one how you see yourself
The one what you really are.



The first one could be different person by person.
The second one is your self-esteem
The third is how one would see if could see all.



As close these three are to each other as happy and confident you could be.



</answer>



<answer from>



Simply United
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 11984 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



There can be as many identities hidden or manifest of a person as many there are possibilities of interaction with an outside world. I think this could even be more that that, there could also be a separate identity for each things or a person we might have in our mind, as we by our very nature like to imitate to varying extents all things that we encounter, i.e. to see if we can fit in, or if something can in us, if we together can live in peace, is there danger, or a cause of concern, and if we are relatively better, if yes then how, lest we should be worse. These things and countless many more in our mind urge to interact with other things, but before that, observe and measure up.



This, in common sense, is just like the way we get dressed up for various reasons: for parties, for social gatherings, for outing, while with friends, and family, at work or play, we have various different costumes, robes, dresses, gears, kits and outfits that we discretely for different occasions. Our identities that we use for instance here on the net too server our various purposes, of various personas that are all but within ourselves in response to that world that we keep outside. Our identities are in fact aspect of our self that is called by a formal name; this is true.



</answer>

<original file>15225.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk89112.txt</current file name>




<category>



Arts & Humanities



Philosophy



</category>



<question from>



J
Member since: 10 March 2007
Total points: 182 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Neuroscience: Is there free will? Is there, then, accountability for one's actions?



In terms of the brain and neuroscience:
Is there free will? Is there, then, accountability for one's actions?



</question>



<answer from>



Brian B
Member since: 29 September 2007
Total points: 16493 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Mathematics



Chemistry



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



We don't know for sure whether or not free will exists. So far, no law of physics yet discovered has any conscious intelligence to it. Supposedly, then, the brain is just a very large system of interacting particles, and thus we are complicated chemical automata. In this case there is no such thing as free will. (However, if it is predetermined that a person will commit a crime, it is equally predetermined that that person faces consequences.) Then again, physics is not absolutely deterministic - there is a possibility that the basic element of free will is the uncertainty inherent in particle wavefunctions (viz. the Heisenberg uncertainty principle). What a fascinating possibility! You might read up on "quantum consciousness" if you're interested.



As far as pure neuroscience goes, there are two results that interest me (unfortunately I can't find these papers again):
* The action potential for a movement appears to occur a fraction of a second before the person consciously registers the will to perform that action (that is, the final decision to commit to that action). This suggests that perhaps we do indeed behave exactly as our chemical system is commanded by neurotransmitters and hormones, reducing us to automata - and that the conscious mind retrospectively interprets our actions, making us think that we have free will, or making us feel emotion (e.g. first you punch somebody, a split second later you think that you feel so angry at this person that you've just decided to be physically violent). However, I am not sure that the time at which a conscious decision is made can actually be measured - I would have to consult the literature.



* A test subject is told to randomly decide to either raise the left hand or raise the right hand. Predictably, lefties raise the left hand a bit more often than 50% of the time, and righties raise the right hand a bit more often than 50% of the time. But when an electromagnetic field is applied to the left side of the brain only, the test subject has a 80% chance of raising the right hand. So do we really have free will? Conceivably, a stronger magnetic field could effect mind control (raising one hand 100% of the time).



Think on this for a while...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks so much! very informative



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



titacabr...
Member since: 05 March 2006
Total points: 732 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



From the religious viewpoint, there is a free will and a person has accountability for his actions. We are given a free will to choose what you want in this life, whether it is good for you or bad for you. You are given a free will because you are responsible for what you see, to decide upon what goals you want to achieve and thus you are accountable for your decisions.



The scientific study of the nervous systems underwent a big increase in the second half of the twentieth century, due to revolutions in molecular biology, electrophysiology and computational neuroscience.  In terms of the brain and neuroscience, there is a continuing debate on the matter of free will or accountability of one's action.



Good luck to you.



Source(s):



Wikipedia.



</answer>



<answer from>



Happy Hiram
Member since: 28 March 2008
Total points: 14009 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Douglas Hofstadter, author of "I am a Strange Loop" and an expert on the workings of the brain, does not think free will is a feasible idea. I think he is being charitable.



I am not responisble for, but I am accountable for my actions.



</answer>

<question from>



twentyfo...
Member since: 13 June 2008
Total points: 1657 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



What category does this question fall under in philosophy?



Does the universe have a purpose? Does life have a purpose?



I do not want to attribute these questions to the wrong definition.  Metaphysics has to do with existence and being.  Epistemology has to do with theories of knowledge.



I was thinking my questions fall under epistemology, because it involves pursuing the truth concerning the purpose of life, is this correct?



For those that wanna know why I am doing a paper on these questions and although an A student philosophy is a challenging subject for me, but I really like it.



</question>



<answer from>



Brian
Member since: 08 April 2007
Total points: 10921 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



well im glad you like philosophy.



i think you messed up a bit on the definition of metaphysics. that's not quite what it is entirely. the definition you gave is actually a sub-branch of metaphysics called Ontology. the study of beings or what exists in this world. not even necessarily existence itself as a subjective experience. for that, i think, would be called existentialism. this deals with the typical "what is the purpose of life" type stuff, in trying to give meaning and value to it.



however a very similar question to your first question in dealt with in metaphysics. and that is "why is there something rather than nothing". its a bit different than what you're asking, but close.



</answer>



<answer from>



guru
Member since: 07 April 2007
Total points: 12241 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I wouldn't use the same standard in the question. Any object can be ascribed a purpose or a function. A rock is a rock. That rock can be used as a tool or as a weapon. We are the ones who describe what the function and purpose of an object.



The universe is not 'alive'. The universe lacks the basic features to be included as life.



Phenomenology may serve your question better?



</answer>



<answer from>



goodoldp...
Member since: 19 July 2007
Total points: 106 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



We are born to be happy, to enjoy life, to be responsible to ourselves and others, based on the law of cause and effect.  You cannot become happy, for instance, by making another person unhappy.  Orthodox buddhists call this the law of Nam myoho renge kyo...devotion to the ultimate reality through causes for harmony.  This is a question of life philosophy.



</answer>

<answer from>



YaddaYad...
Member since: 26 July 2008
Total points: 1247 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



If it has to be a choice between the two, choose the happiness.



Money doesn't make people happy, It can only enhance your happiness if you are already a happy person.



It's all about knowing yourself, what troubles you.
Some people have pains and voids so deep, they look to the money and the things it can buy. They try to fill the voids with material things, but these are just temporary distractions and sometimes addictive highs (like food or drugs) and then sometimes crash and burn.



On the other hand, if you are already a happy, joyful person who finds their completeness in other things- like God or education or love or community service etc. etc.- money can give you more of an opportunity to expand your base and in that, you can be extremely fulfilled, but only if you use the money right.



In a nutshell, you have to first find happiness outside of money in order for money to make you happy.



To your question though, I would ask you if you are a happy person already.
If so, you have no need to be jealous. What you have is harder to come by than money. Maybe not the lottery, but if you plan a good idea and work hard at it, you can have money too, and you will actually appreciate and value it more because you made it yourself.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tiana✫
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 4666 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



A lot of people jump on this question and immediately say 'I choose happiness'. However, what if you already have happiness? Would you take the money if you won the lottery?



I would. Why not? I do not worship it (and never have), or take it for granted (very rarely maybe done that), or want it more than I want my happiness (who would choose money over God?), but it sure would help a lot of people who have nothing, wouldn't it?



Since I have the natural ability to share, and the knowledge that money (properly delegated) can be distributed to help others create a better life for themselves, I know that God would allow me to have possession of a large amount of money. He already knows what I would do with it. I do not care about 'worldly' anything. My gifts and rewards are waiting for me in a far better place than this!



ps. I am not jealous in the least... I am happy for your friend! If he won it, he probably had a need that God fulfilled with the lottery winnings.



</answer>

<answer from>



RIPPLE
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 165 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



why are there rules for your body? why do you have to pee, why do you sleep? why does your hair grow?



</answer>



<answer from>



Samwise
Member since: 01 November 2007
Total points: 9771 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Mathematics



</answer from>



<answer>



Which type of rules do you mean? The ones that say that if you dive off a high cliff onto rocks you won't survive? The ones that say if you chop off a hand it doesn't grow back? The earth, and we as a part of it, are just built a certain way, and our nature imposes rules.



Or do you mean the rules (as in laws or customs) imposed by people on other people? They're there because it's possible for a person who obeys no laws at all to make life unlivable for others. (Obviously, a murderer is an example.) So every society finds it necessary to make rules, and that means it has to come up with some decision-making process (voting, armies, religious obedience, whatever) to decide what the rules are, and then it has to come up with some way to impose them (jail, executions, fines, banishment, whatever).



Whether we're talking about the laws of nature and of physical consequences, or those of governments, religions and social customs, they are necessary tools for survival. Any society that ignored the need for them would not survive; hence, we have rules because we're descended from and part of a society that demonstrated the capacity to survive.



</answer>

<question from>



twentyfo...
Member since: 13 June 2008
Total points: 1657 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Can someone help me generalize this question in philosophy?



Does the universe have a purpose? Does life have a purpose?



I'm a first year philosophy student and lets say I have basic knowledge.  Now my question if it makes sense would be what would I reference these questions to, knowledge or existence?  I am asking because I truly do not know and I'm having a hard time.



So far I've come up with we know that the universe exist, because duh its here, so therfore these questions have to do with knowledge, or Epistemology?  Is this correct?



</question>



<additional details>



I'm not asking people to answer these questions but to categorize them for me.



I'm not asking people to answer these questions but to categorize them for me.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Josh
Member since: 11 May 2008
Total points: 234 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Actually, life is the only thing that has a purpose.



</answer>



<answer from>



Robert K
Member since: 18 May 2008
Total points: 5001 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Maybe the purpose of the universe is to exist the way it present it.  As for our lives, it seems to me that we most definitely have meaning and purpose to our existances on this planet.  In my experience, there's nothing more wonderful, important or powerful than love, and I'm just a beginner in finding out about this subject.  The fact that love is so powerful has led me in the direction of believing that we do have a purpose, and that purpose is to be the best human beings we can possibly be.  If you believe we have free will...and I do...then you believe we get to make all kinds of choices about our lives, including whether or not life has a purpose.  Best wishes in coming up with whatever set of answers work for you!



</answer>



<answer from>



Democrates for 911
Member since: 25 June 2006
Total points: 2741 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



well the real question you have to ask yourself is how do you know something exist? because you can see it and smell it and hear it and feel it? or does it exist because you believe it exist? 100 years ago the world was flat but we now know this to be false because we now have the tools to measure it. a dream can seem real we can feel it and see it, have you never woken from a dream strewn with emotion, does that not make a dream real? reality is all based on perception, perhaps the universe it self is nothing more than a dream, perhaps the universe is really nothing but a black hole and we are spinning endlessly in it?
The fact of knowing is never really a fact but rather popular opinion.



</answer>



<answer from>



Michelle L
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 117 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



These questions and your answers are all very different.



A universe existing and a universe having a purpose are two very different things. Your question was does it have a purpose? Ask yourself, what purpose does it serve for you?



Your next question is does life have a purpose? This question is to be answered differently by everyone; those who commit suicide think not, those on wall street believe it is to make the most money, those at home with a family believe it is to be happy. First decide what's important to you, then figure out what you believe your purpose to be.



I hope this helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



jtrusnik
Member since: 24 March 2007
Total points: 10181 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



You're on the right track, but you aren't quite there yet. The difference between what you're asking and epistemology is:



"Does the universe/life have a purpose?"
and:
"How do we know this?"



The second question is where you enter the realm of epistemology.



</answer>

"I am using an example from everyday life because of your human limitations. Just as you used to offer yourselves as slaves to impurity and to ever-increasing wickedness, so now offer yourselves as slaves to righteousness leading to holiness." (Romans 6:19)

<answer>



It means to:



1) Have the free will to choose good or evil.
2) To love or hate.
3) To fight or run
4) To seek truth or deny truth.
5) To learn or to remain ignorant.
6) To attempt to live a moral life or embrace immorality
7) To dedicate your life or wander aimless.
8) To accept responsibility or deny



9) To live for others or be a narcissist
10) To believe in God or Jesus or reject.



My 10
Bai

<answer>



No, forgiveness is something that comes from us, and it in no way implies that anybody is being encouraged to make mistakes or do anything else.  Simply because you find forgiveness in your heart for somebody doesn't mean that you have to give that person the same responsibilities or more ways that they can make mistakes.  If you know the person is mistake-prone, you can forgive them, but that doesn't necessarily mean that you have to be blind to their capacity to mess things up.



</answer>



<answer from>



Alice in Wonderbra
Member since: 20 December 2005
Total points: 46832 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



After much trying and betrayal and hurt, I concluded that anything "too.." is not right.  Balance to everything is of crucial importance.  Being too good is enemy to being good.  Being too easily forgiving is an enemy to forgiving.  Words and attitudes really lose their meaning when used in exaggeration . Teaching people is by no means punishment.  You cannot forgive someone but you can explain to him WHY you can't do so.  Explain what has really hurt you, explain that we are in all this together and if he keeps on doing evil things he will surely receive such behavior some time in his life..  I believe that the hardest lessons are the ones given with Love.  They are hard but are the only ones that really can make the other person better.



Relationships are not only peaches and cream....  Both parties should know that all kind of behaviors have consequences. The people we love are not garbage bins.  Patience has limits.  People have self respect.  And most of all, Love's color is not exclusively Pink.



Source(s):



</answer>

Dragon

<answer>



Sometimes people need to learn that what they have done really is a mistake, and that they are going to pay the consequences for it. Though it is more difficult in relationships than in governance to discipline/punish without anger becoming a factor, that is exactly what should be done -punishment/discipline should be an indication that they have done something wrong and need to correct their behavior, not an indication that they have angered you (which will only lead them to insure that they don't anger you, rather than correcting the behavior).



</answer>

<answer>



On the contrary, I think, being forgiving and good sets a good example for others to realize that we are all imperfect.  BUT, it doesn't mean we make ourselves tolerant of other's relentless wrong-doings.  Discipline is one thing, punishment is another.  People always have the chance to learn from their mistakes.  If the mistake made hurt themselves more than others, by chance, they may have already suffered the consequence of their own action. In that case, what good would it do them if we 'lash' them more?  They may be provoked to strike back,..and then what?  We may possibly retaliate,.. and before we know it, the little fire may have damaged more than expected.
But yes, we need people know if they have done mistakes. We can  tell them how grossly those mistakes can affect theirs, and others lives as well...and the call of the grimmest is in no one's hands to blame,...but theirs.



</answer>

Xavier L

<answer>



Dear P’quaint, please forgive me if my response is rude or distasteful to you.
I’ll just speak my mind and it’s going to sound contradicting.



Nobody is good enough for everybody, even my beloved teacher the Buddha and Mahatma Gandhi are good but yet not good enough to please the old and the new world.
Not everyone are able to see their goodness and instead their glory have attracted jealousy.



I commit deeds and face its consequence.
Others commit deeds and face its consequence.
There are always penalties and rewards depending on the deeds or misdeeds.
The contradicting part is, I am no one to forgive anyone yet I asked for your pardon if I hurt you. Being good and forgiving are not for expressing neither for impressing.
It’s simply for your own personal cultivation.



Your posted question has been lingering in my thought ever since I was a boy. It has made me quite a hot-temper guy, always ready to judge others, always ready to punish others. I cost me my happiness. And only the recent year have I manage to get out of it.



Who am I to judge, who am I to punish. I am not god.



Lastly, relationships are awarded to us still by means of our past deeds.



Good luck my dear lady.



Here’s one of my experience that I love to share with you.



I was brought-up in a typical traditional family where the young ones have to and must obey and respect the elders. (Sound just?)
My dad is the eldest son of his family, so after my grannies, my dad commands the most respect and authorities. In his 30s’, he’s a rich and successful businessman.



………………..To me, he’s a tyrant, a wife-beater, a child hitter, a drunken, a gambler, a playboy and ….an unreasonable arrogant. (Sound rude??hmm)
My eldest brother evolves as a tyrant too, expecting obedient from everyone younger than him. Taking into account that my dad and my eldest brother both, always thought that they are the wisest and cleverest in the family, if not the whole wide world. In their time, no one dare to oppose them.
Alone came an asshole, that’s me (sound familiar???), who never fail to oppose, argue and challenge them at my age of 9.
You can imagine how much trophy of bruises I have.
I’m not here to air my frustration, but to share with you this cute story.



For Almost 3 decades, my elder brother still insisted that he isn’t wrong. And sadly, his behavior got worse.



You may wish to be the punisher, but be warned of the above mention trophy.
You may wish to be the punisher, but be warned of being trapped in the sea of anger.
You may wish to be the punisher, but be warned that it costs you your happiness.



Oh, please forgive me for parking this story here.



smile



</answer>

First of all, I'm not sure where you get the idea that friendship is an occupation. As we go through life, we meet however many people we meet, and some of them become friends;  viewing that friendly relationship makes it sound like work.  Why would you want to have friendships based on that?

<answer>



A friend is a person who fulfills a need in you and one in which you fulfill a need in them.  A friend is somebody who stands by you and believes in you--right or wrong.  A friend is there FOR you, always.  You can call a friend in the middle of the night, even on a work night, and this friend, knowing you are upset over something, will wake up and talk to you, or listen to you talk, or cry.  Whatever the need is.



If a person is truly your friend they are there for you 24/ 7 /365.  No questions asked.  They love you in spite of your faults.  They are loyal to a fault.



THOSE are the characteristics of a true friend.  My mother always told me that you are lucky if you ever have three true friends in your life, and I  have been very lucky. The day she died I lost my best friend.

Me!  ddt

<question from>



PoetTheD...
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 82 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why are we born? Why is life the way it is? Is there a higher self or a God? Or are we Gods?



</question>



<answer from>



adagio58
Member since: 21 February 2008
Total points: 3682 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



&lt;Why are we born?&gt;
Because there is a purpose for our being here, whether it is [a] to gain more experience and become aware of our true selfhood, or [b] you can be here as a helper to others. We all serve in various ways to benefit mankind, everyone has a part to play in the scheme of things.



&lt;Why is life the way it is?&gt;
For those who are here to gain experience they must work through the good and bad times, difficulties come into our lives for a reason, and that is to teach us about ourselves. We learn and we grow. Now, if I did all your homework for you, would that make you a better person? Not really, because you haven't worked it out for yourself, so your understanding does not deepen and strengthen you thereby. It is necessary to face these challenges in life and find your strengths and weaknesses, plus to 'burn away' the dross and the sterling qualities will be what remains. It's a long journey we all must make.



&lt;Is there a higher self or a God?&gt;
Yes, you have a higher self and that is what you must discover when all else is said and done in your life. "Man, Know Thyself!"



No, there is no "a God" because that means a separate being, or entity, and God, the Infinite Presence is in no way separated from anything or anyone because He is the basis of all that is seen and unseen. To put it plainly, GOD IS LIFE, and you cannot divide Life. What is there to divide it by?



&lt;Or are we Gods?&gt;
If you don't mind, I'd like to quote the Bible:
"Ye are Gods" (Psalm 82, v. 6; and John 10, v. 34)
As I said, God is Life, and God the Universal Mind has formed us in His image and likeness, and this refers to our creativeness, for we also have the ability to create through our thought process when it is linked up to the Universal Intelligence. And this great Intelligence will consciously bring into your life whatever you hold as the deepest thought in your mind. This is something we have not yet fully understood - the processes of our thinking. And why? Because we've been too caught up in our reactions to life, people and things, and have not developed our inner being, our soul.



Well, enough said for this time.  ;- )



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Keep expressing your mind of knowledge wisdom and understanding.



</asker's comment>

<question>



How to buy Arabic books?



I am in the Army and in Iraq. An Iraqi friend of mine picks up trash on base for a living and has a political science degree. Due to extreme censorship in the middle east he has never heard of common but controversial ideas such as "atheism."



I'd like to buy him something on or by Epicurus, David Hume, Bertrand Russel or Ludwig Wittenstein but I am unable to find any of these books in Arabic.



It is thanks to the Arabians that much of western Philosophy was saved From the Church burning books such as Plato's Republic, or Lucretius Poems. I feel I have a debt to the Arabs to give them modern and old philosophy that their "church" is now burning that we are safeguarding for the world.



Where can I find such books?



</question>



<answer from>



hindisik...
Member since: 02 July 2007
Total points: 4139 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You would be putting his family in great danger.



I will nevertheless ask my father, now back in school for a degree in the philosophical and scientific works of the medieval Arab world, to tell me where he gets his copious tomes on Aristotle & Co. in Arabic.



The works you refer to exist in modern translations. God help the person wandering around the modern Arab world with such stuff in his possession.



More, soon.



</answer>

<answer from>



elenchus...
Member since: 25 June 2007
Total points: 275 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes they do.



But the funny thing is an experiment which some psychology researchers did with psychiatrists --- who are supposed to be experts on sanity vs. insanity.



The researchers recruited pairs of psychiatrists --- both fully qualified and "sane", as well as credentialed psychiatrists.



Then the researchers told both psychiatrists, individually, that they were about to interview an uncredentialed patient who was not a psychiatrist --- but merely "thought" he or she was a psychiatrist.



On the basis of their psychiatric interview of this "patient", who had been given a uniform and a badge that said he or she was "Dr. So and So" (to keep him/her from becoming too agitated on the ward) the researchers would decide whether or not to have this "patient" (who was actually a real "Dr. So and So; Psychiatrist" and not a patient) committed to the institution to "cure" him/her of his/her delusion.



Both actual psychiatrists were told the same "patient" story about the other psychiatrist, then both were told to go interview each other as "patients".  And the more that such actually credentialed psychiatrists interviewed each other --- each supposing that the other guy was an actual "patient" --- the more that each of the real psychiatrists "thought" that each other were "nuts".



I guess it was because "patients" are supposed to answer "the doctor's" questions, while doctors are supposed to ask the questions.  So each doctor refused to answer the other doctor's "personal" questions.



And anybody who only asks questions in answer to questions is considered "nuts" by most sane people.  Hence each pair of actual psychiatrists thought that the other "patient" (actual psychiatrist) was certifiably "crazy".



Kevin



Source(s):



A vague recall of Psych 101 or some such course.



</answer>

<question from>



banjaran

<question>



Is it true---Each breath feeds the fire of the heart. ?



Breath is the key to life and almost every spiritual discipline starts and ends with the breath



</question>

<question>



Anarchists please answer. Does it require a hatred of humanity to belief in anarchy?



I say this because without laws, people would be free to rape and murder and assault without punishment or without any apprehension. As a female, it is hard for me to comprehend why anyone would want it to be okay to do this to people. The only conclusion I came to is that they must hate people. is this true? Or is there a better reason?



</question>



<additional details>



Stamps, if you are not white, under an anarchist regime, what's to stop the Ku Klux Klan or a neo-nazi killing you or your whole family? Yes, many laws are unjust and not fair to many races but with no laws there would be no protection for anybody. You've hit a raw nerve here because the one thing I hate most is being accused of being a racist. I work for a department that helps immigrants and defends them against racism. It is my entire life. And being Jewish and having members of my family killed of by racism, I would appreciate it if people didn't just blindly accuse people of being racist- my question had nothing to do with race.



thanks, I actually did objectively want to know the answer, sorry if it seems like I have a "tone" The first guy to post said he hated me (the post is gone now) just because I was ignorant on this subject.

<answer from>



Adam F
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 1291 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



anarchy is similar to a free-market economy.  in a free-market economy (laissez  faire capitalism), the market determines the success or failure of companies, the prices of goods, etc.  in theory, without a government, the society would adjust to deal with miscreants instead of taking an attitude of "it's not my problem"



</answer>



<answer from>



Tripper
Member since: 03 May 2008
Total points: 239 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am not an anarchist per se.. but I do have an answer for you. Anarchists actually believe in the essential goodness of human beings, and not a hatred of humanity. They think that without governments and a centralized economy people will exchange goods through bartering, and will treat others with respect for the common good. Society will naturally reach a state of order based on mutual respect and the exchange of goods and services without money So no, they believe in the essential goodness of people.. the idea of governments as we have them now are actually based on the idea of people in a way being evil and therefore needing to be controlled by the legal system, the police, and legislation etc....  Anarchists believe that power corrupts (as it did in Stalin's case and as many argue does corrupt all U.S President's.. ) which is why people should govern themselves as they know what is best for them.



So in a way anarchism is Utopian, the goal is a perfect society where people do what they feel is best and trade their goods and services without paying tax etc... and treat each other with respect.



Source(s):



Personal research.



</answer>



<answer from>



Therapon
Member since: 10 May 2006
Total points: 2076 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm not an anarchist but know a few, I don't think they hate humanity but they do hate 'The Man'.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Are manners necessary for civilization?



yeah, what's your definition of civilization...



</question>



<answer from>



ektisang...
Member since: 24 October 2007
Total points: 4378 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



No! "Manner" is a relative word-----my (our) mannerism might not fit with yours. I've seen (read: experienced) so many mannerisms that are man-made or a particular society-product! It's not necessary to follow that manners by all. Probably we do have manners too, made by our men!



It's better to use the word "behavior"------and this word includes many many more qualities that enriched civilization or perhaps increased the speed of civilization towards a day-to-day development. (Civilization, I'm talking about, is not that Greek or Egyptian etc---rather civic sense related something. I've met persons with good manners from an uncivilized class.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank you for your answer.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Tiana✫
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 4656 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



MANNERS:
A characteristic or customary mode of acting: custom: a mode of procedure or way of acting: fashion: method of artistic execution or mode of presentation: style: social conduct or rules of conduct as shown in the prevalent customs: characteristic or distinctive bearing, air, or deportment: habitual conduct or deportment: behavior: good manners: a distinguished or stylish air.



CIVILIZATION:
A relatively high level of cultural and technological development; specifically: the stage of cultural development at which writing and the keeping of written records is attained: the culture characteristic of a particular time or place: the process of becoming civilized: refinement of thought, manners, or taste: a situation of urban comfort.



Yes, manners are necessary for civilization, as they are mentioned in both of the above definitions. My own definition of civilization? Everything that the definitions mentions, especially comfort (contented well-being).



Source(s):



definition: http://www.merriam-webster.com/



</answer>

<question>



For something to exist, does it need a beginning from another source?



A few choices come to mind:
1) God is the beginning of all things. He always existed.
2) Energy itself always existed. It has always been present.
3) The big bang started everything.
4) It is impossible to explain by human logic. It is beyond us.



Now the 5th choice is the one that really concerns and scares me actually. I have this belief that in order for let's say a line to exist, I have to draw it. In order for a tree to exist, it has to get started from something. In other words it is not just there; it has to have a beginning. So someone told me to base my thinking on the idea that the Big Bang is the beginning of everything, that there is nothing before the big bang. Wouldn't the big bang need to begin from something too? And here is the fifth choice:
5) Everything started from nothing.
This is my thought because scientists say that nothing existed before it. It is the beginning. How can something start from nothing. If that was the case, then we as humans originated from nothing. That is also something I am curious about. Is there such a thing as nothing? Is there such a thing out there where nothing exists. Where Atoms aren't present? What would this be like. Any and every thought, comment, idea is welcome.



In my opinion this actually sort of supports the existence of God. Another question is what about God himself. Does the bible say how God began? Like as humans, we began from Adam and Eve. But what about God?



So I guess this whole thing revolves around the thought "Everything has to have a beginning in order to exist?" Do you agree with this idea?



</question>

<answer from>



small
Member since: 21 September 2006
Total points: 35239 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Philosophy



</answer from>



<answer>



In my view, logic points to the contrary. It points to a strong possibility that there is no creation, that there is only transformation. The constancy of change gives us an illusory idea as though with every change something old is destroyed and something new is created. There is absolutely nothing before us to logically presume that anything can ever be created out of nothing. That is why even if we believe in God as the Original Creator, we have no other logical option but to suppose that God Himself was not created, that His existence is eternal. In my view therefore, the creation logic to support the existence of God is flawed. If God could be presumed to be existent forever, it should be equally possible to presume that the entire existence of everything (we may call it Nature or Universe) could similarly have been forever, never needed to have been created, and ever changing and transforming thereby giving us an illusory idea of a dynamics, which however, essentially amounts to zero creation or zero destruction.



I think that those who believe in God should never make the mistake of testing it out through logic....... if God exists, He is certainly not bound by our limited logic to be properly explained or understood through our logical thoughts.



</answer>

<question>



Who am "I"? Can there be another Me?



My existence and experience is to question.  Who am "I"? My way of thinking, My personality, all things that are intrinsic to Me... do I own them?  During my birth process, what if there was a slight change in my genetic make-up? Who would I be then? Would I still be Me? Or could I be YOU in the case that you were never born?



</question>



<answer from>



MR.QA
Member since: 13 March 2008
Total points: 4154 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



your true identity has no identity. you tack likes, traits, personalities... onto your mind and body when borned. if you define yourself as likes, traits, personality, then I could be you, given the same environmental and biological conditions. if you define yourself further, with brown hair, hazel eyes, likes basketball, and dancing, and in specific spacial-time location simultaneously, then I couldn't be you.



</answer>

<answer>



A good example of what you are asking about is in a story written by George Orwell's "Nineteen Eighty Four".  In this story, the world is at war between 3 superpowers.  The people of one nation are constantly watched (BIG BROTHER) and they are constantly told on monitor screens and loudspeakers what is happening.  The catch to the story that stood out tho, was that if the Government wanted to change history to manipulate the public, they did: They changed the story, changed the images and completely wiped out every trace of what happened... then it became just a memory ... then a vague thought ... and then ...nothing.  It is a good story (and not a bad movie)  but I believe that all that has happened in History, actually did happen as the observer believed it did... in the physical world.  The catch is that the physical world is not really what we are all about and it is up to each of us to figure out who we are and why we are here.



But that's another story.



Hope this helps

<answer>



I appreciate your stress in figuring out life.  For me, I backed off from trying to have "all the answers".  It is a matter of realizing you are just a grain of sand that is on a beach that goes forever.  It is a matter of your "Leap of Faith".  I learned to tone mine way down.  I just trust  (faith) I will have the answers I need to know... WHEN I need to know them.



In the mean time, I try to smell the roses... take in all the nature I can get.  Look at the small things and not worry as much about the big picture when it gets overwhelming.  You will find your way...just give yourself the time (there are no immediate answers).  That is what I have learned.



I drink diet pop around my keyboard... it isn't sticky... if I spill it.

<answer from>



elenchus...
Member since: 25 June 2007
Total points: 279 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



ASKER:
Damnit, I just spilled pepsi all over my keyboard. How do I get pepsi off of a keyboard?



ANSWERER:
It depends upon whether or not the Pepsi and Keyboard are real Pepsi and a real Keyboard --- or, on the other hand, merely imaginary Pepsi and an imaginary keyboard.



If real use a real damp cloth.  If imaginary just imagine cleaning the imaginary pepsi and imaginary keyboard with a (you imagined it) an imaginary damp cloth.



Source(s):



My imagination.



</answer>



<answer from>



wiseman/...
Member since: 22 May 2008
Total points: 6971 (Level 5)



</answer from>

According to Quantum Physics, you are a collection of molecules, rushing around to give the appearance of a you!  And they are so good at it that you parents, friends and family can recognize the you, you are.
About the pepsi, depends on how much and over what portion of the keyboard.  I had to buy a new one!

<answer>



There are many beleaguered souls cast into caves of iniquity that appear publicly with glowing smiles and dewy eyes. It is possible.



If happiness were caused by an amalgam of factors guaranteeing a state of happiness all would pursue it. There are certain prerequisites of happiness, a path toward this nirvana littered with fear of the unknown, hatred on a considered threat or enemy, ignorance of the unfamiliar.



The path lies within and without and the obstacles man made to ensure the ongoing struggle and suffering of mankind striving for emotional security and stability, a struggle creating a negative energy itself feeding the hatemonger’s quest for power.

<question from>



haringma...
Member since: 22 August 2006
Total points: 11439 (Level 6)



</question from>



<question>



Can philosophy ever lead to science and religion?



i dont think so, a friend told me that philosophy will lead to religion and science in the end, and i think he has not understood philosophy at all especially existentialism



can you present any arguments to support me?



</question>



<answer from>



Warman
Member since: 24 July 2008
Total points: 203 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Philosophy is the science which considers the truth. In which the truth is religion. Philosophy is done to bridge religion and science.



</answer>



<answer from>



steffi
Member since: 25 January 2007
Total points: 2723 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The answer to your question is yes, it already has. Study Socrates and Plato, etc. Does ALL philosophy lead to religion and science? No.



</answer>



<answer from>



randomwr...
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 215 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Philosophy is actually (historically) the foundation of science, look at all the philosophers of the classical times, they observed, and then formulated a theory on how this works, and supported this with their arguments. Science nowadays has more tools to determine the cause of something, so it is more accurate.
But all the sciences (Biology, Physics, Chemistry) started with people philosophizing about natural phenomenons.



</answer>



<answer from>



Eoredd
Member since: 20 November 2006
Total points: 28430 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Philosophy thinks science and religion, in the form of epistemology and theology. Science and religion are objects of the philosophical thought and commentary, but philosophical discipline doesn't lead to science (which is a very specific field of knowledge, very specialized) and doesn't lead to religion either, for religion is based on faith, living experience of the divine, and thought, whereas philosophy implies doubt, research and reason. Some philosophers were believers though, but they never confused their philosophical work with their personal faith.



</answer>



<answer from>



Old guy
Member since: 20 September 2007
Total points: 6080 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



No, I think your friend is correct.  The study of thought can naturally lead to study of the brain.  Study of the brain can naturally lead to the study of consciousness.  The study of consciousness naturally leads to two camps; materialism and religion.



</answer>



<answer from>



Robert K
Member since: 18 May 2008
Total points: 4881 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Such things as philosophy, science and religion do not have to be in conflict.  In fact, it's possible for all of them to "work together."  It just could be that many of us are considering the same things, but we're approaching them from different viewpoints.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bai L
Member since: 27 March 2008
Total points: 1210 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes I believe it can, based on the willingness and predispositions of the person searching.



I cannot give you any arguments against, I would tend to agree with your friend.  Existentialism is just one part of philosophy, I think it is you that hasn't understood.



Francis Bacon - "A little philosophy inclineth man's mind to atheism; but depth in philosophy bringeth men's minds about to religion."



Truth is absolute but many absolutely don't want truth.
Bai

<answer>

<answer from>



Mr. Mister
Member since: 23 February 2008
Total points: 1880 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Science is supposed to be based on verifiable facts, and you can't verify philosophy. Although philosophy tries to base it's logic on facts, it veers off into speculations that can't be verified because philosophy is subjective in the end.



Philosophy can't lead to religion either, since religion comes to conclusions and beliefs that philosophy shies away from. Philosophy can't stay "open to" and keep it's speculations ongoing in it's search for Truth if it comes to a conclusion or forms beliefs. Philosophy can make you act more ethically, for awhile, but your philosophical thoughts die away because there isn't a written ethical code that you're following as in religion.



</answer>



<answer from>



Siddhart...
Member since: 07 December 2006

<answer from>



Aly

<answer>



It's relative. Sure you may receive bias in your favor because you are more attractive compared to another person. You may be able to land that job, get free stuff or discounts, or get invited to the big party.
But, and this is a big BUT, if you do receive this favoritism (especially if it is female reciprocating from a male) you cannot trust anyone or anything.



Did you nail that job interview based on your talents or because you're good-looking? Is the boss expecting you to sleep with him now because "you owe him"? Did the guy who works at starbucks charge you for a tall when you got a grande because you are a loyal customer or because he's trying to score a date with you?
Sure, you get some perks for being attractive but the loss is that one is objectified and that individual can no longer trust others' true  motives.



Additionally, I don't think it is necessarily a bad thing for a person (esp. women) to exploit their appearance to "get ahead," because in the end the individual will be judged accordingly. If you go into an interview with a plunging neckline, the interviewer might be more inclined to put you in a job position that entitles customer service while the "bigger people do the big work."



</answer>

Many women I know use their attractiveness to their advantage. I try very hard not to. How does one know if one is being taken out if its only because of physical beauty... I would much rather be prized for my inner strengths than for my fading looks.



</answer>

<question>



Can you really ignore the future and just think about the present?



i dont think we could ever ignore the past, it is rooted embedded and would always be there as long as we have memories however future occuriences, future worries, can we really do away with it and just live for the moment?

Venus 1485AD
Member since: 23 June 2008

<answer from>



guru
Member since: 07 April 2007
Total points: 12242 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Living for the moment is not an ideal way to live either. The issue is that of worry and fear. One can be hopeful of the future, or fear it. It varies depending on how we construct the time frame. We can look back on the best in a negative or positive way. We can even choose to be neutral about the past, present and future.



Worrying is a type of thinking.



</answer>

When a pilot flies a plane from one destination to another destination ...he has direction, and destination. He also has a carved path on which he/she suppose to keep the plane on ...however, plane doesn't always stay on that path .....infact there are many big and medium size deviations  ....so pilot keeps aligning the plane keeping it on the path carved by computer ...he/she keep checking over and over and they keep examining their path to destination ever FEW minutes ...



same applies to life ... we can't ignore the past ...we can't stop worrying about future ...but if you keep your eyes on present ...YOU WILL AUTOMATICALLY be able to ignore the past and stop worrying about future ....or at least they won't bother you too much ..just keep aligning your path ...and DON'T WORRY too much ...Life will work itself out ...just work hard on your present projects ...Take some tough decisions or risks .... Think Positive ....Be more optimistic and see life's bigger picture ...you are alive, you are healthy and you have shelter, food and clothes ....then we got the first base down .... we can start now ..

<answer>



You can try, but since past behavior predicts future behavior, making your present the learning annex, it's difficult to 'forget' that the future will happen. For example: If all your life you have never been loved, no matter how many people you've known...At some point, in your present, you are going to realize that the future is going to be no different. So living in the present will just be depressing, but you will already sense the lack of change that is coming...



</answer>

Consequently, it is by Meditation that you quieten the conscious mind and allow the subconscious to move forward, take over, so to speak, and this is done in order to contact the superconscious mind, the Christ. <asker's comment>



Virtually every answer is a "keeper" but I was intrigued by your depiction and answer.  It was both scientific and spiritual.  Sometimes the two don't mesh, but you have rocked them together in the same crib.  Thank You...

<answer from>



I'm Hare!
Member since: 03 April 2008
Total points: 20433 (Level 6)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



Challenging question but more psychological than philosophic as there are many doctors doing many amazing things to do exactly what you are asking, trying to reach the subconscious by any means possible.



The answer is No.



You can try sleep therapy. You can try hypnosis.



You can try a treatment that sets up blocks in you conscious to try and avoid it all together. that is a radical idea but it is theoretically possible to train a person's brain to see  anything but reality. Call it brain washing.



The whole answer would be huge to show you all the possibilities but I think the answer is complete in its brevity and points you in the right direction.



You might want to look into post traumatic stress disorders too. there is a lot of research on the subconscious in that area.



</answer>



<answer from>



Happy Hiram
Member since: 28 March 2008
Total points: 13896 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Does intuition go from the front to the back and back out? Do dreams come from my conscious experiences only? Is the subconscious mind a piece of meat or does it have its' own internal processes? Where does the energy for these processes arise? Is instinct a conscious drive with subconscious effects?



The subconscious mind is in effect a funnel, a mile wide at the back and thinner than the eye of a needle where it meets the conscious mind.



My conscious and subconscious mind are not separated properly, so I have personal insight into this issue. When I don't drown it out, my every thought is an "echo" of what my subconscious is addressing, and believe me, it comes in from the back, not the other way around.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mr. Wizard
Member since: 16 May 2007
Total points: 3544 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes... It is only through the conscious mind that anything can be understood. All knowledge is gained through the conscious minds' interpretation of the information gained through the senses. Every experience; sight, smell, touch etc, must be processed by the mind to be of any use at all to us. (The eye perceives images upside down and must be inverted by the brain before we can even 'see' anything.)



Because the term 'subconscious' can mean various things in different contexts, there is a tendency for confusion and consequently the subconscious can be sometimes even worshipped/venerated to a religious degree.



You nailed it with, "if you disagree, what other means are there ?" there are no other means...



</answer>



<answer from>



Tiana✫
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 4586 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



CONSCIOUS:
1: perceiving, apprehending, or noticing with a degree of controlled thought or observation.



2 archaic: sharing another's knowledge or awareness of an inward state or outward fact.
3: personally felt.



4: capable of or marked by thought, will, design, or perception.
5: self-conscious.
6: having mental faculties undulled by sleep, faintness, or stupor: awake.



7: done or acting with critical awareness.



8 a: likely to notice, consider, or appraise b: being concerned or interested c: marked by strong feelings or notions.



SUBCONSCIOUS:
Existing in the mind but not immediately available to consciousness.



According to the dictionary definitions, the answer to your question is yes. I am a person who prospers in my conscious mind and in  positive controlled thought and observation. My past exists in my subconscious.



Source(s):



http://www.merriam-webster.com/



</answer>

<question from>



Joe K
Member since: 15 June 2008
Total points: 139 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



For something to exist, does it need a beginning from another source? A few choices come to mind:?



1) God is the beginning of all things. He always existed.
2) Energy itself always existed. It has always been present.
3) The big bang started everything.
4) It is impossible to explain by human logic. It is beyond us.



Now the 5th choice is the one that really concerns and scares me actually. I have this belief that in order for let's say a line to exist, I have to draw it. In order for a tree to exist, it has to get started from something. In other words it is not just there; it has to have a beginning. So someone told me to base my thinking on the idea that the Big Bang is the beginning of everything, that there is nothing before the big bang. Wouldn't the big bang need to begin from something too? And here is the fifth choice:
5) Everything started from nothing.
This is my thought because scientists say that nothing existed before it. It is the beginning. How can something start from nothing. If that was the case, then we as humans originated from nothing. That is also something I am curious about. Is there such a thing as nothing? Is there such a thing out there where nothing exists. Where Atoms aren't present? What would this be like. Any and every thought, comment, idea is welcome.



In my opinion this actually sort of supports the existence of God. Another question is what about God himself. Does the bible say how God began? Like as humans, we began from Adam and Eve. But what about God?



So I guess this whole thing revolves around the thought "Everything has to have a beginning in order to exist?" Do you agree with this idea?



</question>



<answer from>



Lauren
Member since: 12 January 2008
Total points: 138 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<answer>



Love can mean several things.



Innocent child loves another innocent child without any reservation.



A mother loves her child.



A man loves his wife.



The same love can not be meted out in the same fashion at every time i.e. over a period of aging. The way we love our mother at our innocent tender age cannot be repeated later in our life.



We love our body and its handsomeness during youth. When we become old we start hating our own body.



So I think we cannot love everyone on the street. We should be selective.

</category>



<question from>



Optimus Nate Primal
Member since: 18 December 2006
Total points: 4812 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



What do you understand with this quote "War is peace, freedom is slavery, ignorance is strength"?



George Orwell, 1984



</question>



<answer from>



Puli
Member since: 13 October 2008
Total points: 359 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think the quote stands alone very well without the overall context of the story. Clearly, in 1984, this quote reinforces the idea that one must blindly follow the party and "love big brother." War is the status-quo for Oceania, the citizens should find that strictly following the party is a freeing experience (a form of ultimate surrender, if you will), and ignorance is definitely a strength for the characters under this fictional regime (not knowing/acknowledging subversive activities and thoughts makes it less possible to commit a "thought crime."



Just my thoughts, anyway. :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Lauren
Member since: 12 January 2008
Total points: 140 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



1984 has to be the best book I have ever read. I absolutely love this quote - when I first read the book (I was 12) I didn't understand it but now I realise that this BB quote basically sums up unjust communism's 'victims' and their lives.



Source(s):



My brain?



</answer>
