<answer from>



Envious Sleep
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 266 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Being intelligent (and mature) means being able to type out "you" with all three letters. But I digress.



Getting A's on all your exams is not all about intelligence. It is part intelligence and part memorization. Memorization is not intelligence. And I get A's on all my exams, but I'm not an intellectual. I'm just smart.



"Speaking all the right stuff" does not make grammatical sense. Therefore, it is not intelligent.  However, being able to put the right words in the right place and thus emitting a sophisticated air dose make one seem intelligent, even if they are only pretending.



Overcoming daily problems is not a challenge for most people with the will to. Daily problems means common problems; common people are therefore able to solve them without problems. Intelligent, by definition, means a stronger, faster, better cognitive process and so is beyond 'common'.



...Solving daily problems does not constitute intelligence. It only requires will.



Solving this question does not require intelligence either. It only requires an opinion and a will and ability to back it up. That is not intelligence; it's human stubbornness. That is not intelligence.



In conclusion, none of these choices can be considered intelligent.



</answer>

<answer from>



sadsac
Member since: 11 August 2006
Total points: 538 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



For questions such as these, it is important to define your terms. By 'life', I assume that you mean human life. Because if you meant all life, then life is never fair because all life occurs at the expense of other life.



But for human life, It is not impossible for life to be 'fair'
(must use air quotes, since defining 'fair' isn't so easy).



But history shows that life is regularly 'unfair' to at least some humans. And perhaps overly 'fair' to others.



As far as 'God' is concerned (should 'God' exisit), it either tells us that how things are is how god intended (what seems unfair to us may not be unfair to god). Or, that God is unfair. Fairness is a traditional attribute of god, so either this is how God intended, or God doesn't exist.



</answer>



<answer from>



Adam F
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 1303 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



is the concept of objectivity alien to all of you?  clearly, it is.  define "fair", define "justice", define "life", and what does it even matter if we think "life is un/fair"?  the world is going to be the same whether we approve or not.



furthermore, you go turning an ethics question into a discussion that assumes you can understand the character and intent of an infinite, all-powerful entity.  why not just be straight-forward in your question instead of beating around the bush?  ask whether your invisible man who controls everything is on your side.



if everything is in your favor, is that fair?  no, because it is not favoring someone else.  stop being so egocentric and join the rest of the world.



how many negative points will i receive for this?  5?



</answer>



<answer from>



pkm trainer
Member since: 03 August 2007
Total points: 2830 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Put simply - people attract what they need in life, we desire love, knowledge,  and creativity.  Trying to get and maintain a balance in life is most important.  Only balanced people can pass judgement on others for it to be fair.  I'm not exactly sure what fair is ? but I think its to do with treating others with respect and respecting yourself.



Fairness is a non-judgemental attitude to others.  A fair person will respect the individual needs of others giving attention when it is needed to particular areas.  He/she will have self-respect and
give guidance to others, by being fair and just to others we are treating each other in the way God envisioned.  Look at the answers above - so many people do not understand what fairness is - it is nothing at all to do with circumstance but is treating others with kindness and love.  We should all be more loving.  There is no one who has been able to be as loving and kind as God but we should all aspire to be as loving as we can.



</answer>

Didn't you watch Pulp Fiction's rendition of Ezekiel 25:17, which by the way wasn't even accurate?



Ahem "Ezekiel 25:17" according to Samuel L. Jackson;



"The path, of the righteous man is beset on all sides by the iniquities (injustices) of the selfish, and the tyranny of evil men.  Blessed is he, who shepherds the weak through the valley of darkness, for he is truly his brother's keeper, but I will strike down upon thee with GREAT VENGEANCE, and FURIOUS ANGER, those who attempt to POISON, and DESTROY my brothers, and you WILL KNOW, MY NAME IS THE LORD, when I lay my vengeance upon thee...."



The iniquities of the selfish, and the tyranny of evil men (and women); that is the sad truth of life.



Indeed, "the law," and "justice," are two separate things.  Very, separate things.  Justice, simply defined, is not letting selfish sadists, sadistic sociopaths who enjoy harming people, get away with their crimes.



Revenge, is wishing to harm someone, simply because you are such an arrogant turd, you can't stand the fact that they stood up to you.



Example; killing a KKK rapist of a black girl lynch style, THAT, is justice.



Attacks on Afghanistan by the U.S., that was not justice, that was revenge.



The way the old testament defines justice as an "eye for an eye" is, that if someone did you a terrible wrong, the price exacted to pay for it, must match the wrong inflicted.



White people in the U.S. hunted the native americans to extinction, the eye for an eye law says, someday they too will be hunted to extinction, and the people who do it, will show the same arrogance, apathy, and cruelty, they showed the natives.  They will beg for mercy, but the world will not listen.  They will scream "human rights!  human rights" but their cries will fall on deaf ears.



You think that for all their cruelty, all their malice, that the white people should just walk away like nothing happened, taking the easy way out?  No man.....



</answer>

<question>



How can I prove God's existence?



I have to write a religious studies essay on how to prove God's existence. In the essay, I have to include stuff such as the creation argument, the design argument, the moral argument and miracles. How can I use that to structure my essay? I have no idea how to start it off and what to write.



Please help!



</question>



<answer from>



Julius C
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 135 (Level 1)



</answer from>

Tripper

<answer>



Belief in God is a personal matter, it should not be a matter of proving or disproving his existence.. that would be my essay anyway. The creation argument, the design argument, the moral argument and miracles: none prove his existence. There is definitely something intangible and magical about life, Christian's just choose to call that God (and say he is a man?!). Sorry, I know my answer hasn't really helped.. good luck with it.

Personal philosophizing



</answer>



<answer from>



Lauren
Member since: 12 January 2008
Total points: 140 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Start with an intro with some facts like how many christians there are in the world etc. then ask could all these people be wrong? What are the strong arguments for God? Then write out the arguments one by one. If you want a really high level, include the weaknesses of the argument, then disprove them. End with a strong conclusion including all the arguments you have used and a personal opinion. Hope this helps!



Source(s):



Personal experience



</answer>



<answer from>



wolschou
Member since: 09 September 2006
Total points: 7021 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Julius is right.



None of the arguments you are supposed to use can actually prove god's existence... just as no argument brought against it can ever prove his nonexistence.



the reason for this is that the matter of god's existence removes itself from any kind of argument. the very nature alleged to god by his believers defies logic or rational treatment.



you can believe or disbelieve in god as much as you like. you won't ever find conclusive evidence one way or the other.



its as simple as that. then again... its just my own opinion and in no way compulsory :)



As for your essay you should first describe the general disagreement between theists and atheists, then give an overwiew of the theistic arguments as you did above.



then you should give a brief summation of each argument, and describe how it is supposed to prove gods existence, and then state and explain your own opinion, wether or not it really does.



depending on your findings you then conclude which, if any, arguments can be seen as proof of gods existence.



</answer>

Member since: 23 April 2006
Total points: 17335 (Level 6)

<answer from>



jb
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 1403 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The only way to "prove" this, that I know of, it the Cartesian method.  You ultimately end up looking in on yourself, which forces all of us, then, to do the same.  It forces you to accept that God is a product -- though not necessarily a figment -- of the imagination.  It situates God in the realm of "that which cannot be humanly understood but yet logically conclude it exists."  For Descartes, God existed for the same reason triangles existed.  It's actually pretty cool, because it forces you to respect other people's gods . . . but it does not address the "ethics" question.



I'm sure there are Eastern philosophies to this.  Taoism (or Daoism) is quite nice.  But this question seems like it forces you into a Western conceptualization of God and religion.



</answer>



<answer from>



Yash P
Member since: 31 October 2008

<question>



Why Is It Looked Down Upon To Be A Homemaker Without Children?



</question>



<additional details>



My husband doesn't make a ton of money, but we are very frugal.  We have no debt and quite a large amount in savings.  I also bring some income in, but I don't work at what most people would refer to as a "real job".



</additional details>



<answer from>



Lara
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 155 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Probably becasue people assume if you're not working then you must be claiming benefit, and if you're claiming benefit, you should work. But if you're not claiming money from the state, and you can afford to stay at home, I don't see why that's wrong. I wish I could stay at home!



</answer>



<answer from>



lolly
Member since: 17 January 2008
Total points: 8741 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Singles & Dating



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't look down at it. But at  the same time, I also can't imagine a life without doing something. But if someone who lives that lifestyle still has something with meaning in their life, then thats fine. But if its just sitting at home all day doing nothing all alone, then I just dont even see the point in that kind of existence. If theres more to it, then great, no issues at all.



</answer>



<answer from>



astra.ma...
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 525 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Because then there isn't much to do! You clean, you tidy then what? Its really not much so  of course its looked down  upon. Children make it more difficult??



</answer>

Karen
Member since: 31 October 2007
Total points: 3216 (Level 4)

I'm afraid to say it is not all lies. If you are doing your part of the deal I see no reason you should be looked down upon. Kudos to you for standing up for your life choice.



</answer>
